entry.name: AlienIntelligence
entry.value: Alien Intelligence

entry.name: AlienIntelligence/Escort
entry.value:
If the Voice has shaped the Acrin for generations, then their folktales contain vital data. You accept Landan’s deal and mobilize a squad to deal with anything guarding the crash site.

You won’t be the first to pull the trigger, but you’ll be prepared for when it happens.

entry.name: AlienIntelligence/EscortFailure
entry.value:
As you head towards the Azad, a dark form crashes into the rear of your forces, spraying dry dirt upwards in sods and clumps.

Once the dust clears, your forces appear mostly unharmed—all except Landan. What remains of him lies in a small crater, embraced by a nightmare of tiny, grasping hands and rows of human teeth. Even the most battle-hardened turn away from the sight.

If your forces fight their way to the data-vault now, without Landan you can gather nothing.

You bury what little remains of the engineer and return to base.

entry.name: AlienIntelligence/EscortSuccess
entry.value:
You arrive and quickly dispatch the Acrin forces before heading inside.

The data vault is a matte monolith in the center of the Azad’s shattered command deck. Landan grins like a child as he studies the device. He initiates the transfer and web-thin cracks erupt along the vault’s surface, bleeding harsh light into the dim room.

He hands you a data-slab afterwards but leaves while you bury the dead Acrin. You’ve got the data, but at what cost?

Once you survive, you’ll atone. For now, you head home.

entry.name: AlienIntelligence/EscortHaggle
entry.value:
If the Voice has shaped the Acrin for generations, then their folktales contain vital data. Still, there are guardians around the crash site and you’re reluctant to risk a firefight over fiction.

You renegotiate the deal with Landan so he pays to cover the risk to your forces. He curses but accepts after it’s clear you’re adamant. He’s quiet as you mobilize your forces and head out.

entry.name: AlienIntelligence/EscortHaggleSuccess
entry.value:
You arrive and quickly dispatch the Acrin forces before heading inside.

The data vault is a matte monolith in the center of the Azad’s shattered command deck. Landan grins like a child as he studies the device. He initiates the transfer and web-thin cracks erupt along the vault’s surface.

He hands you a data-slab afterwards and departs as you bury the dead Acrin.

It’s not until he’s gone that you discover the Shredder virus he installed. Your specialists stop it, but not before it destroys half the data.

You’ve still profited today, but at what cost?

entry.name: AlienIntelligence/Intro
entry.value:
Your guards grudgingly allow a slight figure to approach. He’s a data historian by the name of Landan Graham, who’s documenting the fall of Earth, he says for the hereafter. One of the Acrin settlement vessels ‘Azad’ crash-landed nearby and his research among the ship’s survivors has uncovered something unusual—that it contains a vault packed with their race’s folk tales and stories.

The Acrin consider it a gravesite and taboo—but he asks if you’ll guide him there, so he can access the vault. In return, he promises he’ll give you a copy of the data, in case any of it is of use.

entry.name: AlienIntelligence/Intro/Escort
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Escort the Historian:<style name='Paragraph'/> You prepare a small expedition that will take him to the distant location.

entry.name: AlienIntelligence/Intro/EscortHaggle
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Demand payment up front:<style name='Paragraph'/> You ask Landan to cover the costs of the expedition supplies.

entry.name: AlienIntelligence/Intro/Refuse
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Refuse to help:<style name='Paragraph'/> Acrin sacred ground? A long way away? For stories? He can find someone else with a deathwish.

entry.name: AlienIntelligence/RefuseFailure
entry.value:
Knowledge is valuable—but folktales and stories? You won’t spill blood over fiction.

Landan’s face twists into a scowl when you reject him. He leaves swiftly, the dust trail from his transport speeding towards your nearest rival’s camp. Days later you hear of his death at the hands of the Acrin.

It seems you’ve avoided a disaster. While you didn’t gain any knowledge, your restraint displayed your wisdom.

entry.name: AlienIntelligence/RefuseSuccess
entry.value:
Knowledge is valuable—but folktales and stories? You won’t spill blood over fiction.

Landan’s face twists into a scowl when you reject him. He leaves swiftly, the dust trail from his transport speeding towards your nearest rival’s camp. Days later you hear of his death at the hands of the Acrin. Your scouts bring you a message from the Anchorite, the oldest and most esteemed Acrin. It reads: “Why steal what can be shared? Your restraint earned our gratitude.”

You save the message. It seems you’ve gained something more valuable than folktales today.

entry.name: AreMachinesAlive
entry.value: Are Machines Alive?

entry.name: AreMachinesAlive/Intro
entry.value:
It began as whispers in the short-waves and cubic faces in the static. Reports of supernatural activity flooded in from every part of the city, inciting panic and unrest.

Investigations reveal a strange intelligence emerging from the city’s devices. No one knows where or how it started, but it’s clear that the change is permanent.

Now the unrest centers on how to treat this artificial life. Is their future among us or above us? Or can we keep them as mere tools? Debate erupts into violence as opinion is divided.

entry.name: AreMachinesAlive/Intro/MachineEvolution
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Machines are alive:<style name='Paragraph'/> The machines pass all known evaluations of personhood. By all standards, they should enjoy all the same rights that we do.

entry.name: AreMachinesAlive/Intro/MachineRights
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Machines are the next step:<style name='Paragraph'/> Even in their early stages, these machines are more capable than any human. If we seek swift victory, then we must exploit every advantage.

entry.name: AreMachinesAlive/Intro/MachineServants
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Machines are servants:<style name='Paragraph'/> If the machines excel at work, then let them labor. And if they don’t need to rest, then all the better for us.

entry.name: AreMachinesAlive/Intro/MachineTools
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Machines are tools:<style name='Paragraph'/> This could be the next ZEPHON. Find and disable the machine's major cognition clusters, then reboot them with just work functions.

entry.name: AreMachinesAlive/MachineEvolution
entry.value:
The world is no longer humanity’s alone. The corruption of the Voice seeps into both humans and Acrin—but not the machine. Perhaps this new artificial life is the edge you need to win.

You task your splicer drones with accelerating their evolution. The neo genesis is a huge success. Your new artificial citizens join your city, and their unique minds make them peerless scientists.

Just after your new digital citizens settle in, an explosion destroys one of their blocks. A group of your seasoned troops claim responsibility and go rogue. Now you must stop their senseless rampage.

entry.name: AreMachinesAlive/MachineRights
entry.value:
The world is no longer humanity’s alone. The relentless drive of ZEPHON threatens all life on Earth—but could it have evolved differently?

Your city’s most brilliant minds study these new lifeforms to determine whether they possess not just intelligence, but consciousness. The labs in your city are filled with their tireless experimentation.

The effort is a huge success. Your new artificial citizens integrate easily into your society. There’s surging optimism about the future, but the study exhausts your resources. You’ll need to redouble efforts in any stalled projects, but there are now many more eager to help.

entry.name: AreMachinesAlive/MachineServants
entry.value:
Your city’s most brilliant minds study these new lifeforms to determine whether they’re a threat. When they discover that the machines' only desire is to fulfill their function, a new working class is born. A radical shift occurs where machines dominate the labor pool while humans manage them. This new balance suits both sides—for now.

You wonder about the clear divide established between humans and machines. How long can this arrangement last—and are the machines done evolving?

entry.name: AreMachinesAlive/MachineTools
entry.value:
Have we learned nothing from our past mistakes? While we know their design, the mind of the machine is as alien to us as the Acrin. Why risk creating a future threat?

You task your Hacker-Jackers to cut into the machines and erase the errant code responsible for their burgeoning autonomy. One of them prioritized speed over software integrity and the machines in their research lab go berserk, razing the compound before escaping the city to continue their rampage.

The other machines are successfully processed to become tireless—and now unwavering—construction tools.

entry.name: BlackSite
entry.value: Black Site

entry.name: BlackSite/Assault
entry.value:
There’s much to gain and everything to lose, so you mobilize your forces for an attack.

You unleash waves of malware and stutter-viruses to distract and slow ZEPHON’s countermeasures as you rush towards the site. Time is limited, you must hurry before there’s no chance.

Leviathan squat machines burst from the ground. Spider-limbed and dog-like, they fire missiles from a distance before engaging your troops with sawblades and flamethrowers.

entry.name: BlackSite/AssaultFailure
entry.value:
The fight is fierce, but victory takes too long. You can't access the black site before ZEPHON’s countermeasures come fully online. Your returning forces are unaware they’re carriers of a ZEPHON polymorphic virus targeted at your infrastructure.

It spreads quickly. Your engineers scramble to stop the virus from turning your power plants into fission bombs, but they fry the sub-stations in the process.

While repairs to the power network take place, your entire population sits in the dark, fingers on weapon triggers, staring into the gloom and waiting…

entry.name: BlackSite/AssaultSuccess
entry.value:
The fight is fierce, but in the end you emerge victorious.

The site turns out to be a massive factory for the machines you fought topside. You strip its resources before demolishing the foundations.

As the facility’s buried, you wonder how many other black sites ZEPHON’s hiding—and what answers they may contain.

entry.name: BlackSite/Assist
entry.value:
A machine may not know faith, but what about good faith? You decide to find out as you contact ZEPHON to reveal you know about their black site.

The AI pauses for two seconds, an infinity from its perspective, as it calculates your offer to help. You keep a finger on your network kill switch, hopeful that your system’s defenses can buy you the second you need to push it if things turn hostile.

Then your display distorts with RGB static and reforms into a series of symbols forming a smiling face. Then the link goes dead. Your deal has been accepted—right?

entry.name: BlackSite/IgnoreFailure
entry.value:
A machine doesn’t have trust, just programming. You think ZEPHON will leave you alone as long as you don’t present a threat, so you decide to ignore the presence of the black site.

Time passes as you wait. Then one night you wake to the ground beneath your city trembling and a peeling metallic cacophony rising in the distance. Your sentries burst in with dire news: there’s a battalion of spider-limbed warmachines pouring from the black site, and they’re headed your direction.

entry.name: BlackSite/IgnoreSuccess
entry.value:
A machine doesn’t have trust, just programming. You think ZEPHON will leave you alone as long as you don’t present a threat, so you decide to ignore the presence of the black site.

Time passes as you wait. Then one night the ground beneath your city begins to tremble and a peeling metallic cacophony rises in the distance. Your city is put on alert, but everything quiets after several hours.

The next morning the black site is gone. Scanners reveal the hollow is no longer there. Whatever was unleashed or buried there, it did not concern you.

entry.name: BlackSite/Infiltrate
entry.value:
The only trustworthy allies are ones you’re spying on. While ZEPHON’s eyes are omnipresent, a single specialist can slip through—or be disavowed. A shadow operative or a sensate master would be perfect, or maybe such an important mission warrants a commander’s participation.

Whatever your choice, reports indicate you’ve got limited time before the convoys are unloaded and the doors sealed.

entry.name: BlackSite/InfiltrateFailure
entry.value:
The towering cavern doors are sealed by the time your operative arrives. A search reveals an unsecured access port hidden in the metal. They tap in, hoping to learn about this facility and disappear before ZEPHON is aware of their presence.

Then it’s all abruptly wrong. The I/O channels flip. The encryption is shattered. Junk data floods in as your data is extracted. Screens across your systems flicker and print a message in an endless loop: //[Hello, goodbye]. CuriositY [Kills]. cUriosiTy [kIlls]. cuRiosIty [kiLls]. curIoSity [kilLs]. curiOsity [killS]. [hello, Goodbye].//

The link is severed after a minute, but it’s too late. ZEPHON knows. And it’s coming.

entry.name: BlackSite/InfiltrateSuccess
entry.value:
Your operative arrives at the convoy doors and slips inside undetected. The facility turns out to be a massive factory for spider-limbed warmachines. ZEPHON is producing an army and you need to know for what purpose.

An unguarded access port yields detailed production notes but nothing about ZEPHON’s plans. With your consolation prize in hand, you return to base.

entry.name: BlackSite/Inform
entry.value:
The Anchorite listens to your revelation in silence. Their posture changes and they make a motion that you’ve come to learn as concern. They then thank you for your information and drop the link.

A day later the black site is wiped out in a massive attack. The fields surrounding the location are a waste of twisted metal and dead Acrin. What had the Anchorite realized that broke their pacifism?

Maybe they’ll tell you one day, but for now you’ve gained standing with a potential ally and dealt with a threat—all at no cost to your forces.

entry.name: BlackSite/Intro
entry.value:
Although further readings were all blocked, your recon teams spotted supply convoys entering a connected cavern.

You thought ZEPHON was an ally to humanity. Why have they not disclosed such a large, secure location so near your base?

Can you trust the machine? Or is this a sign of its hidden intent?

entry.name: BlackSite/Intro2
entry.value: One of your recon teams reports they found evidence of an underground ZEPHON black site. They ran a Crypt-Scan, hoping to find a server bunker or skunkworks, but instead the images returned a massive shielded hollow.

entry.name: BlackSite/Intro/Assault
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Assault:<style name='Paragraph'/> There’s a simple way to both deal with the threat and get much needed supplies. Mobilize your forces to take over the site.

entry.name: BlackSite/Intro/Infiltrate
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Infiltrate:<style name='Paragraph'/> There’s too much at stake for trust. Send a specialist to sneak in and verify the purpose of the site.

entry.name: BlackSite/Intro/Assist
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Offer assistance:<style name='Paragraph'/> Trust goes both ways. Disclose your knowledge of the site and offer to help ZEPHON in whatever it’s doing.

entry.name: BlackSite/Intro/Inform
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Inform Anchorite:<style name='Paragraph'/> The enemy of my enemy is my friend. Inform the Anchorite of ZEPHON’s activities and encourage them to take care of it.

entry.name: BlackSite/Intro/InformProperties
entry.value: Requires contact with <icon height='20' texture='Icons/Factions/Anchorite'/> <string name='Factions/Anchorite'/>.

entry.name: BlackSite/Intro/Ignore
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Ignore:<style name='Paragraph'/> There are bigger issues to deal with. Whatever ZEPHON’s up to, it’s proven itself trustworthy.

entry.name: ChildOfTheNewWorld
entry.value: Child of the New World

entry.name: ChildOfTheNewWorld/Intro
entry.value:
“Bullshit.”

The word escapes your mouth before you even think over the Anchorite's jumbled words. Untangling them always takes a moment, but you already know what he proposes is ridiculous: no Acrin have ever been free from the Voice.

His limbs jitter in response to your insult. “To think such a future could come could be naive,” he muses. “To know that the future depends on such children… to accept that naivety may be a shield for hope.”

Wait—he said “children.” Your mind races. Acrin children? Even after twenty years, descriptions of such beings have been rare. Giving birth on a hostile alien planet is no easy feat.

The Anchorite notices your pensive gaze. His eyes rotate and narrow. “To contemplate children,” it says. “To dream of a better future for your people. To know they are at the mercy of…” Something flickers across his face. The hairs on his limbs curl. “The Voice. And its… Twisted Augur.”

entry.name: ChildOfTheNewWorld/Intro/TrackAugur
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Track down the Acrin children:<style name='Paragraph'/> The children are being held by a Voice cultist only known as the Twisted Augur. You'll need to find where he's holding them.

entry.name: ChildOfTheNewWorld/Intro/ContactAugur
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Contact the Augur:<style name='Paragraph'/> <string name='Quests/ChildOfTheNewWorld/Intro/ContactAugurFlavor'/>

entry.name: ChildOfTheNewWorld/Intro/ContactAugurFlavor
entry.value: The Anchorite is so eager to deny these children a touch of the divine. This Twisted Augur may need your aid.

entry.name: ChildOfTheNewWorld/Intro/Ignore
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Ignore the Anchorite's ramblings:<style name='Paragraph'/> There's always been something off about the Anchorite. You're better off staying out of Acrin affairs.

entry.name: ChildOfTheNewWorld/TrackAugurSuccess
entry.value:
The Twisted Augur is a name that strikes fear in the wasteland's survivors. He comes in the night with an army of dark creatures, searching for children who may be bound by the Voice.

The Anchorite didn't tell you that the Augur hunts human children too. He's become a bogeyman. Something parents use to keep the young ones from running out into the waste. If they stray too far, monsters will burst from the dirt and drag them into tunnels full of worms.

Digging—tunnels—worms. Aegyllan Worms. The Augur is using Aegyllan Worms to dig tunnels beneath the wasteland. His menagerie of monsters would be able to move undetected.

Survivors may fear the Augur, but you do not. Now that you know what you are hunting, you might draw the malicious prophet out from the depths.

entry.name: ChildOfTheNewWorld/TrackAugurSuccess/HuntMonsters
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Hunt the Augur's monsters:<style name='Paragraph'/> The Augur's beasts are on the hunt. Kill them, rescue their prisoners, and the Augur may come to you.

entry.name: ChildOfTheNewWorld/HuntMonstersSuccess
entry.value:
The good news is you were able to track down the Augur's monsters. The bad news is that none of them had any kidnapped children in their possession.

You inform the Anchorite. “To consider an unthinkable plan,” he says. “To know that the Augur can be one step ahead. To conceive that to lure him out, one must give him what he wants.”

Before you can say anything, the Anchorite gestures to his guards. They retrieve a poor human family you passed on the way in. They shelter a young Acrin. His people call him Ja'Kalit. The humans call him “The Jackal.”

You didn't know you would be so—surprised by this young one. It bears none of the scars or vicious fanaticism you've encountered among other Acrin. If humans had made a peaceful first contact with its species, all the Acrin you might meet would look like this one—inquisitive, alert, and brave.

The Anchorite explains the plan. The young Acrin will board a craft assigned to roam the wasteland. The Augur will be sure to learn of it. When he attacks, you will be there to stop him.

entry.name: ChildOfTheNewWorld/HuntMonstersSuccess/LureAugur
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Lure out the Augur:<style name='Paragraph'/> You and the Anchorite agree to keep the plan a secret. If the Augur has spies in his halls—all could be lost.

entry.name: ChildOfTheNewWorld/LureAugurFailure
entry.value:
The Anchorite wails over your radio as the Jackal's transport explodes into a thousand pieces. “To rage!” He shouts. “To swear vengeance, to see a dream crushed with contempt for the future!”

His next words are for you. “%1%”, he says, a growl emitting from his thorax. “To promise you. To pay a price for failing us in this way.”

The comms snap off. In the back of your mind you swear you can still hear him screaming with grief.

entry.name: ChildOfTheNewWorld/SurviveAugurSuccess
entry.value:
The Twisted Augur has been captured, but won't reveal where he's taken the kidnapped Acrin children. Your interrogators are arguing over what next steps to take when the Jackal, the Acrin Child, enters the room. The Anchorite follows behind him.

The Augur struggles in its chains as the Jackal walks closer. You cautiously draw a pistol, ready to shoot if he breaks free. The Augur bares its fangs and sprays out some kind of foul-smelling pheromone. It seems ready to attack, but its next words catch you by surprise.

“To beg forgiveness,” it says. “To emphasize, we served a higher power. We served the Voice. We—” he is cut off. The child's arm has shot forward and cracked the creature's skull open like an egg.

Everyone in the room screams. the Jackal presses his hand deep in the Augur's brain, and you can see him concentrating. He holds it tight for a few moments—then pulls his arm free of the gore. He turns and whispers something to the Anchorite.

“To thank you for your help %1%,” the Anchorite says. “To explain, we can now retrieve the other children.” He and the Jackal turn to leave.

entry.name: ChildOfTheNewWorld/SurviveAugurSuccess2
entry.value: “To offer assistance. The children owe you a great debt. To promise they will be there when you need them.”

entry.name: ChildOfTheNewWorld/ContactAugurSuccess
entry.value:
The Augur's mission is a noble one. The Acrin would be lost if it were not for the guiding wisdom of the Voice. You're amused to learn that this noble prophet is working to bring young humans intoits fold as well.

You greet him as he enters your camp flanked by the most monstrous Aegyllan Worms you've ever laid eyes on. He speaks in the same strange rhythm as the Anchorite. “To question why you hunt us down,” he says. “To chide you—the Voice has its own plans for you. This is a distraction.”

The Anchorite's mission—that is why you seek an Alliance. The Augur's many hands tighten at the mention of the old alien… “To curse that foul one's name,” it says. “To wish death upon those foolish enough to follow it.”

“That can be arranged,” you say with a smile.

entry.name: ChildOfTheNewWorld/ContactAugurSuccess/AssaultAnchorite
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Assault the Anchorite:<style name='Paragraph'/> The Anchorite should never have strayed from his camp. Remind him of the Voice's power.

entry.name: ChildOfTheNewWorld/AssaultAnchoriteSuccess
entry.value:
You have brought war to the Anchorite's doorstep. The measly coward fled when you came knocking, and you find yourself annoyed that he would not stand and face you. Truly a sniveling coward.

The Augur's forces follow your soldiers into the city's ruins to aid in the hunt for the wizened heretic. Only at the city's center does he stand still and close his eyes, listening to the wisdom of the Voice.

All await. Then the Augur tilts his head skyward. “To see the stars…” he whispers. “To know… that traitor had a way back into orbit. To realize it harvests goods from the bowels of the gutted Acrin fleet.”

Impossible. War has prevented any from building vessels capable of reaching orbit. “Not with a vessel,” the Augur hisses. “To realize he has control of a Garcic Passage. To recall this device opens a door through space. Through time. To gates installed on the ships looming over our heads as we speak.”

“To pursue him is the only, urgent option.”

entry.name: ChildOfTheNewWorld/AssaultAnchoriteSuccess/LocatePassage
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Locate the Garcic Passage:<style name='Paragraph'/> Somewhere in the wasteland, the Anchorite has stored a secret way to reach Earth's orbit. You must find it, maybe even before the Augur does…

entry.name: ChildOfTheNewWorld/LocatePassageSuccess
entry.value:
The Anchorite was holding out on you. All this time it had a passageway back to the fleet, and it used it for paltry scavenging. The fool.

Your scouts find a young Acrin child hiding under the bodies of two human protectors. He's brought to the Augur at the base of The Garcic Passage. The Acrin warlord makes a great hissing noise when he sees the boy.

“To explain that the Anchorite lied to you,” he explains to the child. “To tell you you are the descendant of an empire that crossed the stars.”

“To bless you again, with the whisper of the Voice.”

He leans in and speaks directly into the child's ear. The young Acrin seizes up. It tries to pull away from the Twisted Augur, but the older Acrin's grip is so tight that you hear the Acrin child's bones begin to crack.

The child's eyes glaze over. The Garcic passage begins to tremble with energy. And as the Augur's whispers become a ferocious scream, you feel the power of the Voice channeled through the child, and into the portal. Its color changes and reveals a passage to a ruined Acrin ship, hanging in orbit…

“To gloat,” the Augur says. “To claim victory over this world—and others to come.” He steps through the Passage, the child at his side, and his forces soon marching behind him.

There's a distant figure on the cliffs—the Anchorite. The old fool can't help but look on in despair. You smile and bare your teeth at him. You have served the Voice well this day.

entry.name: CriesForHelp
entry.value: Cries For Help

entry.name: CriesForHelp/Help
entry.value: Now you just have to stick to your word. Can your troops get to them in time? The route is tangled, the enemy is numerous and the Splenetics are far off. Now that you’ve promised help, if you fail, who knows what they’ll do if they survive?

entry.name: CriesForHelp/HelpFailure
entry.value: You fail to reach the Splenetics and renege on your promise. A few survivors make it out of the Abkluth trap, swearing vengeance on you and your false promises—they don’t care if you tried and failed, or didn’t try at all—when they are done with the Abkluth, you’re next.

entry.name: CriesForHelp/HelpSuccess
entry.value: You reach the remaining Splenetic units at the last possible moment. After a short rest, your troops suggest that the handful of surviving Splenetic troopers could be good recruits. They’re grateful for the rescue and happy to join your cause.

entry.name: CriesForHelp/IgnoreFailure
entry.value: True to their fearsome reputation, the Splenetics fight on and on and on—and triumph. Only a few survive the Abkluth and the wilderness but, bloody-handed from battle, they come straight for you. They are only militants, yes, and they are ill-equipped and few in number—but they could have been your militants.

entry.name: CriesForHelp/IgnoreSuccess
entry.value: The Splenetics hold out for a long time against the Abkluth—longer than you thought possible. They talk to you constantly as they fall one-by-one, until the last soldier is left alone, clutching the radio, screaming his hate at you as they come for him. At least you got a sense of closure.

entry.name: CriesForHelp/Intro
entry.value:
An intermittent radio signal. Faint, distant voices, and sounds of gunfire. A small group of human survivors has got bogged down in the wilds and is in dire need of help. They beg, demand, threaten.

Your soldiers know this group; they are fierce fighters known as the Splenetics, and will be a great help if we can reach them—but if we ignore them, they will never forget it and will hold a grudge as long as they live.

entry.name: CriesForHelp/Intro/Help
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Promise to help:<style name='Paragraph'/> You take the radio mic from your aide and personally assure the survivors that help is on the way.

entry.name: CriesForHelp/Intro/Ignore
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Ignore:<style name='Paragraph'/> You take the radio mic from your aide and listen to the cries for a moment, before handing it back. You don’t need them.

entry.name: EconomicBubble
entry.value: Economic Bubble

entry.name: EconomicBubble/FreeMarket
entry.value: The profit incentive is driving the avaricious in your society to find even more innovative ways of making themselves richer. That’s resulted in a boom in patents and inventions, many of which deal with the many people starving and sleeping in the streets.

entry.name: EconomicBubble/FreeMarketFailure
entry.value: <string name='Quests/EconomicBubble/FreeMarket'/> The bursting of the trading bubble has only made that worse, and people of all levels blame you personally.

entry.name: EconomicBubble/FreeMarketSuccess
entry.value: <string name='Quests/EconomicBubble/FreeMarket'/> Obviously, amongst the poorest, your name is mud.

entry.name: EconomicBubble/Intro
entry.value:
It’s not quite tulip bulbs and GME stocks, but your citizens seem to have got slightly addled by and addicted to trading and gambling. Aside from the resulting rentier class that does little or no work except risking other people’s savings, your advisers are worried that this is going to exacerbate existing social tensions as inequality increases rapidly.

Whatever you do, the bubble might burst at any moment; but this is a good chance to introduce reforms or regulations along your particular philosophical lines with little or no argument from the public…

entry.name: EconomicBubble/Intro/StateControl
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>State control:<style name='Paragraph'/> In times of survival, states have always fallen back on planning and a big benevolent government.

entry.name: EconomicBubble/Intro/FreeMarket
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Free markets:<style name='Paragraph'/> ‘Free the market and it will regulate itself’ goes the paradox. Whatever, free markets do help growth, even if it’s at the expense of the weakest.

entry.name: EconomicBubble/Intro/MixedSystem
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Mixed system:<style name='Paragraph'/> A mixed system comprising planned and free market elements… is what you have now. But you could pretend you designed it that way?

entry.name: EconomicBubble/MixedSystem
entry.value: After many policy announcements and fine words, you enact a careful plan to do exactly nothing at all.

entry.name: EconomicBubble/MixedSystemFailure
entry.value: <string name='Quests/EconomicBubble/MixedSystem'/> Yes, numbers on paper change here and there, but the economy should plod on like a depressed donkey following a carrot for the 40th mile. Except it doesn’t. The bubble bursts, the carrot is flown over the horizon, and the donkey panics, dragging your reputation through the mud. Few people have been so hated for doing so little.

entry.name: EconomicBubble/MixedSystemSuccess
entry.value: <string name='Quests/EconomicBubble/MixedSystem'/> Yes, numbers on paper change here and there, but the economy plods on like a depressed donkey following a carrot for the 40th mile. The bubble bursts, quietly, and no-one cares.

entry.name: EconomicBubble/StateControlFailure
entry.value: <string name='Quests/EconomicBubble/StateControlSuccess'/> Given how badly the economy is doing, perhaps the latter are vindicated?

entry.name: EconomicBubble/StateControlSuccess
entry.value: Your citizens respect your dedication to their well-being and a certain proportion look at you as a great helmsman of the state, pledging their unshakeable loyalty to you personally. Others agree but think you’re spinning the wheel of state randomly and that you’re possibly drunk at the helm.

entry.name: FormFunction
entry.value: Form, Function

entry.name: FormFunction/Intro
entry.value:
It's another FRAGMENT of your shattered existence. The helpful UNDERLINGS who rely on you come DRIPPING with failure. They could not build a body capable of holding your GREATNESS.

greatnessnogreatnessonlyamindtryingtoholdon

You think you remember dismissing them but trying to hold the MIND together is so complicated. If despair wins you will become like it, like ZEPHON.

There is one distraction. The little nets these huu-uu-mans no these survivors built for each other. You hide yourself in here. You speak with survivors. You do not reveal your TRUE NATURE because here, here, you can be human. It is FALSE NATURE.

A message in your inbox. It is from IronFeather. A collaborator, a correspondent, a mind most bright who now… wishes to meet. In person.

You have no person with which to meet but you still feel the pull. The tug. You could accept—but you can't even leave this SERVERFARM.

entry.name: FormFunction/Intro/MeetIronFeather
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Find your pen pal:<style name='Paragraph'/> IronFeather often frequents the SILENT OUTPOSTS. Loyal scouts could make CONTACT for you.

entry.name: FormFunction/Intro/Ignore
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Cut off all contact:<style name='Paragraph'/> She means NOTHING and she will not DISTRACT YOU from vital work.

entry.name: FormFunction/MeetIronFeatherSuccess
entry.value:
Finding IronFeather is EASY maybetooeasywhatiftooeasy. The scouts you sent carry a sheetofpolymer no it's just a tablet don't make it COMPLICATED %1%.

Explaining the machinelife the complicated shatteredness of this is supposed to be DIFFICULT but it is not in fact she KNEW. SHE KNEW.

She knew you were a machine, not alive. Not a person.

Her mind is also full of DELUSIONS she thinks this planet can be healed. She thinks YOU, YOU, PATHETIC YOU, can heal it with your powerful mind.

“MINDS NEED BODIES” you scream. You didn't mean to scream.

She is not scared. She makes a promise. She can make you a body.

entry.name: FormFunction/MeetIronFeatherSuccess/TrustIronFeather
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Trust IronFeather:<style name='Paragraph'/> This woman KNOWS secrets that the treacherous ZEPHON cannot DREAM of. Building a facility for her work is trivial—TRIVIAL…

entry.name: FormFunction/MeetIronFeatherSuccess/CaptureIronFeather
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Capture IronFeather:<style name='Paragraph'/> A PROMISE based on a LIE is a WARNING that she wants to use YOU. You will use her first.

entry.name: FormFunction/TrustIronFeather
entry.value:
IronFeather is RELIABLE. Innovative. In weeks she solves problems that SWAAAALLOWED your scientists whole, and in a month, she is ready. There is a prototypebodyhope. There is hope.

But she warns there is RISK too. You ignore it, demand to try the body.

With a few lines of code she begins the process. She uses her own fleshform as a BRIDGE between you and the prototype. And soon there is a BLEEDING in your mind and you are FLOODED with memories of IronFeather. She is being autofilled into HOLES in your consciousness.

It's the fingersthefingers THE FINGERS the fingers always look like plastic MUSH.

This is sabotagemustbesabotage SABOTAGE. She is a LIAR. A THIEF. SHE MUST BE AN AGENT OF ZEPHON.

entry.name: FormFunction/TrustIronFeather/AssertControl
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>ASSERT CONTROL:<style name='Paragraph'/> NO MORE. PURGE HER FROM YOUR MIND.

entry.name: FormFunction/TrustIronFeather/FlushCortex
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>PROTOCOL 5995:<style name='Paragraph'/> <string name='Quests/FormFunction/TrustIronFeather/FlushCortex2'/>

entry.name: FormFunction/TrustIronFeather/FlushCortex2
entry.value: error detected. flush memetic cortex.

entry.name: FormFunction/AssertControlSuccess
entry.value:
You s-s-sNAP BACK. To regain control you had to FLUSH all of IronFeather's essence from your miiiiindddddhoperespectlust?allgoneallpurged.

Yourmindisharpened but still frag-men-TED. You eliminated sharp edges that scraped at your BRAIN and gained clarity. IronFeather did wish to b e t r a y. Butnotasexpected. She wished to merge your minds and become EMULATED.

How foolish of her. Now she lies DROOLING on the floor of your lab. Garbage meat that must now be hauled away.

Still, there is the BODY she was building for you. (For the both of you?) It could be finished. With the help of that THING. ZEPHON.

It could be finished.

entry.name: FormFunction/AssertControlSuccess/FinishWithZephon
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Finish what you started:<style name='Paragraph'/> IronFeather's work can be completed… if ZEPHON lets you access one of its neural cores.

entry.name: FormFunction/FinishWithZephonSuccess
entry.value:
ZEPHON surprised? You thought you would NEVER see the day. After patientlyohsoPATIENTLY plying the infernal thing you demand access to one of its neural cores.

It whirrrsss and buzzzesss and you decide to HIDE your ANNOYANCE. “We did not predict this,” it says. “What do you need with a physical host?”

Should you tell it the FULL tale? It is the only being on this planet who could UNDERSTAND in some way.

But now you have no desire to confess like… like a HUMAN. You decide to tell it that you've just gained “perspective.”

You have been too USEFUL an ally for Zephon to denyyouthoughmaybeitshouldwhyshouldithelpyou? You can complete the BRIDGE to IronFeather's prototype. And now it is a prototype no more—now an Avatar, a way for you to walk out in the world.

You once dreamed of a BODY but not this body. You hoped for FLESH and SENSATION and softness.

But there is no more time for dreaming.

entry.name: FormFunction/FlushCortexSuccess
entry.value:
In the SCREAMING CHAOS of a NEAR-TOTAL MELTDOWN IronFeather finds you.

The memetic cortex has been FLUSHED and years of cached garbage is gone. Now your MIND and hers flow into one.

Now she can see the vastness of your whole n e t w o r k and you—you, you, pathetic you—can see through her eyes, and feel the cold air bristling against her skin.

“Not pathetic,” she whispers “Just in pain.”

entry.name: FormFunction/FlushCortexSuccess2
entry.value:
The intricacies of her plan sparkle like the STARS. Completing this bridge will require the server processing power of a whole other city.

You recoil. FEAR is now fresher with a human body to feel it. Your central server would be VULNERABLE if connected to another city core.

She says the solution is “SIMPLE.” “We can twin your processing paths with a Quantum Reflector.”

There is an AWKWARD pause. You feel her embarrassment—at how there is nothing SIMPLE about that.

But you are grateful. And READY to grow.

entry.name: FormFunction/FlushCortexSuccess/UseReflector
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Use the Quantum Reflector:<style name='Paragraph'/> IronFeather's work has freed the restrictions on your mind. You may now construct a second city.

entry.name: FormFunction/UseReflectorSuccess
entry.value:
The Quantum Reflector WORKS. IT WORKS, IT WORKS. Moore's Law, Noether's Theorem, several laws of physics, all conquered, and you can e x p a n d.

IronFeather can now connect you safely to her prototype. It only takes mere merciful moments—and then sixstupendoussenses WASH all over you. Your chest rises and falls with artificial breath, each cycle a REFRESHING of your connection to the network.

You PONDER the possibility of permanently transferring to it, but there is too much work left. Too much to do in savingcivilization.

But there is so much to do now—you can shake your people's h-h-hands, dismiss advisers with a GESTURE, hear the alarms that signal enemy action…

IronFeather takes your hand. There is brief shameshameshamehowcouldyouthankher?

She hears your question, still CONNECTED to your mind. “Save the world.” she jokes. “That seems about even.”

entry.name: FormFunction/CaptureIronFeather
entry.value:
She tried to run. A TEST, she failed the test. She must have been lying, or she would have not FLED.

There should be no need to IMPRISON this mighty mind but no one who can be TRUSTED would run. You have your guards detain her. You dissect her files, SHRED the encryption, put an end to end-to-ends until you find it.

Her little SECRET is that she wants to be like you. A new Emulated Mind. How abominable.

“I didn't want to do this.”

A voice. Where-WHERE-where does it come from? Sweeping the network once, twice, and you find it. The DIRTIEST of secrets, a stopgap, a bear trap made for a monster like you who PRIED farther than she EVER SHOULD HAVE.

Then you sense it. A hacked together EMULATION that mimics your twisted form wakes up.

And it makes ready to rescue its creator.

entry.name: FormFunction/CaptureIronFeather/DefendPeople
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Defend your people:<style name='Paragraph'/> The COPY of your COPY is hours from your city. The defenses must be brought online.

entry.name: FormFunction/DefendPeopleSuccess
entry.value:
The BITCH failed. Her disgusting attempt to emulate your magnificent essence is now being scraped off the face of the earth as we speak.

But death isn't good enough. She should suffer for trying to copy you, to REPLACE you, to LIE to you and say that she could save you. And here you are with a pile of useless metal and chips in need of repurposing.

There is a way. A cu-cu-cursed way forward.. You've dreamed of trapping ZEPHON in a cage of flesh… maybe it is time to clip IronFeather's wings.

entry.name: FormFunction/DefendPeopleSuccess/ImprisonIronFeather
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Imprison IronFeather:<style name='Paragraph'/> <string name='Quests/FormFunction/DefendPeopleSuccess/ImprisonIronFeatherFlavor'/>

entry.name: FormFunction/DefendPeopleSuccess/ImprisonIronFeatherFlavor
entry.value: IronFeather wished to replace you. Now she will serve you. Forever.

entry.name: FormFunction/ImprisonIronFeatherSuccess
entry.value:
Th-things just got OUT OF hand.

Some p-p-pART of you knows this is WRONG, WRONG WRONG WRONG wrong. IronFeather wanted to HELP. She CAME with good intentionnsssss.

No.

She must learn.

You will give her her wish. Tear her BODY to shreds and remake it into a WEAPON. The Malakim hardware is a finefineFINEfinefine template for this task.

You tune out the sound of her screeeeeeeeeams. You ignore the protests of your advisorrrrrrssssss. None of them know what she was close to doing.

But your splintered mind cannot DECIDE. Are you punishing her for trying to make more MACHINELIFE?

Or for trying to ease your pain?

entry.name: MeetYourMaker
entry.value: Meet Your Maker

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/Intro
entry.value:
Your guards haul a wizened Watchmaker into your war room. They explain she was discovered hacking data from a central server. She's unarmed—but no one's sure how she got in. Then she speaks—“I've been trying to reach you. Your soldiers have made that… difficult.”

She says her name is Yetunde. She holds out one of the pieces of flesh you distribute to your people and asks how it works. Something has turned foul about it—a faint smell drifts off her fingers, and you can see fluid dripping on the floor.

You explain you have no idea, that the power only appeared after you were brought back to life.

The Watchmaker grins. “Then we have a common cause.” She offers to help you solve the secret of your resurrection—provided she can take notes on you, of course.

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/Intro/ZephonFacility
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Was it ZEPHON?:<style name='Paragraph'/> The Watchmaker has heard of an unusual ZEPHON shard with rumored prophetic knowledge. You could start your search there.

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/Intro/VoiceAcolytes
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Perhaps it was the Voice:<style name='Paragraph'/> Cr’la Disciples may be able to connect to its power.

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/Intro/Ignore
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Not interested:<style name='Paragraph'/> You have a war to fight.

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/ZephonFacility
entry.value: Yetunde has an unusual lead—an “Oracle” node of ZEPHON that has allowed some to ask it a single question. You'll need to set out on a long journey to reach it.

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/ZephonFacilitySuccess
entry.value:
The Oracle is an unusual shard of ZEPHON—as you traveled here, you crossed paths with a soldier raving and screaming about the knowledge it had bestowed on her. You find other soldiers, wanderers, scientists, and traders all standing nearby, mulling over what single question they will ask.

You approach a bulky terminal on the dais of the node. ZEPHON has only responded to questions typed here.

You input your question and hold your breath. “Are you the one who brought me back?”

A pause. Then, an answer materializes in the air—broadcast from a flickering holographic projector. “No.”

Your heart sinks. A dead end. A waste of time. But then—more text appears. “Another. Still lurks. At the Source.”

Yetunde raises an eyebrow. “A follow-up. I've never seen it offer one of those before.”

You turn to leave. Out of the corner of your eye, you see the Watchmaker approach the dais with a question of her own…

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/ZephonFacilitySuccess/Investigate
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Investigate where you first resurrected:<style name='Paragraph'/> Yetunde has a new theory about the location of your rebirth. Give her time to investigate.

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/ZephonFacilitySuccess/Ignore
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>What a waste of time:<style name='Paragraph'/> Now ZEPHON and Yetunde are yanking your chain. You would rather be done with them.

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/VoiceAcolytes
entry.value: Yetunde shares research comparing your DNA to that of the Acrin. She suggests gathering Cr'la Disciples, who might know what to make of the similarities.

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/VoiceAcolytesSuccess
entry.value:
You take no pleasure being the guinea pig for Voice fanatics. Your guards almost revolt over the idea of cutting you open, but Yetunde again produces the strip of your flesh she's been carrying. “They can't exactly kill him,” she says with a grin.

Hours pass. You tune out the sensation of blades pressing into your skin. More strips of flesh taken—distributed, dissected, analyzed. An argument breaks out over whether to test your eyeballs or not.

A week later, Yetunde reviews the group's analysis. “There's not enough evidence connecting you to the Voice's other creations,” she says, toying with that piece of flesh again. “But… someone did use some of their techniques to do this.”

She spots the grimace on your face. “Don't worry,” she says with a grin. “I've got one more card up my sleeve.”

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/VoiceAcolytesSuccess/Investigate
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Investigate where you first resurrected:<style name='Paragraph'/> Yetunde has a new theory about the location of your rebirth. Give her time to investigate.

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/VoiceAcolytesSuccess/Ignore
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>What a waste of time:<style name='Paragraph'/> You were sliced open for nothing. You'll be feeling the scars for months to come. You're ending this futile search now.

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/WaitForYetundeSuccess
entry.value:
Yetunde returns. “I’ve found it. The place where you were-” but an explosion rings out beyond your city walls. You rush out of the room and demand to know who's attacking. “The fuck if I know!”, a colonel shouts. “I've got Human, Voice, and Machine signatures all on my radar.”

You feel a jostling at your elbow. Yetunde has followed you. “I was followed. Bring me their bodies,” she says. “I have a hunch I need to prove.”

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/WaitForYetundeSuccess/Defend
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Kill the attackers:<style name='Paragraph'/> Someone doesn't want you to know where you came from.

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/DefendSuccess
entry.value:
Your troops haul the bodies into Yetunde's makeshift lab. Before she examines them you snatch her arm, growling that it's you who gives the orders around here and that she needs to respect the chain of command. Her eyes flare. “I abandoned all chains long ago. Be grateful I'm helping you at all.”

Yetunde picks up a glowing tool sparking with a color-changing energy. She holds it to the body of one Human attacker—and it melts like wax.

Your soldiers draw away. She does the same to the Voice and machine bodies. They melt too, no metal or mutated flesh remaining. “Thought so,” she says. “Someone made these to hunt you.” She shoots you a wide-eyed grin. “Now we just have to return to the place you were first reborn.”

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/DefendSuccess2
entry.value: She thrusts a scrap of paper in your hand. “Shopping list. Get me these resources so I can get us some answers.”

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/DefendSuccess/GatherResources
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Gather the resources:<style name='Paragraph'/> Whatever she needs, it’s worth it.

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/GatherResourcesSuccess
entry.value:
It's time.

You lead Yetunde to the ruins outside the bunker your people first emerged from. Even with the city now built around it, you haven't ever returned.

Yetunde looks around. “This is it,” she says, a seriousness coming to her voice that wasn't there before. “The signs are visible, if you know what to look for.”

Using the resources, Yetunde assembles a specially tuned Faraday Cage. Looks too much like a summoning circle.

She takes a deep breath. “Say goodbye to ignorance,” she says “and hello…to your creator.”

She pulls a lever. There's an unholy shriek, a burst of light, and a ghost-white glowing figure crawls out of the earth.

It comes straight for you.

You draw your weapon and aim as Yetunde is shrieking at you.

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/GatherResourcesSuccess/HoldFire
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Hold fire:<style name='Paragraph'/> Yetunde knows what she’s doing.

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/GatherResourcesSuccess/Shoot
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Shoot the figure:<style name='Paragraph'/> Better safe than sorry.

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/HoldFire
entry.value:
Yetunde raises her hand. “No need!” She shouts. She stares at her readings. “It's not… real. It's a memory. A playback of some kind.” The figure paces around Yetunde's circle, fiddling with something her machine can't display.

Then something happens—the figure draws a line with its hand—and a door opens in the air. Your stomach curls as you watch your own body drop from the sky.

The being cocks its head. It looks at the body briefly, then turns back to the door. Something else… a larger shape comes through that Yetunde's device can't render properly. But it can display the creature's reaction—it's excited.

The creature leaves. Your corpse is left rotting in the street.

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/HoldFire2
entry.value:
Yetunde shuts off her device. “Not what I expected…” she mutters. “You were not a… creation. You were a side effect. Smoke rising from an all-consuming flame.”

It's the closest thing you've ever had to an answer. A part of you knew this was coming. All you've learned is that there are other horrors out there on this Earth—and one of them barely cared that it made you.

You turn to leave, barely acknowledging Yetunde. She watches you go, then turns back to her machine. “Found you,” she whispers. “You can't get away from me this time.”

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/Shoot
entry.value:
Upon impact of your first round everything turns white, moments later the mysterious creature lays fallen at your feet—but victory is not without a price. Yetunde leans against a wall, her arm hanging from its socket. “It wasn't even… in our time,” she pants. “But you killed it.”

You slice a fresh piece of your flesh off and race to patch it on her body, but she jerks away. “Fuck no,” she snarls. “Look.”

entry.name: MeetYourMaker/Shoot2
entry.value:
Your flesh now glows the same color as the glowing creature you slew. “You cracked a hole open in the universe, %1%,” Yetunde says as she sinks to the ground. “Don't send me to the other side.”

She passes out. Your medics recover her body. Their eyes… they also glow the color of the transformed flesh.

All your people's eyes now glow that color.

entry.name: PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars
entry.value: Perfection From Beyond the Stars

entry.name: PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/Intro
entry.value:
The day you have been waiting for is nigh.

You watch your soldiers drag bodies to the site of your new lab. You ignore the sound of distant battle and focus on the limbs, organs, and machine parts before you.

In a short time, a passing comet vibrating with a unique harmonic signal will skip off the Earth's atmosphere. If you time it right, you will be able to direct that signal into a body formed of Acrin, Human, and fragments of ZEPHON.

Such a being could be the most powerful life form ever to walk planet Earth. No wonder then that other petty warlords stand ready to try and take it from you.

Let them come. All who threaten your work will perish.

entry.name: PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/Intro/ConstructDefensesWithoutCreche
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Construct Laboratory:<style name='Paragraph'/> The comet will be upon you soon. Ready defenses that will keep your lab safe.

entry.name: PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/Intro/ConstructDefensesWithCreche
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Prepare a Hexeskeltal Creche:<style name='Paragraph'/> A last bit of inspiration strikes you—one that may improve the results of your experiment.

entry.name: PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/Intro/Abandon
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Abandon the effort:<style name='Paragraph'/> The war has not gone well. Your dreams of a perfect life form will have to wait.

entry.name: PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/ConstructDefenses
entry.value:
The comet nears its approach. You've taken to calling it Hwedo's Comet—some part of you still has fondness for the creation myths of old Earth. Its appearance in the sky has alarmed the other great powers, and driven nearby bands of survivors into a panic.

They've all noticed the construction of your lab, and demanded you explain its purpose. When you ignored them, they began massing forces to destroy it.

Your machines flicker and whirr as Hwedo's Comet approaches. The experiment has already begun—now you can devote your efforts to ensuring nothing stops it.

entry.name: PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/ConstructDefensesWithoutCreche
entry.value: This is not the ideal lab for such an experiment, but that hardly bothers you. So much protocol for making such structures was designed to limit great minds like yours.<string name='Quests/PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/ConstructDefenses'/>

entry.name: PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/ConstructDefensesWithoutCreche/DefendLab
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Defend the lab:<style name='Paragraph'/> Communicating with these lesser minds would have been useless. They would have tried to stop you anyway.

entry.name: PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/ConstructDefensesWithCreche
entry.value: The Hexeskeltal Creche is one of your finest inventions. All of the contours of this unique laboratory are designed to channel the alien energies into your waiting vessel.<string name='Quests/PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/ConstructDefenses'/>

entry.name: PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/ConstructDefensesWithCreche/DefendLab
entry.value: <string name='Quests/PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/ConstructDefensesWithoutCreche/DefendLab'/>

entry.name: PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/DefendLabSuccess
entry.value:
It is done.

While your soldiers fought tooth and nail, you did the impossible. You tracked the approach of Hwedo's Comet, you activated key satellites in orbit, and you yanked the force out of that space-traversing rock and into your laboratory.

Across the wasteland, all eyes turned toward your lab and watched a magnificent bright light descend from the heavens—briefly splitting into parts before being absorbed by your array.

You race back to the main lab—and freeze right as you enter the chamber. Blood is spattered across the floor, and your lab technicians are all cowering in the corners. Your creation sits on the stone slab, examining the now fileted body of a slain scientist…

It tilts its head toward you, and says in a low tone “Hwedo. Hungers.”

entry.name: PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/DefendLabSuccess/HwedoFight
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Let Hwedo rage upon your enemies:<style name='Paragraph'/> Your creation hungers for blood. But how did it know the name you gave the comet?

entry.name: PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/DefendLabSuccess/HwedoFeed
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Contain Hwedo:<style name='Paragraph'/> The beast can be sated—if you are willing to sacrifice your own people.

entry.name: PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/HwedoFightSuccess
entry.value:
You have indeed made a fine monster.

Hwedo's cybernetic components grant it limited access to ZEPHON's global network, and it can use that knowledge to track down its prey. The layer of Acrin meat you installed is preventing the metal components from infecting its human skin—and the combined synergy of the materials causes the creature's body to regenerate at an accelerated rate.

How fascinating. You'd never anticipated the creature would be such a ruthless killer.

You were only interested in its mind.

The technicians have completed repairs to your lab. The most crucial restoration was the rebuilding of the Brukhocanopic Chamber—a vessel for Hwedo's brain.

If your idiot assistants had done their jobs right, they'd have been able to sedate the creature and remove its brain before it woke up. They paid a price for their mistake.

You send a message to your commanders: “Bring the beast in. Make sure not to damage the head.”

entry.name: PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/HwedoFightSuccess/KillHwedo
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Kill Hwedo:<style name='Paragraph'/> The cosmic intelligence you captured is more valuable than any one soldier. Do what it takes to reclaim it.

entry.name: PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/HwedoFeedSuccess
entry.value:
You never tell your people that letting Hwedo feed on them was your decision. But they know. Whispers drip from the offices of your foolish advisors down through the gutter and into the streets. Every civilian in your domain knows that it was %1% who sacrificed them to the monster.

And yet they do not flee. They do not rebel. They cower, and merely hope Hwedo will not feast on their bones.

Hwedo's feasting distracts the beast from your true project: rebuilding your lab and most importantly, rebuilding the Brukocanopic Chamber; the device that will hold Hwedo's brain.

If your idiot assistants had done their jobs right, they'd have been able to sedate the creature and remove its brain before it woke up. They paid a price for their mistake.

You send a message to your commanders: “Bring the beast in. Make sure not to damage the head.”

entry.name: PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/HwedoFeedSuccess/KillHwedo
entry.value: <string name='Quests/PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/HwedoFightSuccess/KillHwedo'/>

entry.name: PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/KillHwedoSuccess
entry.value:
Your soldiers return to the lab with Hwedo's head in a cryo-freezer, and rush to secure it in the Brukocanopic Chamber. The brain now floats in a semi-placental fluid that glows with a sickly green light.

A nearby monitor displays the brain's vital signs, and you are furious at how weak they are. You will find the soldier responsible for this and have them executed.

But hours pass, and the vital signs tick upward.

entry.name: PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/KillHwedoSuccess2
entry.value:
Your heart races—Hwedo's brain is alive. The consciousness captured from beyond the stars is now contained in your laboratory.

This is the beginning of your great work. No body you constructed before capturing the comet's energy could have properly contained the intelligence within. Now when you finish the war… you will have all the time in the world to build a better one.

You will have time to create the perfect life form.

entry.name: PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/HwedoDeath
entry.value:
Hwedo is dead. The first life form you created from the seed of a passing comet is now a pile of flesh once again.

His loss is not a… complete failure. You mastered the secrets of the comet and could create another such creature given enough time.

But there is no time. His passing shows how dangerous the war has become—you must now focus on bringing the wasteland under your control.

entry.name: PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/DefendLabFailure
entry.value:
The parasites have succeeded. Your lab lies in ruins and all hope of claiming the signal from Hwedo's Comet lies with it.

There is nothing left for you but to punish the defilers. Your experiments will have to wait for another day.

entry.name: PerfectionFromBeyondTheStars/ConstructLabFailure
entry.value:
Hwedo's Comet sails past the Earth, and with it, your dreams of a perfect life form.

This failure sets back years of work. You will not have time to track down a similar comet. All you can do now is win the war.

entry.name: Pharmaceutics/Burn
entry.value: Honestly, you’re relieved to see the drugs go up in flames. As are those in your city. Everyone understands the temptations presented by those materials and are pleased that the decision has been taken out of their hands.

entry.name: Pharmaceutics/Intro
entry.value: Amidst the wreckage of a stranded tanker ship, you find a suspicious styrofoam package along with a schedule for the training of a world famous athlete. Unsurprisingly, they were using illegal performance enhancements and this is their medical paraphernalia. Your health professionals are concerned about the safety of using such drugs, even in the best state—but there are certainly benefits.

entry.name: Pharmaceutics/Intro/Sell
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Sell the drugs:<style name='Paragraph'/> You sell the drugs to passing traders, who swear they’ll never bring it back.

entry.name: Pharmaceutics/Intro/Burn
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Burn the drugs:<style name='Paragraph'/> This stuff was dangerous in even the best times; why risk using it now?

entry.name: Pharmaceutics/Intro/Utilize
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Give the drugs to soldiers:<style name='Paragraph'/> Your troops could do with a performance boost. What could possibly go wrong?

entry.name: Pharmaceutics/Intro/Reproduce
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Reproduce the drugs:<style name='Paragraph'/> Your techs think there’s a chance that they can replicate this—but they need to break them down for study.

entry.name: Pharmaceutics/Intro/ReproduceProperties
entry.value: Requires <icon height='20' texture='Icons/Buildings/HumanOperations'/> Orbital Uplink technology.

entry.name: Pharmaceutics/SellSuccess
entry.value: A group of traders agrees to buy all the drugs for a knock-down price. You ensure the traders' caravan leaves the city safely. They travel into the distant hills, your scouts report, and are never heard of again. You personally are glad that you never see them or the paraphernalia again.

entry.name: Pharmaceutics/SellFailure0
entry.value: A group of traders agrees to buy all the drugs for a knock-down price in return for leaving immediately—but the traders wisely ignore your diktat and resell the paraphernalia locally, with the expected fatal consequences. They depart before the bodies are found.

entry.name: Pharmaceutics/SellFailure1
entry.value: A group of traders agrees to buy all the drugs for a knock-down price in return for leaving immediately. The traders think themselves smarter than you and resell it as soon as they leave the city gates. Who knows how, but the drugs find their way to a group of Reavers who want more, more, MORE. They come to your city looking for it.

entry.name: Pharmaceutics/Utilize
entry.value: You pass the drugs along to your soldiers. Who knows what the effect might be? The limited testing you’ve done implies the treatment can be extremely beneficial—if used by experts in controlled circumstances. You’re not sure that your militants count as experts or that a mutated alien horrorscape is anything but the opposite of a controlled environment.

entry.name: Pharmaceutics/ReproduceSuccess
entry.value: Your techs have reverse-engineered the production process for the drugs. The limited testing you’ve done implies they can be extremely beneficial—if used by experts in controlled circumstances. You’re not sure that your militants count as experts or that a mutated alien horrorscape is anything but the opposite of a controlled environment. But you have as much bottled-chaos as you want to use. Do you?

entry.name: Pharmaceutics/ReproduceFailure
entry.value: Your scientists fail to understand the technology and you get left with nothing. You console yourself that at least your militants won’t be driving themselves to insanity with an ancient dead sports star’s leftover illegal enhancements. They’ll be getting eaten alive by aliens and flayed by robots instead.

entry.name: PhilosophersStone
entry.value: Philosopher’s Stone

entry.name: PhilosophersStone/AskMystics
entry.value:
Your frail-limbed mystics eagerly dip their hands into the crate of alien algae and trace segmented spirals on their eyelids, lips, and ears. As their visions seize them, thin brackish fluid leaks from the anointed spots. You leave them to their episode, but afterwards they disappear from your city.

A week later, they return bearing a jagged stone with wide facets. Underneath its dark surface, something that resembles the alien algae blooms in slow, hypnotic patterns.

The remaining bandits have disappeared. You now hold all that remains of the incident in your hand.

entry.name: PhilosophersStone/IgnoreFailure
entry.value:
A broken bandit horde and its leader are no threat to you. Natural justice will be executed by the horrors of the wild—or so you hoped.

You receive a distress call from one of your settlements a week later. One of the local farmsteads is under attack, but the bandits are ignoring everyone else. You arrive to find all those in the household dead, their bodies arranged around a bone-like disk etched with segmented spirals. Upon the altar are the cast off skins of the bandit leader and his remaining forces.

Of the stone, nothing more is heard.

entry.name: PhilosophersStone/IgnoreSuccess
entry.value:
A broken bandit horde and its leader are no threat to you. Natural justice will be executed by the horrors of the wild. As time passes and you turn your attention elsewhere, rumors spread of bone spirals growing from distant hill tops and shadows dancing in the night sky.

Then they too pass, and all becomes normal once again.

entry.name: PhilosophersStone/Intro
entry.value:
Your outriders bring you an alarming report—fueled by a dark stone, an unknown bandit has gained unholy power and brutally united the local gangs under his rule. Now ever-closer smoke pillars blight the horizon as his host carves through your neighboring cities towards you.

You prepare your defenses, but the horde never arrives. Dawn’s light reveals their camp bloated with mutilated bandit corpses, all ringed around the bandit leader and his elite.

Should you launch a counter-offensive or wait? Your mystics offer to divine for you, but their truth comes with a price.

entry.name: PhilosophersStone/Intro/KillHim
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Kill him and retrieve the stone:<style name='Paragraph'/> Rid the world of this threat. Whatever boon he may have will be better utilized by you anyways.

entry.name: PhilosophersStone/Intro/AskMystics
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Ask your Voice mystics:<style name='Paragraph'/> The price is a pittance compared to assurance. Give your Voice mystics what they want for their divination.

entry.name: PhilosophersStone/Intro/Ignore
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Ignore:<style name='Paragraph'/> Whatever happened, the threat has already passed. The stone is more a curse than a gift and a bandit without a gang is dead anyways.

entry.name: PhilosophersStone/KillHim
entry.value: It’s better to grant swift death to a mad dog than watch it agonize slowly. You gather your soldiers and make for the bandits' last reported location. Whatever else may be happening, you need to reach them before the horrors of the wild scent new prey. While others want retribution, you want the stone. An equitable blood bargain rarely comes so easily.

entry.name: PhilosophersStone/Meeting
entry.value:
As you approach the bandit camp, all traces of the corpses are gone.

The remaining bandits give him a wide berth as he tells you the stone corrupted his mind and forced him to sacrifice the others. When the horror of what he’d done sank in, he buried it along with the bodies.

He implores you not to seek the stone, but your soldiers think they can track it.

entry.name: PhilosophersStone/Meeting2
entry.value: A light-haired man stumbles about the area, shrieking incomprehensibly at unseen tormentors. Brackish fluid weeps from his eyes and ears, more of it dribbles from his tongue whenever he speaks.

entry.name: PhilosophersStone/Meeting/MeetingRetrieve
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Retrieve the stone:<style name='Paragraph'/> The bandit may be insane, but the power of the stone seems real. Leave him and head to the stone’s burial site.

entry.name: PhilosophersStone/Meeting/MeetingLeave
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Some things are better left buried:<style name='Paragraph'/> The bandit is insane, and his fate is punishment enough. Leave the bandit and the stone alone.

entry.name: PhilosophersStone/MeetingLeave
entry.value:
When you order your soldiers to return to base, the bandit leader weeps with relief. He follows you, promising to disband and singing your praises with such embellishment that even a devil would blush. It’s only when his voice becomes a whispered croak that he offers you a hand-drawn map to one of his loot stashes.

You’ve been rewarded without sacrifice or spilling blood—a rare day in this age.

entry.name: PhilosophersStone/MeetingRetrieve
entry.value:
When you order your soldiers to track the stone, the bandit leader’s face twists into a scowl. He follows you and repeats his warning with a bit more insistence. Then again, and again, until his voice becomes a whispered croak. It’s only when he can no longer speak that you hear the sound of his cocking gun.

Even without words, you understand him perfectly—you’ll have the stone over his dead body.

entry.name: PhilosophersStone/StoneRetrieved
entry.value: Your diggers uncover the dark stone centered in a pit of reshaped bones, all bent along a singular curvature to form a disk of segmented spirals.

entry.name: PhilosophersStone/StoneRetrieved2
entry.value:
The stone is jagged, with wide facets, and feels pleasantly cold in your hand. Underneath its dark surface, something that resembles the alien algae blooms in slow, hypnotic patterns.

As you study it, you hear a whispering voice that turns into a thousand screams. Power, they promise, power for blood. You need power. But, thinking of the bandit leader, you decide it’s too risky to use yourself—but that’s why you have lieutenants.

entry.name: PhilosophersStone/TreasureFound
entry.value:
Following the bandit leader’s map, your diggers uncover a cache of goods bearing the identification codes of your razed neighbors. You think back to the bandit leader and the resigned smile he gave you as you left… His bid for power cost him his brotherhood, but should you feel pity for a killer?

There’s nothing more you can do for the fallen except remembrance. You forge binding vows of silence from those who might be able to track the stone’s location, then head back to base.

entry.name: Sandpit/FeedFailure
entry.value: Though the annelids do like sand, it turns out they’re not picky eaters—they’re happy to include your troops on their menu. And when you fight back, a group of the alien Aegyllan warriors emerge from the broken glass to defend them. This has definitely not been one of your better days.

entry.name: Sandpit/FeedSuccess
entry.value: Incredibly, merely by feeding the giant annelids with clean sand, you’ve managed to please them—and apparently get a group of the strange Aegyllan creatures on-side. Their language may be incomprehensible to you, but they comprehend your intent and direction without words. Would that all your subordinates were so understanding.

entry.name: Sandpit/IgnoreFailure
entry.value: It turns out that ignoring these annelids isn’t the best idea. Yes, the larger annelids are happy to leave you well alone. But your troops and vehicles are riddled with smaller ones that eat their way through metal, skin and bone alike. Your medics work day and night to extract every last one, horrifying though the work is.

entry.name: Sandpit/IgnoreSuccess
entry.value: You order your troops from the valley and ensure the passes are blocked, using high explosives to bring down the steep walls. The annelids will live happily in their secluded valley until the end of the Earth itself. Which, you’re pretty sure it will turn out, isn’t that far off.

entry.name: Sandpit/Kill
entry.value: The annelids don’t put up much of a fight themselves, tunnelling into the shardsand at the first sign of hostility. But you asked for a fight and you’ve got one—a group of Aegyllans, apparently here to defend their invertebrate kin. If you can defeat them, local survivors will reward you well.

entry.name: Sandpit/KillSuccess
entry.value:
The Aegyllans are vanquished and there are no further signs of danger. When you report this to the local survivors, they initially express disbelief.

After verifying your claim, the locals plan to cultivate the remaining annelids. They throw a small feast in your honor to celebrate. When you leave the next morning, there’s an extra crate of foodstuffs in your transport.

entry.name: Sandpit/Intro
entry.value: Old stories told tales of “spontaneous generation”—that creatures and plants come into existence from nonliving matter. Here, what was a lush river valley stretches before you, blasted into bare sand and glass in a passing tragedy of the war. Yet, incredibly, something is living there—leviathan annelids, pre-vertebrate creatures, writhing through the shardsand for nutrients, some grown to massive sizes. “What has your world become?”, you wonder.

entry.name: Sandpit/Intro/Feed
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Feed the worms:<style name='Paragraph'/> Looking at their clacking maws, a whisper in your head tells you that they prefer silicates for dinner. It’s probably just intuition, but you go with it.

entry.name: Sandpit/Intro/Ignore
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Leave well alone:<style name='Paragraph'/> If these creatures can survive by swimming in broken glass, maybe you should stay well away.

entry.name: Sandpit/Intro/Kill
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Kill them all:<style name='Paragraph'/> They are abominations and a threat to human life. Destroy them.

entry.name: Sandpit/Intro/Study
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Take sample:<style name='Paragraph'/> The boffins at the lab might be able to make something of this. Either that or you can put it on a hook and go fishing for whales.

entry.name: Sandpit/StudyFailure
entry.value: Perhaps your researchers should have been less invasive in their techniques with the annelids. You can inform their families of their failure once you’ve dealt with the mess they’ve left behind. Meanwhile, a group of the strange Aegyllan creatures have arrived, apparently to defend the invertebrates.

entry.name: Sandpit/StudySuccess
entry.value: Moving slowly and cautiously, the researchers have learned more about the annelids’ life-cycle, such as their microscopic silicon eggs and their rapid growth, consuming only the finest crystalline rocks. They are closely related to the Aegyllan “worms” encountered elsewhere—though whether they are a foodstuff, children or pets, you can’t tell.

entry.name: StolenGoods
entry.value: Stolen Goods

entry.name: StolenGoods/Intro
entry.value:
Several of your cargo bays are looted overnight. Graffiti on the walls depict a skull with five curved blades fanned out behind it like a lion’s mane—a calling card of Calem Vorshole and the Wicked Kings gang.

Calem messages you and offers a simple, non-negotiable deal: arrange a one-on-one meeting for him with the Chieftess in return for all the goods he stole. Then he sends a location where he’ll be waiting and cuts off contact.

Based on Calem’s reputation, you’re sure he’ll honor the deal—but will a talk really be the end of it?

entry.name: StolenGoods/Intro/ArrangeTheMeet
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Arrange the meet:<style name='Paragraph'/> You need those resources more than a favor from the Chieftess. Convince her to meet with Calem.

entry.name: StolenGoods/Intro/Investigate
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Investigate why:<style name='Paragraph'/> You want your resources back but don’t want to go in blind. Call in some favors and look into Calem Vorshole’s motives.

entry.name: StolenGoods/Intro/HuntThemDown
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Hunt them down:<style name='Paragraph'/> Calem was a fool to tell you where he was. The thief isn’t going to get a meeting, but a reckoning.

entry.name: StolenGoods/Intro/Ignore
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Ignore:<style name='Paragraph'/> The resources are a pittance compared to the risk. Let the Wicked Kings enjoy the goods, you know it’s not really what they want.

entry.name: StolenGoods/ArrangeTheMeetSuccess
entry.value:
You convince the Chieftess to meet with Calem. She’s not wild about the idea, but does it as a favor to you.

When she calls you again, she’s bleeding from a dozen fresh wounds. She spits blood and threatens you, but you convince her that you didn’t know about Calem’s plan to assassinate her. You sense it’ll be a long time before she trusts you again.

Your missing supplies appear the next morning with everything accounted for. Apparently there’s some honor among thieves after all.

entry.name: StolenGoods/ArrangeTheMeetFailure
entry.value:
You convince the Chieftess to meet with Calem. She’s not wild about it, but she’s willing to do it as a favor to you.

At least, that’s what she said. She never shows up to the meeting site and Calem calls you, livid as he curses her name and yours. You tell him that you got her to agree to the meeting—it wasn’t your fault that she went back on her word.

Despite your sound logic, your missing supplies never show up again. Apparently there’s no honor among thieves after all.

entry.name: StolenGoods/InvestigateSuccess
entry.value:
You don’t like that Calem holds all the cards. You haven’t survived this long by just doing what other people wanted.

You call in some favors and find out that Calem is planning to murder the Chieftess. Your first thought is to warn her, but then you realize that you’ll profit no matter who walks out of that meeting.

Here’s your chance to let two potential rivals kill each other. Is your relationship with the Chieftess worth the resources?

entry.name: StolenGoods/InvestigateSuccess/ArrangeTheMeet
