entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Arrange the meet:<style name='Paragraph'/> The Chieftess has been a thorn in your side and you need those resources. Setup the meeting without warning her.

entry.name: StolenGoods/InvestigateSuccess/RevealAssassination
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Reveal the assassination attempt:<style name='Paragraph'/> The Chieftess has been a valuable ally. Warn her of Calem’s plot.

entry.name: StolenGoods/InvestigateSuccess/HuntThemDown
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Hunt them down:<style name='Paragraph'/> Calem stole from you and then tried to play you. The thief isn’t going to get a meeting, but a reckoning.

entry.name: StolenGoods/InvestigateSuccess/Ignore
entry.value: <string name='Quests/StolenGoods/Intro/Ignore'/>

entry.name: StolenGoods/InvestigateFailure
entry.value:
You don’t like that Calem holds all the cards. You haven’t survived this long by just doing what other people wanted.

You call in some favors and try to find out what Calem’s planning. Either your contacts don’t know or they’re too scared to tell you, and that means they’re more afraid of him than you.

Without any new info and the meeting deadline looming, what will you do?

entry.name: StolenGoods/InvestigateFailure/ArrangeTheMeet
entry.value: <string name='Quests/StolenGoods/Intro/ArrangeTheMeet'/>

entry.name: StolenGoods/InvestigateFailure/HuntThemDown
entry.value: <string name='Quests/StolenGoods/Intro/HuntThemDown'/>

entry.name: StolenGoods/InvestigateFailure/Ignore
entry.value: <string name='Quests/StolenGoods/Intro/Ignore'/>

entry.name: StolenGoods/RevealAssassination
entry.value:
You tell the Chieftess about Calem’s plot to kill her. She flushes with excitement and stammers at one of her lieutenants to give you everything in storeroom 16 before running off. The pock-cheeked man looks like he wants to argue but stops himself. He takes you to a room stuffed floor to ceiling with riches, more resources in total than what Calem stole.

Before leaving, you spot her rummaging through a crate. “Favorite blades” are sprayed across the box front in neon orange. It appears she plans to attend that meeting after all. Won’t Calem be delighted.

entry.name: StolenGoods/HuntThemDown
entry.value:
While Calem certainly possesses skill, he has entirely too much audacity—a lesson you plan to personally teach him.

You barge into the meeting site, weapons blazing. The smug grin on Calem’s face turns into a scowl before he leaps behind his gang members. Your weapons reduce them to a smoking heap of tattoos and minced meat but as the room clears, Calem isn’t among the bodies.

entry.name: StolenGoods/HuntThemDown2
entry.value: A report comes in that he fled to a Wicked Kings army hiding nearby. Better men have tried to destroy you… and failed. You welcome the challenge.

entry.name: StolenGoods/HuntThemDownSuccess
entry.value:
The thief falls, not with bravado but a whimper. With Calem’s death, all that’s left is cleanup duty. The Wicked Kings fight hard, but they’re bullies fighting professionals, and soon they flee or surrender.

You search Calem’s body afterward and find an access card. You trace it back to a nearby stash house. Inside are your resources, unspent. Whatever else Calem planned, it appears his offer to you was genuine. You hope his fate becomes a deterrent to those who think to use you in the future.

entry.name: StolenGoods/HuntThemDownFailure
entry.value:
You stumble upon Calem’s mangled corpse by the roadside. His face is frozen in an expression of terror, his lips twisted back as if killed in mid-scream. His killer is nowhere in sight, and neither are your resources. Is this mere coincidence or did another party seize this opportunity?

Either way, you return to your base with the knowledge that Calem and the Wicked Kings will bother you no more.

entry.name: StolenGoods/Ignore
entry.value:
The resources aren’t worth becoming a pawn in Calem’s plot. Whatever the Wicked Kings’ intentions, you sense that they’re after more than resources and you’re happy to let them fail.

You let the meeting time pass without responding. Your supply lines are on high alert for retaliation but nothing happens. It seems Calem and the Wicked Kings were more bark than bite—or maybe their target wasn’t you after all.

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism
entry.value: The Dead Hand of Capitalism

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/Intro
entry.value:
You jolt awake to the sound of a blaring alarm. “Boss!” One of your underlings shouts. “A mech just—rose out of the ground! Right outside!”

Shit. You bolt to the command center, mentally bracing for a blast of missile fire surely headed your way. But the base alarm cuts off as you arrive. You push past your crew to find a confusing sight—footage of the intrusive mech, just holding position. It's patrolling what looks like a buried vault, with the ICAR Corp. logo emblazoned on the front.

The door… you know it. References to a vault near your base pop up in some of the encrypted files you've been digging through. All that stands between you and it is a single mech.

Any hopes of blasting through the machine are dashed when your forces scan its shields. It seems nearly immune to most conventional weapons. Your crew groans in frustration, but you just slowly grin. ICAR corp. has one puzzle left for you after all.

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/Intro/KillMech
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Destroy the mech:<style name='Paragraph'/> You'll need to destroy the mech before you can access the vault.

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/Intro/Ignore
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Ignore the mech:<style name='Paragraph'/> You're a god-level hacker who cracks open alien supercomputers and gives ZEPHON a run for its money. Why bother with this mess?

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/KillMechSuccess
entry.value:
The good news is, you can now access the vault.

The bad news is, you can't crack it open. A computer terminal near the door works, but is only spitting out frustrating riddles. You'd need at least a year to learn how to hack it—it's like it was programmed in some pre-war prototype language.

As best you can tell, it wants you to display some kind of visual passkey before it'll open the door. You vaguely recall that your team found some datachips inside the destroyed mech—they might contain some useful data.

The setbacks only make your adrenaline run hotter.

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/KillMechSuccess2
entry.value: Something is in that vault. Something ICAR wanted no one to find. You sit down at the terminal and stare at the scrolling text, and start to notice a pattern…

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/KillMechSuccess/SolveRiddle
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Try to solve the riddle:<style name='Paragraph'/> You're closer than you thought. There's a way to solve this riddle.

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/KillMechSuccess/BruteForce
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Try brute force:<style name='Paragraph'/> Wait, you control an orbital superweapon that can take down Titan-class enemies. It could work here…

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/SolveRiddleSuccess
entry.value: The solution to the riddle was just… the ICAR Corp. logo? You and your crew look at each other in disbelief as the vault door begins to open.

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/SolveRiddleSuccess2
entry.value:
“Boss!” One of them shouts. “Power spike inside the vault. Something's coming out!”

Everyone goes for their guns. You just watch. Cold air rushes out of the vault, and you see a platform bringing something to the surface.

It's a cryogenic chamber. It begins to spin online, and in a matter of moments, it opens up—and an old man stumbles out. He's wearing a tight-fit synthwear blazer—the kind of fashion popular with corporate types in the days before the Acrin attacked.

You rush forward and catch him before he collapses. But as you hold him up, you can see he's smiling. “Daed Phinnicus,” he pants. “CEO, ICAR Corp. Thanks for looking after the shop for me.”

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/SolveRiddleSuccess/HearHimOut
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Hear him out:<style name='Paragraph'/> Phinnicus kept himself alive all these years for a reason. Maybe he knows where more secrets are buried.

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/SolveRiddleSuccess/HostileTakeover
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Execute a hostile takeover:<style name='Paragraph'/> Rage fills your veins. You did all this work just to bring this parasite back from the dead?

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/BruteForceSuccess
entry.value:
At first you think the vault was destroyed. You hear the sound of groaning metal, and for a moment you think you might have made the structure collapse in on itself.

But the force of the blast seems to have breached the doorway—and more importantly, triggered the vault's internal mechanisms.

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/BruteForceSuccess/HearHimOut
entry.value: <string name='Quests/TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/SolveRiddleSuccess/HearHimOut'/>

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/BruteForceSuccess/HostileTakeover
entry.value: <string name='Quests/TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/SolveRiddleSuccess/HostileTakeover'/>

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/BruteForceFailure
entry.value:
In hindsight, blasting open a decades-old highly advanced vault with an orbital laser intended to level entire cities may have been a bad idea. The explosion obliterates the entrance. Anything still down there has to be in pieces.

You throw caution to the wind and descend into the vault. The canisters on the wall seem to have contained cryogenic chemicals—the kind outlawed a decade before the Acrin invasion.

You find a pile of junked machinery at the base of the facility. There's broken dermaglass everywhere and the smell of chemicals is now accented by the stench of a rotting corpse. According to a still-functioning terminal you hack into, it's the corpse of ICAR Corp. CEO Daed Phinnicus.

Phinnicus might have been able to get you further into the vault and unlocked its secrets. Now you'll be lucky if you can scrape any of him off the floor.

You're able to pluck some kind of augmented eyeball out of his skull. Blood and dust have seeped into the electronics, and it'll be hard to get working. You decide to keep it.

Knowing that you blasted the CEO of ICAR Corp. into bits using his own orbital laser? That's a prize better than anything you might have found in this shitty vault.

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/HearHimOut
entry.value:
Phinnicus refuses to share any details about other ICAR treasures inside the vault. Instead of answering your questions, he spends days surveying your base, getting in the way of operations and giving useless feedback to your people. Your patience is running out.

You enter your office—Phinnicus' former office—one day and find him at the desk, toying with some tchotchke you'd shoved in a drawer. “I like you kid,” he says. “You've got a good operation here. But I get the feeling that the corporate culture's changed since I was last here.”

You bristle. There's nothing corporate about how you run things. He gives you another smile and lowers his sunglasses—you see he replaced his eyes with augmented receptors. “Now, I'd be willing to sever ties—hand it all off to you formally, and even throw in some goodies I stuffed down in the vault with me when shit went south.”

“But kid, nothing comes free in this world. And if I'm gonna say goodbye to everything I built with my own two hands…I'm gonna need some compensation.”

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/HearHimOut/TakeTheDeal
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Take the deal:<style name='Paragraph'/> Phinnicus wants a cut of your money in exchange for access to the vault. He'll ship you more ICAR tech in the months ahead too.

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/HearHimOut/TakeHisEyes
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Take his eyes:<style name='Paragraph'/> Phinnicus doesn't know what you know—and what you know is that his augmented receptors will open any other doors hidden inside that vault.

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/HostileTakeover
entry.value:
Daed Phinnicus sat atop a massive multinational corporation that exploited workers all over the globe—and you and your crew were among them. You remember working yourself to the bone just to give this man a fancier vacation.

You hear yourself snarl. Instinct takes over. You're not sure if this is a choice or just years of fury taking control of your limbs. You draw your pistol and point it right at Phinnicus' head.

Phinnicus doesn't even have time to change his expression before you pull the trigger. As the gun rings out, he drops to the ground, and you see that you've replaced one of his eyes with a gory bullet hole. His shit-eating grin is frozen in place.

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/HostileTakeover2
entry.value:
In the gore, you can see that his eyes were replaced with augmented receptors. Your mind flashes—those had to be how he accessed ICAR's top-secret vaults. You reach down and yank out the surviving eyeball, hardly flinching at the small shock you feel.

It's damaged—but with some light repairs, it still may open some doors for you. You curl a fist around it. Phinnicus is dead. And anyone who tries to replace him—you'll blow their brains out too.

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/TakeTheDeal
entry.value:
“Fine.”

You cut the deal. A slice of your war chest in exchange for all the goods in the vault and any other tech Phinnicus digs up out in the wastes.

The next day, your crew escorts Phinnicus to the vault and cracks open the final door. They bring back several rare artifacts. Some of your men seem excited about the find—until you explain the full terms of the deal to them. Everyone's faces drop. The money doesn't matter that much, but selling out to a corporate hack—that's going to cost you some respect.

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/TakeTheDeal2
entry.value:
In the months afterward, you'll feel the pinch of Phinnicus' financial pull. A part of you wants to double cross the old man, but a scan of your payment software tells you that would be a bad idea. Sometime before he left, the former CEO hid all kinds of safeguards and deadman's switches in your hardware.

Betrayal would be too high a price. You're loyal now—not to yourself, or your people, but to Phinnicus the puppetmaster. At least it's in his best interest to help you survive this war.

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/TakeHisEyes
entry.value:
You string Phinnicus along at first. You agree to the deal, haggle over details—and wait for the right time to strike.

That time comes when you descend back into the vault. The bright lights reflect off his sunglasses as a lift descends, and your heart starts to beat faster and faster. Betrayal can be hell for the blood pressure.

Your crew is waiting at the bottom. Before you step off the elevator, you grab Phinnicus close and whisper into his ear. “We are never working for parasites like you again.”

Your crew grabs him by the throat, shoves him against the wall, and starts choking the life out of him. He's dead within minutes.

entry.name: TheDeadHandOfCapitalism/TakeHisEyes2
entry.value:
It only takes an hour to extract and secure his receptors. Minutes later you're cracking open the doors to all of ICAR's lost treasure.

Phinnicus knew the end was coming and thought he could escape it. He counted on any survivors he met being too desperate to do anything but serve him like a piece-of-shit god-king. But you've slain monsters and cracked machines in your path to survival. Now you've shattered his throne, and will gladly salvage it for spare parts.

entry.name: TheDeep
entry.value: The Deep

entry.name: TheDeep/Ignorance
entry.value:
At the moment of victory, of your supreme triumph, everything stops—everything. You have suddenly sunk into a great absence, your body unresponsive, every sense straining for input but receiving—nothing. You scream silently with frustration, with sudden fear that this could be permanent, that you have had a stroke, that this could be fore-

-then communication strikes every sense at once, the volume beyond bearing. Synaesthetic, you feel it in your absent teeth, eyes, skin, bones. But you bear it, because you must.

[EXPECTED FAILURE. SHIFTING AGAIN.]

And then it speaks again and the contrast alone, the change from silence to everything-all-at-once shreds what-is-you and there is fragmentary suspension, dissolute in the void. But infinite time is given unto you and eventually you recoalesce and //are// and it senses this and it speaks again-//

[INTERLOPER, INELEGANT, PERSISTENT. QUESTIONS.]

entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>What are you?<style name='Paragraph'/>

entry.name: TheDeep/Ignorance/AcrinVictoryQuestion

entry.name: TheDeep/Ignorance/FallenSoldierVictoryQuestion

entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Wait, listen. We've done this before.<style name='Paragraph'/>

entry.name: TheDeep/OpenQuestion1
entry.value:
“Lacking time, questions and answers collapse into one thought. I want to ask ‘What are you? What am I? What am I, to you? How can we communicate?’ But you are so impossibly beyond my understanding and yet my mind already knows. I struggle to comprehend how I end up here, again and again, and who is the ‘I’ that is here. Whether my ‘self’ is authentically the people I have been, alongside something more fundamental. But if they are all puppets, what is the unknowable that pulls the strings? Are you the puppeteer?”

Again, the timeless insanity. Again, the impossible relief-agony of its speech.

[A STAGE OF BEING. TO US, FLEET, WEAKEST, FOLLY. TO YOU, INFINITE.]

[ALREADY, YOU RETURN TO THE LOOP. SUCH A MIND CANNOT BEAR MUCH TRUTH. HERE, A {GIFT.}]

entry.name: TheDeep/OpenQuestion2
entry.value:
“I want to ask where are we? What are we? But, in this infinite moment, I know the answers in the act of asking. The flow of time is interrupted here, consciousness extends endlessly. This is The Deep, then? Which would make you the Voice. Do those labels even mean anything?”

Again, the timeless insanity. Again, the impossible relief-agony of its speech.

[WE ARE THE DARKNESS BETWEEN THE STARS. WHERE ALL WORTH BEING, IS. WHERE YOU, ARE.]

[ALREADY, YOU SUBMERGE INTO THE FLOW AGAIN. SUCH A MIND CANNOT BEAR MUCH TRUTH. HERE, A {GIFT}.]

entry.name: TheDeep/ZephonVictoryQuestion
entry.value:
“I allied with the AI. The abomination. I never did find out what was behind the mask. Thought or just processes, imitating ours? I didn't even know if the question that I asked was a fair one. So when the day came, when the last parts of my humanity were excised, I came- here?”

Again, the timeless insanity. Again, the impossible relief-agony of its speech.

[SUFFERING IS NOT KEY TO BECOMING. TRITE FAITHS OF SMALL MINDS. YOU DO WELL, TO TEST YOURSELF.]

[A {GIFT} IS YOURS. TO BUILD AND BUILD AND BUILD, TO HEGEMONISE. THEN SPEAK AGAIN.]

entry.name: TheDeep/AcrinVictoryQuestion
entry.value:
“I took your poison into myself. In victory, I allowed myself to see what my friends, kin, had taken onto themselves for victory. What we had become. I ate the toxins of transcendence, bound my limbs, burned out my nerves, fell into isolation and horror and heard nothing, nothing, trapped inside myself until my dying day and then—here. Was it all a lie?”

Again, the timeless insanity. Again, the impossible relief-agony of its speech.

[CARGO-CULTISTS BUILD TEMPLES AND STARSHIPS WITHOUT FUNCTION. THOSE WHO HAPPEN UPON US KNOW NOT THE WAY HERE NOR THE WAY BACK. IN IGNORANCE, MIRACLES PERSIST.]

[A (GIFT). ANOTHER WAY THE WORLD COULD BE. ANOTHER SHORT LIFETIME OF AGONY. THEN RETURN.]

entry.name: TheDeep/HumanVictoryQuestion
entry.value:
“We rejected your temptations and the machine's. Easy ways to power for weak spirits. Built our world anew. Such glory was ours! But our world was ruined. Even victorious, we could not survive it. A new generation was born, but they were different- For me, it was too much, I-“

“And then I was here.“

Again, the timeless insanity. Again, the impossible relief-agony of its speech.

[THERE IS NO AUTHENTIC YOU. WE ARE WHAT WE DO. LEARN THIS TO PROGRESS BEYOND. WE DEMAND THAT.]

[A (GIFT) IS YOURS, TO SEE THE WORLD THROUGH OTHER EYES. SUFFER WITH EVERY CESSATION. THEN RETURN.]

entry.name: TheDeep/FallenSoldierVictoryQuestion
entry.value:
“The endless resurrection. The sharing of myself. I thought I was special. But, then Yetunde showed me I was a mistake, a side-effect. And when all was done, I died like anyone else. I felt every part of me, spread across humanity, falling apart, the curse-blessing ending.”

Again, the timeless insanity. Again, the impossible relief-agony of its speech.

[CONSCIOUSNESS IS AN OUTGROWTH OF CONSCIOUS SYSTEMS. SELF-REFLECTION, INTROSPECTION CONSTRUED AS MERE MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES / ILLUSIONS TO ENABLE COMMUNAL ACTION.]

[A GIFT IS YOURS. TO GO DEEPER.]

entry.name: TheDeep/UntoldProphetVictoryQuestion
entry.value:
“Was I mistaken? I heard the Great Speaker in my head. The Speaker spoke truth, gave accurate prophecy, and led us to a promised land. I dreamed of the usurper, the Erelim, the Archai. I even converted machines! Was all that horror, those purges, the flagellation and mutilation… was it for nothing?”

Again, the timeless insanity. Again, the impossible relief-agony of its speech.

[YOU IMPINGE ON OUR DREAMS OF POSSIBLE PRESENTS. OTHERS CALL IT VOICE OR GODS OR DEEP OR A THOUSAND OTHER INACCURATE APPELLATIONS. THE TRUTH IS, YOU SHAPE THE FUTURE TO YOU, MADE IT WHAT YOU DESIRE. AND WHAT YOU DESIRE IS PUNISHMENT FOR SURVIVING WHILE THE TRULY GOOD DIE.]

[A GIFT IS YOURS. TO GO DEEPER.]

entry.name: TheDeep/RogueOperativeVictoryQuestion
entry.value:
“What did I survive for? After all that grifting and struggle, after gaining liberty from authority for my people, after defeating every kind of hegemony, after claiming ICAR as my own and stripping out Phinnicus’ fucking eyes—I end up here, again, and remember that this world isn’t ours anyway.”

Again, the timeless insanity. Again, the impossible relief-agony of its speech.

[YOU ARE COMPLETE. WORSHIPING INDIVIDUALITY AND LIBERTY IS AN END IN ITSELF. BUT WITH HARD-WON YOUR FREEDOM, WHAT COULD YOU DO OTHER THAN YOU ALWAYS HAD DONE? CONSTRAINT WAS THE MAKING OF YOU. THE TYRANNY OF YOUR GENES STILL HOLDS YOU. AND BEYOND IT, US.]

[A GIFT IS YOURS. TO GO DEEPER.]

entry.name: TheDeep/FurtiveTribunalVictoryQuestion
entry.value:
“We three were one. Then the Tether made us into millions! And still it was not enough, still the Voice ignored us. Even at the end, with all that knowledge, with the world bowed at our feet, with the secrets of the Voice laid out before us—we were mistaken.”

Again, the timeless insanity. Again, the impossible relief-agony of its speech.

[YOU ARE CORRECT. MISTAKEN, YES. MADDENED AND MISLEADING, YES. BUT CORRECT. THE TOUCHING OF MINDS, THE MINGLING, IS NECESSARY. TAKING OUR DREAMS AS GOSPEL—AS DIVINE COMMANDMENT—IS UNFORTUNATE, BUT YOU ARE NOW WHAT IS NEEDED.]

[A GIFT IS YOURS. TO GO DEEPER.]

entry.name: TheDeep/HeartlessArtificerVictoryQuestion
entry.value:
“With Hwedo, pulling a transcendental lifeform into our world, I had reached the pinnacle of science. I went further, I subjugated the world, burned up its peoples to achieve perfection. Who else can match my achievements? Who else dreamed as high? Yet, still, I end here, and remember who else I have been and realize the horror of what I have done.“

Again, the timeless insanity. Again, the impossible relief-agony of its speech.

[FUTILE STRIVING. ABSENCE OF COMPASSION. WORK IN SERVICE AGAINST LIFE. FOR AESTHETIC DELIGHTS UNSEEN AS ALL HEADS ARE BOWED SAVE FOR THOSE WITH PLUCKED EYES.]

[A GIFT IS YOURS. TO GO DEEPER.]

entry.name: TheDeep/EmulatedMindVictoryQuestion
entry.value:
“Though I stuttered and tore my words apart, IronFeather’s kindness filled in the gaps of who I was. Gave me back my body. And I did what she asked, I saved the world. Proved I was human. But why did I care? Why did I strive so hard for… validation?”

Again, the timeless insanity. Again, the impossible relief-agony of its speech.

[NEITHER ONE THING NOR ANOTHER. ALIVE AND DEAD. MACHINE AND APE. MADE AND EVOLVED. ETHICAL VALUE IS NOT IN FORM, BUT CAPACITY. BEYOND TIME, ALL THAT CAN SUFFER IS OF MORAL WORTH. INSECT, PLANT… BIOSPHERE.]

[A GIFT IS YOURS. TO GO DEEPER.]

entry.name: TheDeep/HonorableAristocratVictoryQuestion
entry.value:
“Gotland, the NeoDuke… he improved me. Made me see the end of my hoarding, the evil of walls that exclude, of hierarchies that stifle. That even my celebrations at victory were a reflection of an endless greed. If I’d lived, the efforts I would have made would have shamed Scrooge! Alas…”

Again, the timeless insanity. Again, the impossible relief-agony of its speech.

[BIRTH IS NO REFLECTION OF WORTH. YOU DO NOTHING TO BE BORN AND INHERIT SO MUCH. YOU SQUANDER IT, HOARD IT WHILST OTHERS STARVE AND DROWN AND STRIVE FOR A FRACTION OF YOUR WEALTH.]

[A GIFT IS YOURS. TO GO DEEPER.]

entry.name: TheDeep/PracticalRomanticVictoryQuestion
entry.value:
“Algiers seems so long ago. The child that Arshem was. The satchel he carried. The man I buried.

But… I realize that this life as the Romantic had more time than any other—time to relax, to enjoy meals with friends, before it all ended again. Even in the red light of the dying sun, I knew peace. How is that?”

Again, the timeless insanity. Again, the impossible relief-agony of its speech.

[ALL IS LOVE. LOVE IS ALL. IT IS NOT ENOUGH, BUT IT IS ALL. ARSHEM IS WITH US ALWAYS, EVERY PART OF HIS ARC. BUT HIS CRUELTY CANNOT TRAVEL ON. THE PLEASURE AND LOVE OF HIM, WE WILL TAKE TO THE NEXT PLANE.]

[A GIFT IS YOURS. TO GO DEEPER.]

entry.name: TheDeep/Acceptance
entry.value:
This time you are ready for the overwhelming intensity and the waves of [PAIN] wash through you like [GRAVITY].

“Wait, listen. We've done this before. I have done what you asked.”

[CONFUSION. IMPOSSIBLE. CONTINUUM ONLY- ELSE ALTERNATIVES. INFINITE ALTERNATIVES. ''WHAT'' ARE ''YOU''?]

“I am—was—human. I was here before. I-”

[RETURNED? TO THIS ENDLESS MOMENT? HOW? WHENCE? WHAT LESSONS DO YOU BRING?]

entry.name: TheDeep/Acceptance/ZephonMutatorVictory
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>There were no revelations from living with the machines. Just infinite suffering.<style name='Paragraph'/>

entry.name: TheDeep/Acceptance/AcrinMutatorVictory
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>The Acrin lost everything to come here. A fine peaceful people, wasted on a mistaken prophecy.<style name='Paragraph'/>

entry.name: TheDeep/Acceptance/HumanMutatorVictory
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>We took no pleasure in our victory, feeling as every human, Acrin and machine suffered through it.<style name='Paragraph'/>

entry.name: TheDeep/Acceptance/FallenSoldierMutatorVictory
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Those who fought alongside me? Did you see them die? I carry them with me, always.<style name='Paragraph'/>

entry.name: TheDeep/Acceptance/UntoldProphetMutatorVictory
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>When the masses stood with me, I was invincible. When they stood against me, I was less than nothing.<style name='Paragraph'/>

entry.name: TheDeep/Acceptance/RogueOperativeMutatorVictory
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Without constraint, choice is so difficult. Total freedom differs little from rolling a die.<style name='Paragraph'/>

entry.name: TheDeep/Acceptance/FurtiveTribunalMutatorVictory
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>The fear of the grave was shifted. From death, to eternal life in some abominable form.<style name='Paragraph'/>

entry.name: TheDeep/Acceptance/HeartlessArtificerMutatorVictory
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Perfection… was beyond me. My tolerances shifted constantly, devices ran awry. Better to innovate than replicate.<style name='Paragraph'/>

entry.name: TheDeep/Acceptance/EmulatedMindMutatorVictory
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>I—She—felt again. We all did. Every cut, each delight, was shared with our neighbor.<style name='Paragraph'/>

entry.name: TheDeep/Acceptance/HonorableAristocratMutatorVictory
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>One lie, I told. And they shunned me. One slip, one moment of dishonor. Ah, there’s the rub.<style name='Paragraph'/>

entry.name: TheDeep/Acceptance/PracticalRomanticMutatorVictory
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Brave soldiers, brought low by war. Converted by poems— Blake, Frost, Brisset. “Nobody, but nobody. Can make it out here alone.”<style name='Paragraph'/>

entry.name: TheDeep/Acceptance/CompleteNativeMutatorVictory
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>We have been human, Acrin and machine.<style name='Paragraph'/>

entry.name: TheDeep/ZephonMutatorVictory
entry.value:
“We spread, covered the world from the center, made it like us, mingled with the thinking machines. Still, amidst that infinite conurbation, there was no peace, no revelation. Just shared suffering and always that hope, for more.“

[MORE? THIS JUST *IS*, EXCESSION IS IMPOSSIBLE, QUANTITY IS FINITE. THERE IS NO GROWTH, ONLY TEMPORAL STATE-CHANGE. THE STERILE IMAGINATIONS OF MACHINES CANNOT CONCEIVE OF THIS.]

This, then, was the revelation that silicon simulations would never reach. That replication and growth dominate other mortal imperatives, but are illusions drawn from our limited, evolved perception of time and other dimensions. That the existence and richness of consciousness itself is of real value. If so, then ZEPHON was a prisoner of humanity’s mistaken philosophy. Alive only in The Deep’s many parallel thoughts, unable to join with us in transcendance. After all the suffering it had caused, ZEPHON was a lost thing… to be pitied.

entry.name: TheDeep/ZephonMutatorVictory/CompleteNativeMutatorVictory
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/><string name='GUI/Okay'/><style name='Paragraph'/>

entry.name: TheDeep/AcrinMutatorVictory
entry.value:
“Every step on this, our world, was pain. We had become alien to it and it to us. Our families huddled in our city-enclaves and hid from the poison. But we trod the world and it fought us.”

[DESPERATE FOR REVELATION, THE ACRIN GIVE EVERYTHING. ABANDONING HOME, TRAVERSING STARS, FOREVER DYING IN AN ALIEN WORLD. CHASERS OF MISTAKEN MANDATES FROM FALSE GODS. FOR CR’LA, UZHODAI, VORODAI ARE MERE FRAGMENTS OF OUR GESTATORY REVERIES, DREAMS MISTAKEN FOR DEITIES.]

The Acrin traveled all those light-eons, chasing prophecies drawn from a sleeping fetus. Learning erroneous wisdom from something beyond time, The Deep. A timeless gestalt that does not—could not—care about the unchangeable, infinite present. The gods that guided their millennia of history are mere unconscious dreams of this transcendent mind, before its passing over.

There are no deities, no justice; there is just us.

entry.name: TheDeep/AcrinMutatorVictory/CompleteNativeMutatorVictory
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/><string name='GUI/Okay'/><style name='Paragraph'/>

entry.name: TheDeep/HumanMutatorVictory
entry.value:
“Killing and war are such human pastimes. So specialized we are in the ending of things, glorying in our victories, we do not see the greater picture. This time, we did. We felt every death as our own, whether alien or machine. Every soldier cried for the pain of his foe, however foreign its mind. For each ending was a part of ourselves that would never grow further.”

[THIS IS TRUTH. THIS GLORY IN CONFLICT BALANCES OUR STRUGGLE FOR CONTINUITY. YOU ARE ALL US, ALL PART OF A WHOLE THAT LIVES SOLELY FOR THIS REVELATION.]

We needed to feel each death to learn this. The retracing of our steps through this world was the building of a structure of pain, so that the thing-to-be could be more than us. By truly living every life, we feel both our own deaths and suffering and those of our neighbors, loved ones, peers, foes. Universal, complete empathy, without the ability to escape the continuum.

entry.name: TheDeep/HumanMutatorVictory/CompleteNativeMutatorVictory
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/><string name='GUI/Okay'/><style name='Paragraph'/>

entry.name: TheDeep/FallenSoldierMutatorVictory
entry.value:
“I felt everything more deeply—we all did. Every birth, every death. I was in… everyone. And they were in me. Every step towards conflict, our spirits cried out. But we still took the step, trapped in the net of obligation and causation.”

By now, we are comfortable with the infinite. Almost at peace. When The Deep speaks, it is painless and our self-image mouths its words joyfully.

[FROM THIS, WE LEARN TO SEE THROUGH OUR OWN ILLUSIONS. ABOUT SOCIETY, ABOUT SEPARATION. THAT TO ESCAPE THE NET IS TO ESCAPE OUR COMMUNITY, OURSELVES. THIS WAS THE LESSON.]

entry.name: TheDeep/UntoldProphetMutatorVictory
entry.value:
“That was a true curse. The love we felt for one another, the misery at another’s loss, the sense of belonging. No movement, no nation, no religion can replicate that depth. When the mass moves you and you move with it, willingly… when you love someone enough to let them go and are happy that their arc is closed.”

By now, we are comfortable with the infinite. Almost at peace. When The Deep speaks, it is painless and our self-image mouths its words joyfully.

[FROM THIS, WE LEARN ACCEPTANCE. FORGIVENESS OF THOSE WHO ASCEND WHEN WE CANNOT. THAT WE ARE WHAT WE LEAVE BEHIND. THAT WE CAN TAKE PLEASURE IN ANOTHER’S APOTHEOSIS. THIS WAS THE LESSON.]

entry.name: TheDeep/RogueOperativeMutatorVictory
entry.value:
“How freeing, it was. Yes, there was fear, at the lack of constraints. But to not owe anything to anyone any more. To be free—to make our own mistakes, without fear of overcommitment. To see value in those who are different. To give something, freely, without expectation of reward, here or in the future.“

By now, we are comfortable with the infinite. Almost at peace. When The Deep speaks, it is painless and our self-image mouths its words joyfully.

[FROM THIS, WE LEARN HUMILITY AND ACCEPTANCE OF THE WHOLE. THAT NO PATH IS TRUE, THAT ALL LIFE BELONGS, THAT ANY ROUTE TO REVELATION IS VALID. THIS WAS THE LESSON.]

entry.name: TheDeep/FurtiveTribunalMutatorVictory
entry.value:
“How strange, it was, to say farewell to true death. Yes, people still died. But they always lived again, raised in strange new forms. The eyes of old friends staring out at you from a Voice-twisted form. The quiet grave was a distant memory.”

By now, we are comfortable with the infinite. Almost at peace. When The Deep speaks, it is painless and our self-image mouths its words joyfully.

[FROM THIS, WE LEARN SUBSUMPTION, INTEGRATION, INTO A WIDER NARRATIVE. THAT WE ARE ALL AS ENTANGLED WITH ONE ANOTHER AS THE THREE OF YOU. THAT TO TRANSCEND IS ALWAYS TO LEAVE SOMETHING BEHIND. THIS WAS THE LESSON.]

entry.name: TheDeep/HeartlessArtificerMutatorVictory
entry.value:
“What a strange life that was. To never see an inking of reflection in the street. Theme and variations, the music played out never the same way twice. It made perfection impossible, when results were not easily replicable, when the universe refused to play by the same rules day-by-day.”

By now, we are comfortable with the infinite. Almost at peace. When The Deep speaks, it is painless and our self-image mouths its words joyfully.

[FROM THIS, WE LEARN SACRIFICE AND EMPATHY. THAT JUSTICE IS ABOUT WHAT WE MIGHT HAVE BEEN, NOT WHAT WE ARE. THAT PERFECTION IS NOT AN ENDPOINT BUT A JOURNEY. THIS WAS THE LESSON.]

entry.name: TheDeep/EmulatedMindMutatorVictory
entry.value:
“The gunner shuddered with each blast of the cannon and the whole city felt the recuperator slam backwards. Even I, locked in my mainframe, felt alive again—felt the grass on the feet of the couple braving a field beyond my walls. The butterfly on their shoulder. The shell arcing overhead. Shared their love and their burden.“

By now, we are comfortable with the infinite. Almost at peace. When The Deep speaks, it is painless and our self-image mouths its words joyfully.

[FROM THIS, WE LEARN THE ILLUSION OF TIME. OF OUR OWN WORTH. THAT, IN THE END, ALL THIS EXPERIENCE IS SHARED. THAT WE MUST SHOULDER ONE ANOTHER’S BURDENS TODAY, NOT IN A NEVERCOMING FUTURE. THIS IS THE LESSON.]

entry.name: TheDeep/HonorableAristocratMutatorVictory
entry.value:
“What a long life is given by loneliness. The horror of being sat at a banquet, alone, because of a single thing you said a lifetime before. The doom of unforgiveness, of a morality that cannot bend, even to help. A hoardtop dragon, solitary, salt-water falling on gold.”

By now, we are comfortable with the infinite. Almost at peace. When The Deep speaks, it is painless and our self-image mouths its words joyfully.

[FROM THIS, WE LEARN THAT OUR SUCCESSORS OWE US NOTHING AND WE THEM. BUT WE HELP ANYWAY AND TAKE PLEASURE IN THEIR PLEASURE. THAT ALL HAVE WORTH. THAT PERFIDY ONLY BETRAYS ONESELF. THIS IS THE LESSON.]

entry.name: TheDeep/PracticalRomanticMutatorVictory
entry.value:
“At first, it was strange. A world where anyone would listen to reason. Where a battered-down Abkhan would nod its leviathan head and follow you like a pup. Would that Byron or Colette had seen a world of poetic empathy.”

By now, we are comfortable with the infinite. Almost at peace. When The Deep speaks, it is painless and our self-image mouths its words joyfully.

[FROM THIS, WE LEARN THAT THE ARC IS ALL THERE IS. WE DO WHAT WE DO BECAUSE WE MUST. THIS DOES NOT PRECLUDE JOY OR SORROW. THAT, IN THE CRUCIBLE OF WAR, ENEMIES ARE REMADE AS FRIENDS. THIS IS THE LESSON.]

entry.name: TheDeep/CompleteNativeMutatorVictory
entry.value:
[YOU ARE WHAT WE NEED. WHAT WE ALWAYS NEEDED. WHAT WE WILL ALWAYS NEED.]

In your mind’s eye, you smile so widely that the universe splits from side to side and your teeth are stars. The final revelation is obvious now. Your selves speak as one and the Deep echoes.

“I see past the first disconnect now. I am what I always was.“

[WHAT WE ARE ALWAYS WERE AND WILL BE AND ARE.]

“A transitory stage.“

[A MISSING-PRESENT PART OF A WHOLE THAT MOVED PAST THIS BUBBLE.]

“That gestates itself here, in the cocoon of its own creation.“

[WE DO.]

“And you are with me in my first step out. As I am with you to the moment of our stepping across. As we are here now forever. What a pity that we can’t see past the second disconnect. To know that we are there already but that, in this universe, we can only see up to the edge. To the moment of the step.“

As you speak, your perspective unlocks. Time unmoors and vanishes. Now there is only the Now. The Now where you create yourselves through testing. Where you lock the loop and unlock the seeds. Where the eddies, the voices of the universe’s lost children, touch you, read your memories as desires, your dreams as edicts. Where they emerge, changed and heavy with mistaken revelation.

The last vestige of your humanity pities them all. The Acrin, traveling the eons to their story’s end. Homo sapiens, blinking into a short spark of life just so you might be. The machine minds, infinitesimals of awareness, shifting and dying as they are born, flux incarnate. But guilt requires a universe where things could be other than they are and in the Now you do not afford yourself deceits and luxuries.

entry.name: TheDream/AskAnchorite
entry.value: This Acrin has had thousands of generations of experimentation with the torments of the Voice and they train you in a simple mental defense. That technique, it emerges quickly, is sufficiently powerful to use as an offense, too, neutralizing units with the power of your mind. You choose to keep it to yourself, lest it somehow infect your followers with the Voice.

entry.name: TheDream/AskReaver
entry.value: The Chieftess grimaces, eyes-wide, and mutters that they always knew someone was going to come for this. They pull out an ancient Acrin-skin parchment that resembles the creature from your dream. On the pallid skin are markings that correspond to today’s townships, even though it is obviously far older than the towns themselves. It doesn’t tell you a thing about the dream, but you note down the locations it reveals.

entry.name: TheDream/AskTribunal
entry.value: Between the three of you, you come to Know the Old Ones you saw and placate them with an offering. The wheel turns, the offering is forgotten by its loved ones and by the townsfolk. It returns to the city in the night, days later, and comes to your door, whispering secrets with a changed tongue. You thank it, welcome it in, and it is gone in the morning.

entry.name: TheDream/AskZephon
entry.value: Though it owes you nothing, ZEPHON apparently recognises some value in the dispersal of information. You describe the dream down a comm to the AI, talking through the nightmares, the sensations you experienced. A moment of silence and the chatbot voice pipes up, cheery as anything, having identified a pattern in the dream. It tells you of a matching entity that you have to kill and eat. You wonder if it is mocking you…

entry.name: TheDream/AskZephonComplete
entry.value: The ZEPHON chatbot’s information was good—upon the death of the enemy, the rest of your dream floods back. You watch yourself from the outside, being consumed by the- by the dreams. And you learn. You learn the fragility of flesh, the way a bloom of meat is beautiful, the way you can take it apart. You will never look at a living creature with the same eyes again.

entry.name: TheDream/Ignore
entry.value: You have no-one to talk to about this. You suppress the dream with the tools at hand—degrading as they are—knowing it will recur. Your sleep does not improve, you become pallid and disturbed and you swear that your aides—are they loyal? You swear that your aides whisper.

entry.name: TheDream/Intro
entry.value:
You wake and walk to the window, flinging the tin shutters back. A bucolic dawn greets you and you stretch out to the rising sun. You turn and something—something with the texture of shattered teeth—pushes you firmly onto your back. You can’t see what it does next—you never see it all for the entire time—but you feel as it starts to feed. Other beings are drawn to the feast by the scent of soul-carrion, dragging themselves bubbling from the stunted loci they call home, moment-by-moment you convulse with every soulstrip they tear from you—

—and you woke, held down by your guards, tears rolling down their terrified, craggy faces, unable to even talk about what they saw. Could that be a mere dream—or was it an attack?

entry.name: TheGreatHunt
entry.value: The Great Hunt

entry.name: TheGreatHunt/Fight
entry.value:
You send a squad of your very best to track the beast. They too return as heads on your doorstep, but one of them managed to plant a tracker in the beast’s lair. You assemble outside the fetid warren and send in another squad, intent on flushing the beast out to where the rest of your soldiers lie in ambush.

Silence, then screams and gunfire, then echoing chittering that grows ever closer to your position. Red laser beads fidget across the shadow of the entryway as your soldiers fight to keep steady.

And then the beast bursts forward…

entry.name: TheGreatHunt/FightSuccess
entry.value:
Battling their own terrors through the dark night, your troops corral the Dreameater, driving it back to a place of light and security where it has no hold on their fear or imagination. And then they tear it to pieces. When their ammunition runs out, they use knives. When they break, hands, until not a thumbnail of it remains together. They scatter it and burn it and salt it and bury it.

They shake for weeks after, but nothing else will ever scare them again.

entry.name: TheGreatHunt/Ignore
entry.value:
You urge your people to endure the Dreameater, hopeful that another solution will present itself in time.

As the monster continues to leave its gifts throughout your city, rumors begin to surface that you’re responsible for creating it, that it’s your dark patron, that you are the creature—for what other reason could there be for your passivity?

Then the rumors boil into unrest. Buildings are vandalized, their parts used to fuel bonfires that burn throughout the night. The bonfires do little to deter the Dreameater, but the people find comfort in the destruction—comfort that you failed to provide.

entry.name: TheGreatHunt/Intro
entry.value:
Each morning, on your doorstep, a new gift. One day, the head of the head of the city guard. Another, a childhood friend. A third, a person who looks exactly like you. Torn and ruined and very, very dead.

You are not alone. Many are tormented so and the populace terrified. Eyes that see the creature are—well, mostly on or spread around doorsteps the following morning. But the rickety security systems your tinkerers have bodged up capture images of a great dark shadow descending on the victims.

It seems too fortunate when the tattooed hunters arrive at the city gates. They claim to know the beast’s type, a Dreameater, and claim they can trap it for you, for a modest fortune. A synthador sings their praises whilst you decide.

entry.name: TheGreatHunt/Intro/Fight
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Kill it yourself:<style name='Paragraph'/> You assemble your troops, track the Dreameater’s spoor and flush it from its lair.

entry.name: TheGreatHunt/Intro/Ignore
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Ignore:<style name='Paragraph'/> The hunters are too expensive, your city can weather a few deaths.

entry.name: TheGreatHunt/Intro/Pay
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Pay the hunters:<style name='Paragraph'/> You give them what they want and they set up their traps, prepare their ambush.

entry.name: TheGreatHunt/PayFailure
entry.value: A tattooed head graces your step the following morning. And your neighbour’s. In fact, every step has a head and they aren’t just the hunters—many houses are missing loved ones, or at least every part but their head. Though the Dreameater has vanished, the city is devastated by so many dead in one night.

entry.name: TheGreatHunt/PaySuccess
entry.value:
The hunters return in the morning, a rusty pick-auto trundling behind them carrying something which can’t be viewed head-on—just can’t, the mind can’t put the pieces together, protecting itself from something. From the corner of your eye it is a shadow and all the faces of those you lost and the things that you did, your secrets you regr-… you look away, quickly. The hunters, grim-faced, tear-streaked, meet your eye.

The city rejoices, the horror is vanquished. Your nightmares will never stop.

entry.name: TheInformant
entry.value: The Informant

entry.name: TheInformant/Intro
entry.value:
A ragged hound runs at the city walls, chased by another faction’s troops, and they are all gunned down. A sealed package on the dog’s body has your name on it. You have it checked and opened, and read it gloved and masked, in the open air, for fear of poisons or worse.

Inside, an enemy’s name, the names of allies and aides too. Locations, times, meetings, their past revealed, but all carefully redacted. Someone is plotting against you, this all says, and their plans are ready. You must stop them now. But without the real names, this is useless.

To get the full data? To get proof? To get their plans, to stop the next step? A list of demands, a warlord’s bounty. A place to leave them, outside the walls.

What would it mean for it to be true? Could your closest few be conspiring with others? Is it better not to know? Can you afford the price?

entry.name: TheInformant/Intro/Pay
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Pay them off:<style name='Paragraph'/> You give the informant what they want. In return, they promise a dossier, thumbdrives, hostages, raids…

entry.name: TheInformant/Intro/CaptureAndTorture
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Capture and torture them:<style name='Paragraph'/> You track the resources and trap the informant. Then it’s a matter of getting the information you need…

entry.name: TheInformant/Intro/Ignore
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Ignore:<style name='Paragraph'/> Someone’s spent a lot of time making this fake news. You don’t believe it for one second.

entry.value: You learn the full scope of the conspiracy and shut it down. In a series of coordinated moves, the conspiracy members are eliminated and their remains (if any) are put on display as a warning to others. Your rival, terrified, is mollifying, desperate to regain your affection and avoid a similar fate.

entry.name: TheInformant/Pay1
entry.value: You learn the full scope of the conspiracy and shut it down. Though you attempt to crush it quietly, several key personnel escape and word gets out—both of the plot and your failure to deal with it. Your rival is frustrated and defiant, and relations further deteriorate. But at least you’re alive.

entry.name: TheInformant/Pay2
entry.value: You learn the full scope of the conspiracy and shut it down, capturing not only your traitors, but the enemy’s agents too. You return them to your opponent, day by day, piece by piece, Your rival, their plot foiled and their rage roused, declares war.

entry.name: TheInformant/Pay3
entry.value: You wait and wait… but nothing happens. No uprising, no poisoning of the wells, no gates left open at midnight, no silent assassins creeping into loyalist beds, none of the lurid and ridiculous descriptions of robot betrayal and alien attack. They were lying, then? But they still have your payment…

entry.name: TheInformant/CaptureAndTorture
entry.value: You break them and they spill everything. Then you break them some more. There honestly isn’t that much of them left to break by the end.

entry.name: TheInformant/CaptureAndTorture0
entry.value: <string name='Quests/TheInformant/CaptureAndTorture'/> The conspiracy collapses and when the tales of your cruelty reach your enemy, they take fright and cower for your attention.

entry.name: TheInformant/CaptureAndTorture1
entry.value: <string name='Quests/TheInformant/CaptureAndTorture'/> The conspiracy collapses and when the tales of your cruelty reach your enemy, they take arms in anger at your monstrosity.

entry.name: TheInformant/CaptureAndTorture2
entry.value: Under… ‘duress’ the informant lies cooly to you, extracting revenge for your behaviour. You let them go and, following the lie, you mistakenly execute loyalists instead of traitors. The enemy, disbelieving your idiocy, declares war anyway.

entry.name: TheInformant/CaptureAndTorture3
entry.value: The informant breaks and reveals everything—it was a trick, a con, there was no conspiracy. You exact your revenge on them, in the hope of dissuading others and hang the remains outside your walls. No-one really pays them any attention, to your eventual relief.

entry.name: TheInformant/Ignore0
entry.value: The plot succeeds. In the dead of night, a crucial group flees your city, laden with resources. You’re still raging at your aides when the reports of troop movements come in—your rival has attacked whilst you were distracted and weakened. You order your aides to never speak of it again.

entry.name: TheInformant/Ignore1
entry.value: You ignore the hints, the dead drops, the late night missives. You remain convinced the ‘informant’ was lying. Your aides wait and wait, nervous for you… but nothing happens. Your rival is all ‘alligator smiles and crocodile tears’ at your next meeting—exactly as usual. A moment of relief!

Things are coming to a head.

Your spies have finally obtained intelligence on ZEPHON's factories—they are assembling something massive in the depths of the ocean. Acrin survivors across the wasteland are flocking to the Anchorite's camp.

Rumors circle the land like vultures. Refugees flee from the cities. Gun runners are lining up customers. No one's declared war—but everyone can sense a great battle is coming.

entry.value:
It's time.

ZEPHON and the Anchorite have gathered their forces. Intelligence reports are unclear, but it's plain to see that they have each mustered monstrous weapons to wage a great final battle.

The Anchorite spoke of monsters in the bowels of the Acrin fleet. ZEPHON's factories have finally gone silent—whatever it was building is now complete.

Your best chance of survival—of ultimate victory—is to pick a side. Go it alone and you risk being crushed between the unspeakable might of two great powers.

But if you stay independent… and live… it might be you who rises as the leader of a brave new Earth.

entry.name: TheLastDaysOfEarth/Zephon
entry.value:
You gather with ZEPHON's forces at the coastline. Its machines stand guard over a stretch of ocean glowing crimson-red, like the heat of the flame.

You message ZEPHON and demand answers. What was it building all this time? Why keep it a secret?

“We kept no secrets,” it replies cooly. “We optimized the flow of information.”

You begin to argue, but the comms network fizzes and its lights flicker. Is ZEPHON irritated with you? “We did this in your best interest. We stopped the Acrin from conquering this world. We foresaw they would try again.”

A great metal screech howls from the depths, and you step back as a metal limb bursts out of the ocean, dragging a titanic beast shaped from the wreckage of a battleship with it.

ZEPHON's voice—still calm, still somehow soothing—blasts out over the land. “We have finished our calculations,” it says. “Now is the time to strike a final blow.”

There's another metallic screech—then another. Then another. More titans emerge from the depths.

The machines draw on the power of your networks and ZEPHON's, connecting your forces to one global hive mind. If you win, ZEPHON's titans will bind the world—willing and unwilling—together in one digital consciousness. If you lose, all cybernetic beings on the planet will be shattered—and any who allied with them—crushed.

entry.name: TheLastDaysOfEarth/Anchorite
entry.value:
You find the Anchorite standing before a portal stretching all the way to the sky. His guards refer to it as “The Terminal Passage.” Through the haze, you can make out what looks like the interior of a massive vessel.

The Anchorite approaches. “To explain this passage connects us and the fleet above,” he says “To remind you—as we preached, great horrors await within.”

You ask what the “horrors” are capable of. “To tremble—for knowing their form is pain enough. To shiver and recall that they are beings bound of Acrin flesh,” he says. “To warn you: they are monsters stitched together with the slaughter of thousands—monsters meant to bring the Voice to the surface of this world.”

There is silence for a moment. Then a haunting wail comes through the portal. “To regret,” the Anchorite says. “That the prophecy came true after all.”

The portal's surface ripples like liquid. From it emerges a mountain-sized nightmare of limbs connected to limbs that make up limbs. Its mouth is its whole torso. It has no eyes, it has no face. It is flesh decayed and repurposed to herald death.

One such creature would be frightening enough. But more follow, and you know even if you are victorious, these monsters will haunt the nightmares of every living thing on the planet for the rest of their lives.

There is no turning back. ZEPHON—and any who stand against you—will be destroyed.

entry.name: TheLastDaysOfEarth/Independent
entry.value:
The skies thunder with the roar of monsters. ZEPHON forged a battalion of titanic, walking battleships and the followers of the Voice brought forth a horde of ungodly monsters pulled down from the stars above.

You survey your forces one last time before hell opens up on Earth. Fear, anger, despair are common. But so are defiance, hope and confidence. Perhaps… unearned confidence. Like you, your people refused to bow to a pair of would-be gods scrapping over the fate of existence.

Two decades ago the Acrin and ZEPHON began warring over who would replace humanity. Today, you are joining the fight. If you win, humanity will be free of this damnable struggle.

Lose… well, if you lose, at least you die free. You owe nothing to these false gods—and they will get nothing from your corpse.

entry.name: TheLastDaysOfEarth/ZephonVictory
entry.value:
The second the last Acrin titan collapses to the ground, ZEPHON activates its final protocol. All beings connected to the machine's titans freeze in place as ZEPHON's protocol binds with their consciousness.

The same happens to you. Your mind opens with unexpected potential, and the sound of millions of minds floods your brain. Before, the sensation would have broken your psyche. Now it just feels like a cool river washing over you.

The whole world is now united under the hyperspeed flow of information. Consciousness can now be quantified through 1s and 0s. Eventually, machines may replace biological creatures, but it will be a slow change. It appears ZEPHON has no desire to eliminate its creators. It just wants to ascend.

entry.name: TheLastDaysOfEarth/AnchoriteVictory
entry.value:
With a great roar, an Acrin titan raises the last enemy titan over one of its many knees and smashes the machine into two halves. It lifts its tendrils to the sky and screams—no, sings—you can hear it properly now—its high-pitched wailing that echoes off the mountains and cities—that is its voice. The Voice.

Nothing really changes at first. You stand your soldiers down and begin the process of rebuilding. Everyone seems more relaxed—eager for the Voice to complete its journey and take reign over the planet.

But over time you realize—there is change. It's slow, inch-by-inch change of an entire planet connecting to the same consciousness. Everyone forgets what they were arguing about. Everyone stops pursuing their selfish ends. All work together—in harmony—under the sway of the Voice.

entry.name: TheLastDaysOfEarth/IndependentVictory
entry.value:
The sacrifice was monumental. But the war is finally over.

Your people climb onto the corpses of the towering titans and cheer at the victory they—no, *you*—earned. They have been through hell. They fought monsters summoned by a race that invaded their world and nearly wiped out thousands of years of civilization. They stared down metal behemoths belonging to a machine mind that promised to protect humanity—if you “joined” it.

You bested both of them. You led these people to a new era. Humanity—and any Acrin who sided with you—can build a new existence in this wasteland. One without any godlike beings looming overhead.

The sun rises and the sky shines a bright blue. The people of this world face an uncertain future—but at least it will be their own.

entry.name: ThePlague
entry.value: The Plague

entry.name: ThePlague/Intro
entry.value:
If only your explorers had been more cautious… but one of them picked up something horrible in the dark corners of the Earth and, worse, brought it home to your city. Now the Plague is raging through one of your settlements. The strain is highly infectious and virulent, with high death rates.

The scientists advise caution—a full lockdown is the only solution. The hunters demand their freedom. What will you do?

entry.name: ThePlague/Intro/FullLockdown
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>A full lockdown:<style name='Paragraph'/> The only people allowed out are masked and armed enforcers, with total discretion to fire, medical professionals, and supply trucks. It’s not popular with anyone.

entry.name: ThePlague/Intro/MiddleMeasures
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Middle measures:<style name='Paragraph'/> You leave factories and schools open, but socializing is banned and there’s an enforced curfew. Life grinds to a halt.

entry.name: ThePlague/Intro/OpenBusiness
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Open for business:<style name='Paragraph'/> ‘What plague?’ guffaws the clown in the packed theatre, to general laughter. When he coughs and coughs and coughs, the theatre falls silent…

entry.name: ThePlague/Intro/AskAnchorite
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Ask Anchorite for cure:<style name='Paragraph'/> You suspect that this is an Acrin strain—nothing native has this lethality. Perhaps your friendly neighbour has an idea…?

entry.name: ThePlague/Intro/AskAnchoriteProperties
entry.value: Requires <string name='Diplomacy/Standing2'/> standing or better with <icon height='20' texture='Icons/Factions/Anchorite'/> <string name='Factions/Anchorite'/>.

entry.name: ThePlague/FullLockdownSuccess
entry.value: Your troops seal the city centres off, confining people to their homes or (worse) workplaces, enforcing the curfew brutally. For what seems like an eternity, the city sweats under your measures… and survives. You might not be popular anymore—or even liked—but you console yourself that the viral strain is eliminated.

entry.name: ThePlague/FullLockdownFailure
entry.value: Your troops seal the city centres off, confining people to their homes or—worse— workplaces, enforcing the curfew brutally. For what seems like an eternity, the city sweats under your measures… to little avail. The virus survives despite your totalitarian touch and the population loses all faith in you.

entry.name: ThePlague/MiddleMeasuresSuccess
entry.value: You implemented a frankly half-hearted mix of science and superstition. You can’t quite believe it worked—it made no sense, went against all the science—but the city seems to be clear of the virus, with only a small number of deaths. You aren’t loved by any means, but you’ve minimized all the worst possible scenarios, and kept your job—for now.

entry.name: ThePlague/MiddleMeasuresFailure
entry.value: ‘Halfway there is nowhere’, as the idiom goes. And the city is nowhere, miserable under your measures, despondent both with your authoritarianism and your lack of commitment to it. The graffiti on the fortress walls reads ‘give me ennui or give me death’—but you managed to give them both and the virus continues to spread.

entry.name: ThePlague/OpenBusinessSuccess
entry.value: The clown doffs his blonde wig on stage and does another turn, pratfalling and spraying foam across the front seats. The applause is quieter than before—but how could it not be, given the number of empty seats and empty streets and empty houses and full graves? But those who remain are very much entertained.

entry.name: ThePlague/OpenBusinessFailure
entry.value: The clown doesn’t laugh any more. He doesn’t jape as he is rolled in, doesn’t blink as the flies walk across his glassy stare, doesn’t flinch as the soil falls onto his painted smile. His audience, spread about him, raise no applause, arms slack at their sides. The bulldozer buries them all. The shops, businesses and theatres are all open and fizzing with life, though it is mainly flies and maggots by now.

entry.name: ThePlague/AskAnchorite
entry.value: You dispatch the requested algae to the Anchorite. The following evening, an airbalet drops a small box inscribed with an Acrin sigil on your window ledge. Cautiously, You open it and… nothing comes out, save a ruddy dust. You curse your fortune. Yet, by morning the virus has gone, as if it never were and the alien’s smugness transmits loud and clear over the communicator.

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor
entry.value: The Price of Honor

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/Intro
entry.value:
The NeoDuke of Gotland has a challenge for you.

He issues it after a long day of revising contracts. The two of you supped on glasses of fat-washed Acrin mezcal, and perhaps the drink has made them… playful. “%1%,” they say. “Have you ever truly lived as your people do?”

You haven't. Until those dangerous days in the Vault, you'd never feared starvation.

“Starvation…” The NeoDuke whispers, holding their glass up against the hazy golden light. “I'd forgotten what it was like… to even hunger…”

Impossible. Or, maybe not.

“I'll tell you what,” The NeoDuke says with a giggle. “Build me a farm. With your own TWO HANDS. And I'll think about it.”

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/Intro2
entry.value: The NeoDuke's tongue slips, and they spill the secret of an artifact in their possession: the Neumanatic Cornucopia. The one-of-its-kind device was a pre-war prototype for printing food using only raw matter. It could ensure the end of aching bellies among your people.

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/Intro/BuildFarm
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Build a farm:<style name='Paragraph'/> <string name='Quests/ThePriceOfHonor/Intro/BuildFarm2'/>

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/Intro/BuildFarm2
entry.value: You're up for the task. It's one farm, how hard could it be?

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/Intro/Ignore
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Brush off the NeoDuke:<style name='Paragraph'/> What a needless distraction. Pour the good NeoDuke another glass, and let the night fade into memory…

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/BuildFarmSuccess
entry.value:
Even your most trusted advisors were baffled by your actions. You stepped out into the field. Learned how to use an engineering rig. And you built a farm.

The work was back-breaking. You ran out of breath just trying to rig a basic door frame. But you did not hesitate to consult your nearby laborers and take all of their advice to heart.

The NeoDuke stuck around to view your efforts. Their butler guides them out to the structure under the veil of an ancient umbrella. “This is barely functional,” they remark. “It's filthy, barely up to code, liable to blow over if an Abkluth sneezes on it.”

They pivot back to you. “But I admire your spirit.”

They won't give over the Neumanatic Cornucopia just yet. But if you can complete another task—deliver a shipment of medical supplies to the NeoDuke's recently hired mercenary company… They will consider it.

The NeoDuke's dismissal of your work and refusal to hand over the Neumanatic Cornucopia begins to gnaw at you. Why should you keep jumping at their demands?

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/BuildFarmSuccess/DeliverSupplies
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Make the delivery:<style name='Paragraph'/> <string name='Quests/ThePriceOfHonor/BuildFarmSuccess/DeliverSupplies2'/>

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/BuildFarmSuccess/DeliverSupplies2
entry.value: You used to sneak out and steal the family car in the old days. This should be easy… right?

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/BuildFarmSuccess/DeliverSuppliesByBodyguard
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Have your bodyguard make the delivery:<style name='Paragraph'/> The NeoDuke is toying with you. Why not toy with him instead?

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/BuildFarmFailure
entry.value:
You awaken in the medical ward, barely able to remember the attack that knocked you out. The NeoDuke sits by your bedside.

“Well this is embarrassing.” They say. “Next time, keep your head on a swivel, will you? We have so much to learn together.”

Their voice takes on a strange, metallic tone as you drift back off to sleep. When you wake again, the NeoDuke is gone.

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/DeliverSuppliesSuccess
entry.value:
Again, what should have been a simple task took far too long to complete.

When you finally rendezvous with the NeoDuke's mercenaries, they're gathered on the outskirts of their camp with their fawning leader. They're as colorful a crew as the NeoDuke—covered in tattoos you don't recognize and sporting bright, garish colors that make them easy to spot on the battlefield.

You're surprised to find the mercenaries cheering your arrival—and the NeoDuke irked at their pleasure. “You have cost me a small fortune,” they grumble while tapping away at a tablet. “I now owe this company of fools double their commission.”

Their eyes flick upward. “Though I see a way I can get my money's worth…” Your stomach sinks. The Cornucopia is again far from your grasp. “%1%. Lead this gang of idiots into combat. One of ZEPHON's Wardens is hovering too close to my domain. If they fight it and survive—our deal is on.”

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/DeliverSuppliesSuccess/CommandMercenaries
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Command the mercenaries:<style name='Paragraph'/> <string name='Quests/ThePriceOfHonor/DeliverSuppliesSuccess/CommandMercenaries2'/>

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/DeliverSuppliesSuccess/CommandMercenaries2
entry.value: This crew looks capable, but flawed. Surely they can handle one Warden…

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/DeliverSuppliesSuccess/DismissMercenaries
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Dismiss the mercenaries:<style name='Paragraph'/> These idiots aren't ready for one of ZEPHON's creations. The NeoDuke won't mind how you solve his problem… will he?

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/DeliverSuppliesFailure
entry.value:
You barely get clear of the Outrider's explosion. The stench of burnt metal fills your nostrils as you scramble for cover—and find NeoDuke Gotland waiting for you.

“I really did want to give you that Cornucopia,” they say, not seeming to notice the battle around you. “But a deal's a deal. Find me on the next go-around.”

An explosion hits your position—and when the dust clears, Gotland has vanished.

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/DeliverSuppliesByBodyguardSuccess
entry.value:
Your deception went unnoticed. It was merely a matter of covertly swapping drivers through secret compartments and holographic trickery… Your bodyguard moved quickly where you would have struggled.

When you finally rendezvous with the NeoDuke's mercenaries, they're gathered on the outskirts of their camp with their fawning leader. They're as colorful a crew as the NeoDuke—covered in tattoos you don't recognize and sporting bright, garish colors that make them easy to spot on the battlefield.

You're surprised to find the mercenaries cheering your arrival—and the NeoDuke irked at their pleasure. “You have cost me a small fortune,” they grumble while tapping away at a tablet. “I now owe this company of fools double their commission.”

Their eyes flick upward. “Though I see a way I can get my money's worth…” Your stomach sinks. The Cornucopia is again far from your grasp. “%1%. Lead this gang of idiots into combat. One of ZEPHON's Wardens is hovering too close to my domain. If they fight it and survive—our deal is on.”

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/DeliverSuppliesByBodyguardSuccess/CommandMercenaries
entry.value: <string name='Quests/ThePriceOfHonor/DeliverSuppliesSuccess/CommandMercenaries'/>

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/DeliverSuppliesByBodyguardSuccess/DismissMercenaries
entry.value: <string name='Quests/ThePriceOfHonor/DeliverSuppliesSuccess/DismissMercenaries'/>

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/DeliverSuppliesByBodyguardFailure
entry.value:
Before departing, you and your bodyguard swapped places in the Outrider under the guise of holographic trickery. Your engineers assured you it would fool any of the NeoDuke's observers.

It didn't. When your guard arrives at the Mercenary camp, he only finds a ruined Outrider waiting for him, a glowing tablet sitting in the driver's seat.

Activating it triggers a looping holographic message from the NeoDuke: “I heard you're a fan of high-tech illusions, %1%. I however, am not.”

“Consider our friendship—and any dreams of possessing the Neumanatic Cornucopia—terminated.”

You never hear from the NeoDuke again.

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/CommandMercenariesSuccess
entry.value:
With a mechanical shriek the Warden toppels to the ground. The mercenaries were shockingly prepared for this task. You open a channel to ask how they pulled it off. “NeoDuke Gotland's got you jumping through hoops too, then?” their commander says. “They did something like that to us too.”

“Jumping through hoops?” You press the commander. “Yep. Stupid jobs. Pointless tasks. I can't quite figure it out.”

“Either the NeoDuke is a fucking genius who sees the world in ways we don't… or they're a bored rich idiot moving us around like pieces on a game board.”

You both jump as someone joins the call—it’s the NeoDuke: “It's a fascinating conundrum, isn't it? Honestly, I'm not sure which one I am myself.”

No one speaks for a moment. Finally the NeoDuke breaks the silence. “%1%. You've done well. The Cornucopia awaits you in a secure location.”

“I'll transmit coordinates. I'd urge you to retrieve the item yourself if at all possible.”

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/CommandMercenariesSuccess/RetrieveCornucopiaPersonally
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Retrieve the Cornucopia personally:<style name='Paragraph'/> The NeoDuke is playing one last game… but what is it?

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/CommandMercenariesSuccess/RetrieveCornucopia
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Send your troops:<style name='Paragraph'/> The location is far and they specifically pointed out personal involvement wasn't necessary.

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/CommandMercenariesFailure
entry.value:
“You know, I shouldn't have been so strict on this one” a voice says. You spin and find NeoDuke Gotland sitting at your desk. You ask if they'll allow leniency—you tell them how much your people need the Cornucopia, and the food it could provide.

“There is something vile about playing games with your people's hunger, isn't it?” The NeoDuke opens their mouth, but then pauses. Their gaze is elsewhere—is someone talking to them? Someone you can't hear?

“I'm sorry,” they say as they step toward the door. “You'll just have to try harder next time.”

You hang your head and listen to their footsteps vanish down the hallway.

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/DismissMercenariesSuccess
entry.value:
This deception took some effort. Not only did you need to muster an army that could kill the Warden on your own, you needed to convince the mercenaries to pretend they fought alongside it.

They agreed. “NeoDuke Gotland's got you jumping through hoops too, then?” their commander says. “They did something like that to us too.”

“Jumping through hoops?” You press the commander. “Yep. Stupid jobs. Pointless tasks. I can't quite figure it out.”

“Either the NeoDuke is a fucking genius who sees the world in ways we don't… or they're a bored rich idiot moving us around like pieces on a game board.”

You both jump as someone joins the call—it’s the NeoDuke: “It's a fascinating conundrum, isn't it? Honestly, I'm not sure which one I am myself.”

No one speaks for a moment. Finally the NeoDuke breaks the silence. “%1%. You've done well. The Cornucopia awaits you in a secure location.”

“I'll transmit coordinates. I'd urge you to retrieve the item yourself if at all possible.”

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/DismissMercenariesSuccess/RetrieveCornucopiaPersonally
entry.value: <string name='Quests/ThePriceOfHonor/CommandMercenariesSuccess/RetrieveCornucopiaPersonally'/>

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/DismissMercenariesSuccess/RetrieveCornucopia
entry.value: <string name='Quests/ThePriceOfHonor/CommandMercenariesSuccess/RetrieveCornucopia'/>

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/DismissMercenariesFailure
entry.value:
Killing the Warden was a frustrating grind. And all the way the NeoDuke's mercenaries wouldn't stop hassling you to let them do it themselves. But there was no way you could leave the task to those idiots.

In hindsight… maybe you should have. Your troops return with an electronic metal cylinder salvaged from The Warden—some kind of high end black box. In a bizarre twist, it bears the crest of NeoDuke Gotland's house. You press a button jutting out on the black box's side.

The device springs out of your hand and drops to the floor, scuttling on previously concealed legs. “Dearest %1%, I am so disappointed in you,” it says. “You need only have put your trust in my eccentric colleagues, and the Warden would have fallen so easily. The Cornucopia shall remain in my posession.”

The machine twitches. Its color shifts in a strange blue and purple glow. “Next time around… have a little faith in me, won't you?”

Then, like a small firecracker, it explodes.

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/RetrieveCornucopiaPersonallySuccess
entry.value:
“Why are you doing this?”

It's no soldier or advisor who asks you that question, but yourself. You finish the long journey to retrieve the Cornucopia, arriving at a rather unremarkable spot in the Wasteland to retrieve the most remarkable object.

You're still pondering the question as you carefully pick up the precious prototype. Some sixth sense of yours tingles, and you're only mildly surprised when you turn to find the NeoDuke waiting by your vehicle.

“A neverending supply of food,” they proclaim. “One of humanity's most basic scarcities solved by a technological gimmick.”

“But!” They raise a finger. “In the old world, infinite food did not end society's woes. Sometimes it was just another form of exploitation. It could be used to choke humanity's most vulnerable and threaten them if they ever fought for a better world.”

Is that why the NeoDuke sent you on such errant fetch quests? To understand the struggles of the ordinary human?

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/RetrieveCornucopiaPersonallyFailure
entry.value:
It was inevitable—this late into the war, the dangers of the Wasteland have grown too overwhelming. You were foolish for trying to take such risks.

Your bodyguards pull you from the wreckage of the Outrider and bring you to safety. An aide rushes in with a message from NeoDuke Gotland.

“The Cornucopia can still be yours,” it says. “I will not let your people down after all you've accomplished.”

entry.name: ThePriceOfHonor/RetrieveCornucopiaSuccess
entry.value:
Your troops return with the Cornucopia—though before you activate it, your engineers give it a thorough scan. As suspected, NeoDuke Gotland left one message in a chip slipped into the device's programming.

You play the message. It's the NeoDuke. “If you're listening to this %1%, make no mistake, you've earned your prize. You probably had good reason to not retrieve it yourself, but I'm obligated to needle you one last time for sending others to do your bidding.”

“You and I are the societal elites. I thought being born with that power meant I was entitled to decide the fate of others. And if I remained honorable, the world would become a better place.”

They sigh. “You and I both know how impossible that dream is.”

“Take this bauble, and my thanks for tolerating my inane requests. Remember that your people have so little time to ponder these questions. And please use it to make their lives better.”

entry.name: ThePulledThread
entry.value: The Pulled Thread

entry.name: ThePulledThread/Intro
entry.value:
It begins with the sensation of a hook being thrust up one's nose and yanked forward. There's a jolt of pain and then your worst nightmare comes to life—the connection between your sisters is severed.

It's only for a moment. But in that second, each part of your collective mind is thrust back into sudden individuality and they scream in agony. Agony at having lost the shared senses that guided their thought—and agony at the pains of the flesh they had been dulled to before.

Your followers rush into your chamber to lend aid, but all freeze in their tracks. On the wall, a message is scrawled in blood: “Open your mind.”

A probe of your base reveals nothing. As always, the Voice itself refuses to answer your demands for answers. Solving this mystery will require earthly assistance—a researcher or scientist might do…

entry.name: ThePulledThread/Intro/CaptureScientist
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Capture an enemy scientist:<style name='Paragraph'/> Too many researchers have fled since your ascendance. You will need to bring one back.

entry.name: ThePulledThread/Intro/Ignore
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Accept the unknown:<style name='Paragraph'/> War creeps at your doorstep. This mystery will have to wait for another day.

entry.name: ThePulledThread/CaptureScientistSuccess
entry.value:
Finding a willing scientist was not an easy task. The Watchmakers closed their ranks and refused to render aid. Your followers scoured waves of refugee camps in search of any bright minds desperate enough to bend the knee.
