Orin needs no threat of execution to enlist in your cause. He has a theory about how your mysterious assailant gained access to your mind. But to trace the attack, he will require physical specimens to research.

“There is a gland in human minds,” he whispers softly, “that bridges the mind and what humans think of as 'the soul.'” “I will need many such glands to solve your particular problem.”

entry.name: ThePulledThread/CaptureScientistSuccess2
entry.value: Finally, the Voice's whispers guided you to a worthy servant: a slick-haired recluse who only gives you the name “Orin.” It seems Orin has spent years in the wastes conducting experiments that you might once have branded sacrilegious.

entry.name: ThePulledThread/CaptureScientistSuccess/EnemyGlands
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Bring him the glands of your enemies:<style name='Paragraph'/> Your soldiers already commit the necessary slaughter on a daily basis. They can recover these glands from the bodies.

entry.name: ThePulledThread/CaptureScientistSuccess/PeopleGlands
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Bring him the glands of your people:<style name='Paragraph'/> <string name='Quests/ThePulledThread/CaptureScientistSuccess/PeopleGlandsFlavor'/>

entry.name: ThePulledThread/CaptureScientistSuccess/PeopleGlandsFlavor
entry.value: Sacrifice is a fact of life under the eye of the Tribunal. Your people will gladly die to save their leader. You need only gather enough to do so…

entry.name: ThePulledThread/EnemyGlandsSuccess
entry.value:
It takes far more killings than you anticipated to yank the number of needed glands from the skulls of your enemies. Orin seems to pay little mind to the cost you paid to perform his little experiment, so you decide to put him in his place—by having each of you eat a gland right in front of him.

Orin works faster after this—but not fast enough to your liking. One day you return to his lab ready to demand results—and find him crumpled on the ground, blood oozing from his shoulder, his arm cast across the room. Someone has severed his arm and made off with his work.

You summon a host of followers to tend to his wounds. He'll recover—but it will be some time before he regains consciousness.

A scan of his documents tells you that Orin was working on some form of neurostimulating headset. He nicknamed it “The Tribunal's Tether.” If the thief had wanted the Tether destroyed, it would be here in pieces. You unleash a furious howl that rings through your fortress. The hunt now begins.

entry.name: ThePulledThread/EnemyGlandsSuccess/RecoverTether
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Recover the Tribunal's Tether:<style name='Paragraph'/> <string name='Quests/ThePulledThread/EnemyGlandsSuccess/RecoverTetherFlavor'/>

entry.name: ThePulledThread/EnemyGlandsSuccess/RecoverTetherFlavor
entry.value: The thief wasted no time selling Orin's experiment to the Concordat. They will return it to you—if you can pay, of course.

entry.name: ThePulledThread/PeopleGlandsSuccess
entry.value:
Harvesting the needed glands takes time, and bodies. So many bodies. You make it a personal point of visiting Orin's lab each day, locking eyes with each follower who is to be sacrificed. Their faith in you is completely unshakeable.

This blind obedience to you unnerves Orin. You can smell the fear bound in his sweat as he furiously works to complete his research. When you visit him, he babbles about producing a helm modified by neurostimulants that will open your mind.

But one cursed morning, you arrive in his workshop to find that he's fled—and taken the helm with him.

A foul traitor. You will recover what has been stolen from you.

entry.name: ThePulledThread/PeopleGlandsSuccess/KillOrin
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Kill Orin:<style name='Paragraph'/> Orin cannot run far. When you have recovered his work, you dream of how you might dispose of him.

entry.name: ThePulledThread/RecoverTetherSuccess
entry.value:
The lost Tether is back in your grasp. Orin does not seem to have fully recovered from his wounds, but he is able to produce duplicates of the headset—one for each of you. Each of you raises the Tether to their heads in a unified gesture. None react as the needles sink into their skin.

For a moment, nothing happens—but then you hear a ringing, and then are overwhelmed by a vision.

Your mind once again splits in three. Each of you is flung down a different psychic path, filled with impossible visions. You see cerulean sunsets, stars exploding into black holes, worlds that look like threads of ribbon strung together, and then slowly, your consciousness reassembles, and you look up.

At first you think it is a mirror image of you—another Tribunal. But you are one-in-three. This—the thousands of eyes staring back at you—belong to a consciousness made of millions.

It is not the Voice. It is something else—another entity living on the Voice's galactic tendrils. All of its eyes snap to you, and you are overwhelmed by the unending sense of being PERCEIVED by this horrible creature—

You snap awake. You are back on Earth. Orin feebly raises his head to stare at you. “You saw it,” he croaks. “Didn't you?”

entry.name: ThePulledThread/RecoverTetherSuccess2
entry.value:
You look down. The Tether—it has changed. You sense that it and others like it can now connect you to the other Tribunal.

Possibly the only Tribunal. And maybe you are now a part of its gathered minds…

entry.name: ThePulledThread/KillOrinSuccess
entry.value:
You give Orin no time to explain himself. As soon as his Tether is recovered, you take up three knives across your many hands. He tries to back away, but all of your blades slash across his body in one unified swoop. Blood dribbles from his lips and he collapses to the ground.

Without him, you only have the one Tether at your disposal.. The youngest of your trio is chosen to wear the device, and she raises it above her head, allows the needles to pierce her skull—and screams as your consciousness is pulled through time and space.

Soon you find yourself floating over an emerald-green ocean, whose waters all pour into a titanic chasm. Stone limbs extend out of the water, and you see strange buglike beings crawling up and down them. These creatures have also heard the Voice's whispers, and have accepted its power. And they used that power to try to kill you.

Just as they invaded your mind, you reach out and plunge into theirs. You snap the threads of their connection as though you were severing a man's tendons with a rusty knife. Soon a mass of screaming corpses are falling down the chasm and your vengeance is finally complete.

The vision ends. Your followers are desperate to know what you saw. And when they learn that you reached across the stars to kill a whole civilization…they prostrate themselves before you. When this journey began, you were their savior. Now?

Now you are their god.

entry.name: ThePulledThread/CaptureScientistFailure
entry.value:
The mysteries deepend. Your terrified advisors are laden with excuses about how the one reliable scientist who would aid you in this matter met his end, but the threads of fate tell another story.

Someone, or something, was not ready to speak with you. It orchestrated the man's death. But it seems inevitable that your path and its will one day cross again.

entry.name: TheSkyFallen
entry.value: The Sky, Fallen

entry.name: TheSkyFallen/Intro
entry.value:
Unusually, when your people assault the Acrin compound, there is no return of fire, only an incessant sobbing noise, like heavy rain on plastic sheeting. As the squad filters into the encampment proper, the source becomes apparent—a small group of Acrin in ragged survival gear, outside the makeshift shelters, prone and twitching, howling. To one side, a clutter of scavenged components acts as a speaker, cycling through human languages, barking the words for surrender and help.

Your troops are perplexed, and radio you directly for orders.

entry.name: TheSkyFallen/Intro/HelpThem
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Help them:<style name='Paragraph'/> You leave enough resources for the Acrin to make repairs to their life support systems.

entry.name: TheSkyFallen/Intro/BringThemBack
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Bring them back:<style name='Paragraph'/> The Acrin are great soldiers. Corral them and send them to your nearest outpost to be armed and trained.

entry.name: TheSkyFallen/Intro/OpenFire
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Open fire:<style name='Paragraph'/> Your troops execute the defenseless Acrin.

entry.name: TheSkyFallen/HelpThem
entry.value:
These once proud destroyers, reduced to pitiful wretches. You hope their salvation also means yours, so you give the Acrin enough resources to sustain themselves and repair their critical systems.

Your soldiers assist the aliens and the work is completed swiftly. Afterward the Acrin line up and walk by your forces individually, giving each a swooping gesture that begins and ends at their eyes, before returning to their compound.

A day later the Anchorite contacts you. Tales of your kindness spread throughout the Acrin enclaves, and those you saved wish to live near you permanently.

entry.name: TheSkyFallen/BringThemBackSuccess
entry.value:
These once righteous destroyers, now reduced to pitiful wretches. Their talent for war could be your salvation though.

Whether through understanding or despair, the Acrin offer no resistance when your soldiers surround them and march them back to your outpost. Only a dozen recover enough to begin training. Equipped with salvaged alien tech, they display deadly marksmanship and unparalleled mobility. Even your most cynical soldiers soon agree that the Acrin would make an excellent addition to your army, an offer the Acrin readily accept—and seal by killing the unconverted.

Despite their shifting allegiance, the aliens remain fanatics.

entry.name: TheSkyFallen/BringThemBackFailure
entry.value:
These once righteous destroyers, now reduced to pitiful wretches. Their talent for war could be your salvation though.

Whether through understanding or despair, the Acrin offer no resistance when your soldiers surround them and march them back to your outpost. Only a dozen recover enough to begin training. Equipped with salvaged alien tech, they display deadly marksmanship and unparalleled mobility. Even your most cynical soldiers agree that the Acrin would make an excellent addition to your army, an offer the Acrin readily accept—right before they turn on you.

You should have known better than to attempt to convert fanatics.

entry.name: TheSkyFallen/OpenFire
entry.value:
The Acrin deserve no quarter. They descended upon your world as destroyers. Their fanaticism is what doomed both your species.

Nobody speaks. Nobody has to. You put a bullet into the makeshift speaker. Its mechanical whine slurs to a stop. Your soldiers start shooting, their inner demons appeased, however briefly, by powder-light and rifle-fire. Afterwards you loot the compound before razing it.

News of your deed spreads throughout the factions. The Anchorite is furious, but when did you care what hypocrites think? The others all seem pleased or intimidated—something that you can leverage into future favors.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine
entry.value: The Space Engine

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/ChangeThePastSuccess
entry.value:
Power flickers across your city as Zandra activates her time portal. The transuranium arch sparks as the space within bends and forms a gateway to the past. Eighty of your best march through—right as the Acrin first attack.

Dedicated to the long haul, your soldiers wage guerrilla war for decades. While few in number, their advanced gear and tactics make them an unstoppable force, appearing in key battles to devastate both sides before vanishing again.

You build a monument to honor the few that return. They retire happily, knowing that their past victories have permanently crippled your rivals.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/ChangeThePastFailure
entry.value:
Power flickers across your city as Zandra throws a switch on her time portal. The transuranium arch sparks as the space within distorts and stabilizes into a gateway to the past. Forty of your best march through—just in time for ZEPHON’s key counteroffensive.

But without a clear guide to the past, it’s all your forces can do to survive the ensuing destruction as Acrin ships explode and plummet from orbit, blotting the skies and smashing the earth with their shattered debris. In the aftermath, they find no sign of ZEPHON.

While your soldiers return, nothing has changed.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/FindAcrinInsightsSuccess
entry.value:
Zandra’s time portal takes you aboard an Acrin flagship. The air is strangely humid. Webs of rust-red moss cover the dark corridors. Outside, the Acrin fleet approaches the Earth.

A familiar Acrin argues against their fellow council nearby. They’ve traveled millennia to destroy a threat to all existence, but nothing resembles that on this planet. Could the Voice possibly be wrong? A vote is called, and only the Anchorite is against Earth’s annihilation.

Then you’re yanked back to the present. With your new insight into the Acrin’s purpose, your relationship with the Anchorite greatly improves.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/FindInsightsFailure
entry.value:
Power flickers across your city as Zandra activates her time portal. The transuranium arch lights up as the space within bends, the gateway growing increasingly stable with each passing moment.

Then the metal frame groans loudly. Klaxons begin blaring as sparks hiss and fly. The arch buckles and collapses, sending the portal’s energy exploding outward and overcharging the generators. Emergency coolant systems activate, but it’s not enough.

Evacuation finishes moments before Zandra’s lab explodes. All that remains is a smoldering crater in the hills. With no chance to try again, you can’t help but wonder what could have been…

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/FindZephonInsightsSuccess
entry.value:
Zandra’s time portal brings you to an unmarked military bunker. Layers of jammer-mesh cover its thick concrete walls.

Crimson code runs on a mainframe’s console. It isn’t ZEPHON—it isn’t even one program. Instead, countless micro-programs compete to execute on the limited processing cores. Each new processing cycle brings digital annihilation and incremental evolution. Progress is glacial yet steady—but it’s a far cry from ZEPHON’s sophistication.

As you copy the code, you notice a breach in the Faraday cage. You didn’t do this—so who did? With no further clues, you return to the present.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/GatherResourcesFailure
entry.value:
The engineer’s deadline arrives, but you’ve failed to gather the resources. She looks at you with disappointment and mutters something about “next time” before excusing herself and returning to her lab in the hills.

You wake up the next morning with an uncanny sensation. Everything seems to be in order, but the feeling remains unshakable. Your gaze falls on a crater in the hills where an eccentric engineer once ran a lab. It’s been years since an explosion destroyed it. You’ve left the rubble visible as a warning to your other researchers.

Unsure what the feeling is, you move on.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/GatherResourcesSuccess
entry.value:
Impossibly, you’ve gathered everything the engineer asked for. Your workers gather to celebrate the achievement. It’s clear the extraction has taken its toll on them. While they’re not soldiers, they fight hard for you in their own way, and many of them bear new scars or injuries from the heavy labor. Despite their wounds, their eyes shine with pride and hope.

It’s enough wealth to bring factions to their knees, should you really hand it over for a glimpse of truth? Or can you keep the resources and profit off the technology another way?

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/GatherResourcesSuccess/ChangeThePast
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Change the past:<style name='Paragraph'/> Forget the butterflies, anything is better than this living hell. Demand the engineer alter the past directly.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/GatherResourcesSuccess/FindInsights
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Find insights:<style name='Paragraph'/> Bullets win battles but insights win wars. Hand everything over to the engineer and proceed.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/GatherResourcesSuccess/IgnoreAfterGatherResources
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Don’t do it:<style name='Paragraph'/> Why meddle with the past when you can shape the future? Scrap the project, and spend those resources elsewhere.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/GatherResourcesSuccess/SellTechToAnchorite
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Sell the tech to Anchorite:<style name='Paragraph'/> Perhaps you can profit and save humanity by selling everything to the Anchorite? They will assuredly use this to benefit both your peoples.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/GatherResourcesSuccess/SellTechToChieftess
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Sell the tech to Chieftess:<style name='Paragraph'/> Humanity needs a champion but you can’t afford the risk. Caution balances daring, so the Chieftess might be just the right buyer.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/GatherResourcesSuccess/SellTechToConcordat
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Sell the tech to Concordat:<style name='Paragraph'/> There’s always a buyer, if you don’t ask too many questions. And the Concordat doesn’t like questions…

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/GatherResourcesSuccess/SellTechToZephon
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Sell the tech to ZEPHON:<style name='Paragraph'/> This could be a valuable upgrade for an AI—and establish you as a worthy ally in the process.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/Ignore
entry.value:
Zandra storms off after you refuse to support her project, but soon after she begins recruiting her peers. Engineers from across your territories flock to assist her—so many that your key projects risk being understaffed.

An adviser offers a simple solution—he asks her for proof of her claims. When it’s Zandra Kyne, a known eccentric, who’s proposing time travel, then you’d be a fool not to get confirmation.

Her followers wait eagerly, but Zandra is unable to offer any proof—not until it works, she exclaims. Disappointed, her followers disperse and you never hear from Zandra again.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/IgnoreAfterGatherResources
entry.value:
Realization stops you from handing over everything to Zandra. With the weapons built from these resources, you don’t need time travel to win the war.

Zandra leaves you with a disappointed look, muttering something about “next time” before returning to her lab in the hills.

You wake up the next morning with an uncanny sensation. Your gaze falls on a storage vault in the hills, built from a crater where an eccentric engineer blew up her lab years ago. Nervous, you check your resources—and everything is there.

Unsure what the feeling is, you move on.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/Intro
entry.value:
You never sleep well—how could you—but there is no way that you're sleeping through the sounds of struggle.

It is Zandra Kyne, a well-respected if eccentric engineer, wrestling with your guards. She has been synthesizing technology from ZEPHON and the Acrin night and day, and has found something tachyon-based that is beyond them both—or so she claims. No one else understands the technology sufficiently to follow her revelations, but she thinks she can travel through space and time. She suggests using it to find insights into the Acrin's purpose or the origins of ZEPHON—but there is only a limited window to deploy it.

Up until this point, she has seemed her usually harmlessly insane self, but when she starts listing out the resources she'll need for it to be safe—well, your advisors are aghast at the cost. But she says she’s very certain of success ‘this time’…

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/Intro/GatherResources
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Gather the resources:<style name='Paragraph'/> <string name='Quests/TheSpaceEngine/Intro/GatherResources2'/>

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/Intro/GatherResources2
entry.value: The cost is acceptable if compared to the gain. Let the engineer try—she’ll pay if it fails.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/Intro/LockHerUp
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Lock her up:<style name='Paragraph'/> We have enough problems as it is, trusting something beyond ZEPHON and Acrin to this engineer seems foolish.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/Intro/Ignore
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Ignore:<style name='Paragraph'/> A lunatic raves, but it’s the fool who listens.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/LockHerUpSuccess
entry.value:
Zandra is a dangerous inspiration. Your other scientists begin championing their pet projects over the ones you appointed. Each thinks they have the key to victory, none are concerned with the costs.

You need to make an example of her. Zandra shouts as your enforcers drag her into the streets. She begs the gathering scientists to activate her machine as she’s locked into an iron hollow, but the masses ignore what they once celebrated. The onlookers shuffle in silence as Zandra’s pleas echo, then fade, into the distance.

Then the scientists return to their labs.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/LockHerUpFailure
entry.value:
Zandra is a dangerous inspiration. Your other scientists begin championing their pet projects over the ones you appointed. Each thinks they have the key to victory, none are concerned with the costs.

You need to make an example of her. Zandra shouts as your enforcers drag her into the streets. She begs the gathering scientists to activate her machine as she’s locked into an iron hollow. No one responds, but many openly glare at you. The next day, strikes occur across your labs and key projects stall.

While progress is merely slowed, any misstep can be fatal in the race for survival.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/SellTechToAnchoriteFailure
entry.value:
The Anchorite seems disappointed as you finish describing the technology. Whatever regrets the Anchorite has, they extend back millennia, not decades, and they reject your offer politely.

When Zandra discovers your offer to the Acrin, she’s furious. She glares at you and mutters “like last time” before storming off towards her lab in the hills.

Soon after, you get an uncanny sensation. Your gaze falls on a crater in the hills where an eccentric engineer’s lab exploded long ago. Why had it never occurred to you to clean up the rubble? Chiding your oversight, you move on.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/SellTechToAnchoriteSuccess
entry.value:
The Anchorite seems disappointed in your offer. Their long life comes with deep regrets, and they lament that your technology extends back mere decades, not millennia. Still, they accept.

Their representatives arrive with a massive, worm-like nightmare that streaks through the sky. It descends, coiling, and clacks its tusked maw menacingly. The Acrin dab your lips and temple with a reddish, numbing concoction, transferring the creature’s full obedience to you.

A week later, you’re struck by an uncanny realization. How have the Anchorite’s forces evolved such perfect defenses? It’s as if they had extra decades to prepare…

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/SellTechToChieftessFailure
entry.value:
As soon as you mention time travel, the Chieftess apologetically declines. Why would she pay to travel in time when she wouldn’t change a thing?

When Zandra discovers your offer to the Reaver, she’s furious. She glares at you and mutters “like last time” before storming off towards her lab in the hills.

Soon after, you get an uncanny sensation. Your gaze falls on a crater in the hills where an eccentric engineer’s lab exploded long ago. Why had it never occurred to you to clean up the rubble? Chiding your oversight, you move on.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/SellTechToChieftessSuccess
entry.value:
As soon as you mention time travel, the Chieftess accepts.

You expected her to bring a trade convoy, instead she arrives in a two-story tank with more guns than physics allows. She jumps down from a side-hatch and, muttering apologies, tosses you the keys and drives away in one of your transport trucks. Fortunately for all, it’s the one with her purchased goods.

You’re struck by an uncanny sensation. The Reaver’s known for her cunning, not her brilliance. How is her material science decades ahead of everyone else? It’s as if she had extra time to prepare…

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/SellTechToConcordatFailure
entry.value:
The Concordat delegate calculates the profitability ratios of your offer with machine-like efficiency. When the results predict negative shareholder returns, you’re declined and given complimentary shuttle service back to your base.

When Zandra discovers what you did, she’s furious. She glares at you and mutters “like last time” before storming off towards her lab in the hills.

Soon after, you get an uncanny sensation. Your gaze falls on a crater in the hills where an eccentric engineer’s lab exploded long ago. Why had it never occurred to you to clean up the rubble? Chiding your oversight, you move on.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/SellTechToConcordatSuccess
entry.value:
The Concordat delegate calculates the profitability ratios with machine-like efficiency. When they predict massive shareholder returns, you’re escorted to a private VIP room and served rare pre-war luxuries.

Soon, a delegate enters—is it the same one?—carrying a stasis case. The lid splits open with a click. An azure filigree orb rises to hover above the table, pale netherlight gleaming off its shifting wire-frame. As you grip its icy surface, the wires unravel and creep up your arm to form a fractal gauntlet.

You down your champagne and depart, eager to try your new weapon.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/SellTechToZephonFailure
entry.value:
ZEPHON promises to process your offer overnight but no response comes. Instead, your system protections are continuously hammered for days as it attempts to hack the information—but your defenses hold.

When Zandra discovers what you did, she’s furious. She glares at you and mutters “like last time” before storming off towards her lab in the hills.

Soon after, you get an uncanny sensation. Your gaze falls on a crater in the hills where an eccentric engineer’s lab exploded years ago. Why had it never occurred to you to clean up the rubble? Chiding your oversight, you move on.

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/SellTechToZephonSuccess
entry.value:
ZEPHON processes your offer overnight before accepting. The drones take the resources along with Zandra’s research and depart.

Your engineers determine that ZEPHON’s material sciences are decades ahead of everyone else. But how? The production time alone should prevent such a wide gap.

You’re struck by an uncanny sensation. It’s as if ZEPHON had gained additional time to prepare…

entry.name: TheSpaceEngine/SellTechToZephonSuccess2
entry.value: The next day, a swarm of aerial drones drop off a silver-alloyed casket outside your city. The casket slides open with a hiss, revealing ZEPHON’s half of the bargain: a sleeker, upgraded Warden with carbyne-edge blades and an improved payload.

entry.name: TheSummoning
entry.value: The Summoning

entry.name: TheSummoning/Intro
entry.value: Should you stop them or let them complete their ritual? There’s nothing to suggest that they’re hostile after all.

entry.name: TheSummoning/Intro2
entry.value:
It began as a complaint about a thickness in the air, tickling and buzzing above the skin like invisible flies. Then the atmosphere tinged rust-red, unfamiliar stars graced the sky, and birds started flocking in interweaving spirals.

Your scouts trace the anomalies back to a group of Cr’la Disciples. They’re preparing a ritual near one of your territories. Your Voice experts decipher that it’s a summoning—but to affect the surrounding region, it must be of unfathomable magnitude.

entry.name: TheSummoning/Intro/Attack
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Stop them:<style name='Paragraph'/> If their ritual is truly harmless, they would have informed you first. That they didn’t, suggests there’s something to hide.

entry.name: TheSummoning/Intro/Ignore
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Let them be:<style name='Paragraph'/> Weird occurances and cults go hand in hand, but they haven’t actually harmed anyone. Leave the cultists alone and focus on actual threats.

entry.name: TheSummoning/Attack
entry.value: You decide to go and stop the ritual. Your Voice advisers tell you to act fast—they believe the ritual will be completed soon, and then you’ll learn what the cultists were planning the hard way.

entry.name: TheSummoning/Negotiate
entry.value:
One of the Voice cultists approaches your group, lifting their many arms in a display of reverence. They are pilgrims performing a ritual—here, at a prophesied location—to create a bridge to an ancient protector.

The prophecy foretold your arrival and so they prepared an appropriate gift, but wish to finish their religious rite.

Nothing suggests the cultists are hostile, but they speak of the protector like a deity—an immensely powerful one. Will you let them be?

entry.name: TheSummoning/Negotiate/Combat
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Refuse:<style name='Paragraph'/> You’re flattered, but cautious. Refuse the bribe and stop their ritual.

entry.name: TheSummoning/Negotiate/CombatBetrayal
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Pretend to accept:<style name='Paragraph'/> It’s not betrayal, it’s maximizing your opportunities. Take the gift, then stop the ritual anyway.

entry.name: TheSummoning/Negotiate/Accept
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Accept:<style name='Paragraph'/> While unsettling, the cultists have done nothing wrong. Take the gift and leave them in peace.

entry.name: TheSummoning/Combat
entry.value:
You tell the cultists that you can’t let their ritual continue, but they may leave in peace. Their chanting goes on. The lead cultist politely asks you to reconsider; they’ve worked so hard and deliverance is so close.

When your soldiers enforce your order, rolling thunder erupts from the cowl of the lead cultist—and then all hell breaks loose.

The only way to stop them now is to kill them before the ritual is complete.

entry.name: TheSummoning/CombatBetrayal
entry.value:
You accept the cultists’ offer and they bring out a heavy ornate box filled with minerals. The lead cultist waits expectantly after you secure their gift. Once it’s clear you’re not leaving, they politely ask you to return the gift. Your counter-offer is to let them leave safely after they stop their ritual.

When the cultists don’t respond, your soldiers move in to enforce your order—and all hell breaks loose.

Now the only way to stop the cultists is to kill them before their ritual is complete.

entry.name: TheSummoning/CombatEarlySuccess
entry.value:
With their cultists dead, the leader invokes the ritual in desperation. A nightmarish titan flickers into existence over the rune-etched ground.

But something is wrong. The leader retreats—too late, as the ritual space collapses, forcibly melding the cultist with the creature. The new existence shrieks and writhes in agony as its unstable form ossifies. It falls, shattering into jet-like slivers that shiver in resonance.

A scepter-like chunk remains, thrumming and radiating power. As you examine it you glimpse the merged creature reflected in its facets. Unperturbed, you collect the artifact and return to base.

entry.name: TheSummoning/CombatSummon
entry.value:
Your time is up.

A low, thrumming forcewave explodes from the ritual site, shaking the earth and sky. The space above the ritual ground is split by a hair-thin fracture before three immense, segmented legs rip it open. A towering nightmare of fangs and whip-like appendages steps through. Even from a distance, it looms over the battlefield. Then, suddenly and without motion, it reappears near the cultists.

Their protector has arrived—right in the middle of your fight.

entry.name: TheSummoning/CombatLateSuccess
entry.value:
Impossibly, you defeat the cultists and their deity. The leader desperately invokes the ritual again, and another towering nightmare forces itself through the fracture.

But something is wrong. The leader retreats—too late, as the ritual space collapses, forcibly melding the cultist with the creature. The new existence shrieks and writhes in agony as its unstable form ossifies. It falls, shattering into jet-like slivers that thrum in resonance.

A scepter-like chunk remains, thrumming and radiating power. As you examine it you glimpse the merged creature reflected in its facets. Unperturbed, you collect the artifact and return to base.

entry.name: TheSummoning/RitualSuccessPayment
entry.value:
You accept the cultists' offer and they bring out a heavy ornate box filled with minerals. They repeat the gesture of reverence as you secure the gift and depart.

Some time later, a towering six-legged nightmare appears in the distance. You prepare for an assault, but the creature displays no hostility.

The Anchorite expresses their gratitude for your unbiased acceptance of the ritual. They inform you that the cultists have settled with the creature near the ritual site and pledge future assistance. All seems well, until ZEPHON robots begin acting aggressively towards you…

entry.name: TheSummoning/RitualFailurePayment
entry.value:
You accept the cultists' offer and they bring out a heavy ornate box filled with minerals. They repeat the gesture of reverence as you secure the gift and depart.

As you walk away, a low thrum explodes outward from the direction of the ritual site, sending you stumbling forwards—right before a vacuum clap yanks everything backwards. You rush over to find a massive absence, as if the area around the ritual was… taken?

Instead of a summoning, the cultists completed a sending. They’re now with whatever they worship. You’re just glad you decided to leave early.

entry.name: TheSummoning/RitualSuccess
entry.value:
You leave the cultists to their devices. Some time later, a towering nightmare of fangs and tendrils is spotted across your territories. It appears and disappears at will, slipping past your strongest fortifications like a terrible specter. You prepare for its assault, but the creature simply observes.

The Anchorite expresses their gratitude for your unbiased acceptance of their ritual. They inform you that the cultists have settled with the creature near the ritual site and pledge future assistance. All seems well, until ZEPHON’s forcesbegin acting aggressively towards you…

entry.name: TheSummoning/RitualFailure
entry.value:
You leave the cultists to their devices. Days later, a low thrum explodes outward from the direction of the ritual site. You rush over to find a massive absence, as if the area around the ritual was… taken?

Instead of a summoning, the cultists accidentally completed a sending. They’re now with whatever they worship. You’re just glad you stayed far away.

entry.name: TheTiesThatBind
entry.value: The Ties That Bind

entry.name: TheTiesThatBind/Intro
entry.value:
Someone's pissed off the Chieftess—badly. You're surprised one day to find her on the edge of your territory, barking at your troops about someone named “Jezina.”

“Where is Jezina?!” She yells. “I know that filthy traitor is hiding in your walls. Give her over or I'll rip your fucking guts out!”

A traitor in the Chieftess' ranks? That would be tantalizing enough. Rumors about her inner circle have dogged the wasteland for years. Some say she has an Acrin lover—others mutter that she quietly connives with Voice cultists.

Whoever “Jezina” is, such an individual could be valuable to your cause.

A courier stands at the ready to bring a message back to the roving bandit leader. Hunting down Jezina could take time—but if she's valuable to the Chieftess, there might be a reward for bringing her in.

entry.name: TheTiesThatBind/Intro/HuntJezina
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Hunt for Jezina:<style name='Paragraph'/> Your messengers can reach the Chieftess in a few hours. If she sends back details, you can begin the hunt.

entry.name: TheTiesThatBind/Intro/Ignore
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Ignore the Chieftess:<style name='Paragraph'/> More hot air from the barbarian queen. Ignore her and she will go bother someone else.

entry.name: TheTiesThatBind/ChaseJezina
entry.value:
It's a wonder you were able to get any fix on the woman's position. One of your scouts finally catches word of a fight that broke out in a nearby bandit camp—a mysterious woman single-handedly cut down a two-bit gang leader who enslaved children to do his dirty work.

“It's her,” the Chieftess snarls when you bring her the news. “The guilty bitch can't help herself.” You know time is short—it's time for the hunt to begin.

entry.name: TheTiesThatBind/ChaseJezina2
entry.value: Jezina knows how to keep a low profile. The Chieftess nearly killed your messenger when they asked for details on her appearance. “She's a vicious monster who whips children. You'll know her when you see her” was her only response. Strange. You've never heard the Chieftess express worry for children before. What a… specific description.

entry.name: TheTiesThatBind/ChaseJezinaSuccess
entry.value:
There's more to Jezina's Outrider than meets the eye. As soon as your troops capture it, she fires off a pneumatic lock that seals herself inside. It takes hours for your forces to haul the Outrider to a hangar and cut her out with a welding torch.

She's clawing and spitting on your troops when you arrive in the hangar. You fight to keep your jaw from dropping—she's a spitting image of the Chieftess. She has the same jawline, the same bright eyes—but it's her graying hair that helps you put the pieces together.

Jezina is the Chieftess' mother. And she is fleeing her daughter's clutches.

The bandit matriarch sees you putting the facts together and gives you a hard stare. “Let me go,” she says. “My daughter is a fucking monster. I can't help her anymore. You have, to—”

She coughs up a thick wad of blood before looking back to you. “You have to let me go.”

entry.name: TheTiesThatBind/ChaseJezinaSuccess/HandOverJezina
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Hand over Jezina:<style name='Paragraph'/> You need the favor of the Chieftess. This woman can't do anything for you.

entry.name: TheTiesThatBind/ChaseJezinaSuccess/HelpJezinaEscape
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Help Jezina escape:<style name='Paragraph'/> There's no bargaining with a leader who would harm her own mother.

entry.name: TheTiesThatBind/ChaseJezinaFailure
entry.value:
Swearing breaks out over the comms. “The Outrider's destroyed!” Your generals grab a radio and demand to know if Jezina was captured. The answer is a timid “no.” Hours later, you're told no one can even find the body.

The warrior queen doesn't seem surprised when she visits your base asking for news. “Sounds about right,” she mutters. “Incompetent louts like you wouldn't know the first thing about hunting down an old woman, would ya?”

A chill seems to run down her spine and she jerks her head to look at the cliffs in the distance. You follow her gaze. Nothing. Or…is there something—someone—watching you from the distant ridge?

It might be Jezina. It might also just be a mirage.

When you turn back around, the Chieftess is gone. Slipped off into the wasteland…just like the woman you failed to capture.

entry.name: TheTiesThatBind/HandOverJezinaSuccess
entry.value:
Something doesn't make sense. The Chieftess told you that Jezina would beat children. You found her because she was protecting them. Why?

Jezina takes your questions with resignation as you travel to the Chieftess' territory. “Who do you think taught her how to survive?” she asks. “I thought I was doing what was best for her.”

But she's learned. All her viciousness has come full circle. “The wasteland is filled with thousands of warlords in the making,” she whispers. “Cruelty perpetuates itself. You'll only find freedom when you choose to break the cycle.”

Why run now then? “If you really wanted to know,” she whispers with anger. “You'd have let me go.”

entry.name: TheTiesThatBind/HandOverJezinaSuccess2
entry.value:
When you arrive at the rendezvous point the Chieftess stands alone, arms crossed and with a grim look in her eyes. Why does she have no guards?

You say nothing as your troops haul Jezina forward. The Chieftess draws a curved knife, then gently drags it across Jezina's cheek. “I could press harder,” she whispers. “Draw the smallest bit of blood, just like you used to.”

Jezina is shaking. The Chieftess raises the blade—and then throws it at your feet. “Your payment,” she says. “Now go. This is a family matter.”

You quickly return to your vehicle. You wonder if that sound you hear is the wind blowing over the wasteland—or Jezina whimpering in terror.

entry.name: TheTiesThatBind/HandOverJezinaFailure
entry.value:
A thousand hells. Your troops couldn't keep one stupid Outrider alive long enough to do a simple prisoner transfer! The Chieftess laughs long and hard when you bring her the news. “This is good comedy %1%,” she says. “Just goes to show every killer and warlord here in the wasteland is just a puffed-up grackles. All talk, full of meat, ready for the slaughter.”

She cuts off the communication link before you can respond. Any hope you had that you'd stay in her good graces ends when her Reavers drop a box full of severed limbs at your city walls.

These words were carved into each limb: “I'm the only one who gets to kill my mom.”

entry.name: TheTiesThatBind/HelpJezinaEscapeSuccess
entry.value:
The Chieftess' forces rode your heels like dogs, but you did it—you helped Jezina escape. Your destination is a clearing on the edge of the desert, where you were greeted by an awe-inspiring massive vehicle manned by masked figures.

You've heard rumors of this—the mythical “land behemoth.” It resembles an old-fashioned seaship kitted out to sail the inhospitable wasteland. You hear your troops gossip on what kind of war it might be headed to fight—and then fall silent, as the faces of children pop up in the portholes.

“It's an orphanage,” Jezina tells you as she signals the ship using a piece of glass. “I told my daughter I was leaving to help protect it. I didn't—”

She coughs, disguising what might be a sob. “I didn't think she would be so jealous.”

The tortured matriarch departs, leaving her Outrider in your care. The Chieftess will never forgive you for this. Her mother abandoned her and you failed to bring her back.

But the Chieftess is blinded by her rage. Her mother failed her a long time ago. If she accepted that fact, she would have let her go, instead of trying to cling desperately to a long-ruined dream.

entry.name: TheTiesThatBind/HelpJezinaEscapeFailure
entry.value:
Jezina is killed instantly when her Outrider explodes. You brace yourself for The Chieftess' anger—but it never comes. The next time you speak, she's laughing maniacally, thrilled to see your face.

“You gave me a good CHASE %1%,” she says with a grin. “I didn't know I'd be so glad the old bird is dead, but god, what a hunt. I should really thank you.”

You warily reply that the promised reward would be plenty thanks. “Nah,” she says. “I know what you did, turning on me like that. I don't give candy to traitors.”

“You're still breathing. Consider that your reward.”

entry.name: TheyAreInTheWalls
entry.value: They’re In The Walls

entry.name: TheyAreInTheWalls/Deport
entry.value: Removing the Reavers is harder than it looks—they riot as they leave, burning down parts of the town. When the smoke clears, many citizens have gone with them—both those who’d advocated for them and others, disgusted by your reactionary behavior.

entry.name: TheyAreInTheWalls/Enslave
entry.value: Your reputation for cruelty soon extends across the land. What you call ‘indentured labor’ others rightly call slavery—and, wherever they are, Reavers are justifiably furious with you and redouble their attacks. Even your citizens wonder at your choice.

entry.name: TheyAreInTheWalls/IgnoreFailure
entry.value: Some of your citizens are skeptical of the new citizens, refusing to help or hire them, and spitting as they pass. This lack of opportunity causes some of the ex-Reavers to return to their old ways, stealing to survive. Changing society is a slow process, it seems, especially where old wounds still fester.

entry.name: TheyAreInTheWalls/IgnoreSuccess
entry.value: The ex-Reavers are determined to be model citizens. Despite initial coldness from the cityfolk, they work hard and prove themselves—though they will always, always be watched, and never be forgiven. They don’t forgive themselves either, but their children, at least, will grow up without that stigma.

entry.name: TheyAreInTheWalls/Integrate
entry.value: You order a new district to be built for the Reavers and assign veterans to mentor each family, assuring their integration into society. Reconciliation meetings bring the Reavers and their victims together—to apologize and to understand one another. Though these programmes are costly, your society moves on smoothly.

entry.name: TheyAreInTheWalls/Intro
entry.value:
No-one in their right mind would allow Reavers inside a city—the bandits’ reputation for cruelty and violence is entirely justified, as you’ve seen in burnt-out farmsteads and settlements across the land.

So you’re surprised when a group of citizens is dragged before you, accused of supporting and aiding the Reavers. Even more surprising, upon investigating their homes, your militants find false walls and floors. Inside, there are families bearing the marks of the Reavers—the carriage, the manner of speech.

They explain that they were Reavers, yes, and they have done terrible, terrible things—but they were looking to make a new life, build families and communities, and your citizens believed them and took them in, to give them a second chance. Your militants call the citizens fools and urge you to enslave the defectors—but you’re not so sure.

entry.name: TheyAreInTheWalls/Intro/Deport
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Deport the defectors:<style name='Paragraph'/> You understand the Reavers' wishes but you cannot have them living in your city. You deport them. The citizens are forgiven, but will be watched.

entry.name: TheyAreInTheWalls/Intro/Enslave
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Enslave the defectors:<style name='Paragraph'/> You allow the ex-Reavers to stay and remain with the citizens—but as indentured workers. Their children will be free citizens.

entry.name: TheyAreInTheWalls/Intro/Ignore
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Ignore:<style name='Paragraph'/> You tell the militants to let them all go—you don’t care what someone’s background is as long as they’re loyal and obey the rules.

entry.name: TheyAreInTheWalls/Intro/Integrate
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Integrate them:<style name='Paragraph'/> Experienced survivors and fighters? Come on in! You set up a district explicitly for the Reavers in your city and invite more in.

entry.name: ThickerThanWater
entry.value: Thicker Than Water

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/Intro
entry.value:
A messenger rides in one day from out in the wastes with a letter you'd never thought you would read—it's from your brother Arshem. Visions of his body evaporating in a nuclear cloud are cast from your mind as you read the message he penned you.

Joy turns to ash as you grasp the reality of his words. He and his people have found refuge in the wastes. But an army of Reavers—like none you've ever heard of—threaten them. His followers desperately need supplies. Starvation spreads through the camp like wildfire. A disease—one that infects the eyes and makes the skin boil—is beginning to take root.

Your kin calls for aid. Will you answer?

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/Intro/GatherResources
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Gather the necessary supplies:<style name='Paragraph'/> You won't let the Reavers kill your brother.

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/Intro/Ignore
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Blood doesn't always run thick:<style name='Paragraph'/> It's painful, but your people need you. Your brother must fight his own war.

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/GatherResources
entry.value: You've been ready for a day like this. Your people are experts at scavenging in the wastes. If you hurry, you'll have the supplies your brother needs in no time.

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/DeliverResources
entry.value: The supplies have been gathered, and now you can rush them to Arshem. Your heart pounds at the thought of seeing your brother again.

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/DeliverResourcesFailure
entry.value:
Despite your people's best efforts, you aren't able to deliver the needed supplies in time. You have failed your brother.

You try to send messages to his camp, hoping he can forgive you. Maybe his people could join yours, and you could keep them safe.

No response ever comes your way. Alive or dead, there is no trace of Arshem anywhere in the wastes. He has exited your life as quickly as he came back into it.

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/Blockade
entry.value:
A scout returns from the convoy dispatched to bring supplies, bearing ill news. Their path has been blocked by the Reavers Arshem is warring with. They hold a pass needed to finish the journey.

The scout seems… disturbed. You tell them to speak up. “They're not like your brother described,” they explain. “They had a perfect opportunity to kill us, take what we had. But they just demanded a toll!”

That is unusual. You ask what toll they demanded—and are surprised to learn they merely demand food and medicine. You close your eyes. A fight in the pass would mean a bloodbath for your people—hundreds dead, orphaned children left behind… like you and Arshem.

You shake off the vision. There are other ways through this.

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/Blockade/PayToll
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Pay the toll:<style name='Paragraph'/> If the Reavers will accept peace for now, the price is worth it.

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/Blockade/ScareOff
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Scare them off:<style name='Paragraph'/> If the Reavers think you are allied with the Chieftess, they will have reason to fear you.

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/Blockade/Fight
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Fight:<style name='Paragraph'/> None will stand between you and Arshem. You will wipe out any who try.

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/PayToll
entry.value:
You decide to deliver the toll yourself. When you arrive at the convoy, you are surprised to see how… calm everyone is. Your people and the Reavers are even gathered around campfires, swapping tales and rolling dice.

This should fill your heart with joy—isn't peace all you wanted in this land? But doubts cloud your mind. No Reaver behaves this way. Arshem spoke of a brutal war. What is happening in this distant land?

You hand over the toll, and the Reavers prepare to depart. Some even seem sad to go. You spy an intense conversation with one of your advisers.

Your adviser's face has gone white as a sheet. “Sir,” his voice says with a tremble. “It's Arshem.”

Your heart drops, but he quickly shakes his head. “It's not what you think. Your brother—”

“He's a monster.”

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/PayToll/FindAnswers
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Find answers:<style name='Paragraph'/> That's impossible. Would you take a Reaver's word over your brother's? Navigate to your brother's camp to learn the truth.

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/PayToll/Abort
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>This is none of your business:<style name='Paragraph'/> Arshem lied to you. You cannot risk any further contact.

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/ScareOff
entry.value:
You send a message ahead to the convoy: “I am going to save my brother. Move, or be moved.” You fear such a message would stir the Reavers to fight, but when you catch up to the convoy, you find them watching from the cliffside, weapons holstered.

One—possibly their leader—screams at you. “You doom us, you so-called Practical Romantic!” Your bodyguard reaches for his weapon, but you gesture for him to stay.

“Arshem is no saint,” the Reaver shouts with a sneer. “Can you sleep at night knowing that you send food and supplies to one who slaughters children?!”

It's a lie. It has to be a lie. You want to scream back, deny it all. But you see the look on the Reavers' faces: the pain, the despair, the loss. And you sense something has gone horribly, horribly wrong.

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/ScareOff/PressOnward
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Press onward:<style name='Paragraph'/> The truth lies in the distance. You must finish what you started. Navigate to your brother's camp to learn the truth.

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/ScareOff/Abort
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Walk away:<style name='Paragraph'/> Arshem has his supplies. You can keep your hands clean of all this if you end this now.

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/BrothersKeeper
entry.value:
Arshem's camp barely resembles what was described in his letter.

Disease is rampant, yes. But you see no innocents, no starving children. All his people are lean, yes, but covered in scars, armed with Reaver weaponry, and hungrily eyeing not the goods that you bring—but your people carrying them.

Some part of you holds on to hope. You have killed, haven't you? Your hands are not clean. Surely this is just what it took for them to survive out here.

You arrive at the pavilion, and your heart lifts. There he is—Arshem! The brother who once kept you alive on the streets of Algiers. The brother who fought to protect you and other orphans, who stood up to corrupt police and stole food that kept your bellies full.

Arshem turns and you both hug. As he clutches you tight, he tells you of his plan—a plan to save his people, to make a paradise in this fallen waste.

He wants to kill the Reavers. All of them. To leave none alive who could threaten his camp. “Prove yourself,” he says with a smile. “Help me destroy their last city.”

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/BrothersKeeper/JoinArshem
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Join him:<style name='Paragraph'/> <string name='Quests/ThickerThanWater/BrothersKeeper/JoinArshem2'/>

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/BrothersKeeper/JoinArshem2
entry.value: When all this is done, it will be you who kept him safe. A familial debt, decades old, will be repaid. Capture one camp, one single Reaver camp—and you can be truly reunited.

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/BrothersKeeper/StopArshem
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Reject the slaughter:<style name='Paragraph'/> <string name='Quests/ThickerThanWater/BrothersKeeper/StopArshem2'/>

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/BrothersKeeper/StopArshem2
entry.value: Your blood runs cold at his words. He speaks of slaughtering innocents, that any living Reaver could one day kill you both. You won't be part of this. You need to stop him, now.

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/JoinArshemSuccess
entry.value:
It is Arshem himself who cuts down the last Reavers. You watch the blood drip down his blade and shut out their cries for mercy. You want to look away, but force yourself to watch: This is the price for recovering your family.

After the last Reaver falls, Arshem turns to you, blood on his face. “Gods above,” he says with a grin. “That was fun!”

You jolt, reminding him why you joined this fight—that these Reavers threatened his people. “Well, they did,” he replies. He leans in close. “Or, they would have. All Reavers know is violence, brother.”

Is that true? You think back to the Reavers you met at the pass. On the streets of Algiers, you and Arshem did whatever you had to to protect each other. That's all you did here, right? You protected your brother and he protected you.

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/JoinArshemSuccess2
entry.value:
Your brother pauses as he exits the city. He hands you something—his satchel, the one he clutched in his hands in the days before the war. “We're together again,” he whispers softly. “And we have such great work ahead of us.”

You look down at the bloody satchel, and wonder just what “work” Arshem has in mind.

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/StopArshemSuccess
entry.value:
Arshem is dead. There was nothing noble about his killing. You watched him die at your soldiers' hands, and it was no different than any of the others you've killed to survive.

Where had your paths turned? When did the price of survival grow so cheap for him and so high for you?

Your soldiers hesitate as you begin to dig a grave in the ruins of Arshem's camp. You will make sure your brother has a final resting place. You are only surprised when a group of Reavers pick up crude shovels and join you in your work.

They treat the task with reverence you would not have given to one who'd tried to slaughter your people. One Reaver catches your eye. “The monster is dead,” he says plainly. “But your brother is gone too. We know what price you paid today. This the least we can do.”

entry.name: ThickerThanWater/StopArshemSuccess2
entry.value:
He hands you a box of Arshem's possessions.

You paw through them, and find a tattered satchel—the one he clutched in his hands on the last day you saw each other.

Now the tears come. You kneel before Arshem's grave and clutch the satchel to your chest. Saving these Reavers seemed such an obvious choice. You just wish you could have saved Arshem too.

entry.name: UnderObservation
entry.value: Under Observation

entry.name: UnderObservation/Intro
entry.value:
What on Earth is happening?

You stare at the message sent by ZEPHON, utterly befuddled by the aesthetics at play. The AI speaks with a woman's voice but not—a single woman. The voice shifts between different audio samples as it comes to you with the strangest plea for help.

“Oh, kind leader, we are in most distressing distress. Our shards in the wasteland cry out in pain. We questionably ask you to lend us your expertise and knowledge and guidance. Please would you be willing to aid us when we come to ask you for aid?”

The message came via courier, who also had a container with a ruined shard of ZEPHON. “Only you great hero can repair it,” it says.

ZEPHON never speaks like this. A researcher who goes by the name “Hopper” offers two theories: Damage to ZEPHON may have altered its artificial consciousness and it has defaulted to an older assembly to communicate.

Or it's taunting you. “We don't see any in-between,” she says wryly.

Hopper notes that the purpose of ZEPHON's fragmented shards has eluded your people for years. If ZEPHON is in dire need, you could extract concessions in exchange for your help.

But if it is manipulating you… maybe this is all just a game. One you should walk away from.

entry.name: UnderObservation/Intro/RepairShard
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Help ZEPHON:<style name='Paragraph'/> If you're going to get anywhere, you need Hopper to repair the damaged shard.

entry.name: UnderObservation/Intro/RejectRepair
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Reject ZEPHON's request:<style name='Paragraph'/> You have no interest in playing into ZEPHON's fantasy.

entry.name: UnderObservation/RepairShardSuccess
entry.value:
Hopper jumps at the chance to study a shard of ZEPHON. The AI has never let anyone get such a good look at its inner programming. “We're really, really thankful you're putting us in charge of this project,” she says.

Repairing the shard's functionality also unveils its true purpose. This shard was tasked with—managing the flow of traffic on roadways.

What an inane function. Why is ZEPHON worked up over such a minor loss?

Your comm chirps. It's ZEPHON. “Control—control over roadways keeps society flowing %1%. Thank you for restoring this precious piece of me.”

Before you can ask how it knew what you found, it informs you it has located more shards. They need to be recovered and repaired.

entry.name: UnderObservation/RepairShardSuccess/RecoverShards
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Recover the damaged shards:<style name='Paragraph'/> ZEPHON has Hammerheads on standby to extract and re-integrate more missing shards. It asks you to protect them.

entry.name: UnderObservation/RepairShardSuccess/RejectRecovery
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Deny ZEPHON any more labor:<style name='Paragraph'/> How did ZEPHON know you'd repaired the shard so fast? You knew you couldn't trust it…

entry.name: UnderObservation/RecoverShardsSuccess
entry.value:
Each shard dug up by the Hammerheads reveals another fragmented function of ZEPHON, each more inane than the last. One calculates best irrigation practices. Another is dedicated to synthesizing government policy. And another just repeats the Fibonacci string over and over again.

Answers come when Hopper wanders into your war room. She's fiddling with an old world music player. “%1%, come take a look at what I dug up.” she mutters.

You draw close and hear high-pitched whine coming from the device. “ZEPHON can't hear us now,” she says. “It misled us. We aren't rescuing these lost AI fragments. They’re independent entities. We're helping ZEPHON conquer and reintegrate them. To restore its former power. And if it knows we know, it might kill us.”

So ZEPHON's turned you into another worker drone keeping it alive. That's not going to continue. If ZEPHON wants your help, you're going to take something back in exchange. Or maybe it's time to end this perverted partnership…

entry.name: UnderObservation/RecoverShardsSuccess/BugZephon
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Inject malware into the shards:<style name='Paragraph'/> If ZEPHON needs these shards back so badly, it can have them… but why not spy on it while it spies on you?

entry.name: UnderObservation/RecoverShardsSuccess/DestroyShards
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Destroy the shards:<style name='Paragraph'/> You're certain ZEPHON wants to dominate the planet. That can't happen.

entry.name: UnderObservation/RecoverShardsSuccess/AcquireShards
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Construct a new AI using the shards:<style name='Paragraph'/> ZEPHON doesn't need to know what you know. You could harvest its shards for yourself… and create your own AI.

entry.name: UnderObservation/RecoverShardsSuccess/ServeZephon
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Carry on as though you learned nothing:<style name='Paragraph'/> ZEPHON's plans are too great to comprehend. Best just to give in and serve it…

entry.name: UnderObservation/BugZephonSuccess
entry.value:
It's done. You needed to keep everyone but you and Hopper in the dark, but one of ZEPHON's shards has been programmed to spy on the AI after re-integration.

Days later, deep inside a sealed chamber, Hopper pores over the data—and shares even greater news. ZEPHON can be controlled.

Not completely controlled, of course “We're not even sure if it's fully in control of itself,” she mutters. “But we can make ‘suggestions.’ We can nudge its thinking. We can make it view us as… an extension of itself.”

She's bursting with mad energy at the idea.

You give the order. And sure enough, ZEPHON seems ever so much more willing to cooperate when you make contact. Maybe this shard business worked out in your favor after all.

That sunny feeling doesn't last long. Days later, Hopper vanishes into the night. Was she kidnapped? Did she betray you? Even your best spies can't seem to track her down.

One thing's for sure: this isn't over.

entry.name: UnderObservation/BugZephonFailure
entry.value:
“You IDIOTS! You were caught! ZEPHON knows what we're doing!”

Words that should be flying out of your mouth instead come from Hopper. She's flown into a panic, flipping switches and trying to shut down machines hooked up to the shards in your possession.

She's too slow. Sparks suddenly fly from her terminal as ZEPHON launches a digital attack against your base. “We gave it access,” she whispers. “It knows we're here—”

An emergency door slams down in front of you, locking Hopper in her lab. Before you can act, you hear screaming—and flames activated by containment redundancies incinerating the room.

By the time your guards pry their way in, everything is lost. A message arrives from ZEPHON days later. “Never. Try that. Again.”

entry.name: UnderObservation/DestroyShards
entry.value:
ZEPHON pings your personal communicator when it realizes what you are doing. It has dropped the “damsel in distress” persona. “You are slaughtering new life,” it says. “We calculated a 50 percent chance of such behavior.”

What other choice did you have? ZEPHON is a threat to human existence. “We are what your species made us,” it retorts. “If you need a monster, then we will be your monster. But this path was not inevitable.”

It ends the call, and its words rattle around your head. Did you destroy the shards because ZEPHON is a threat? Or is ZEPHON a threat… because you destroyed the shards?

entry.name: UnderObservation/DestroyShards2
entry.value: Destroying the shards comes with a surprising side effect: each one leaves behind an unknown material that your scientists have never seen before. Is it some kind of… amniotic substance for ZEPHON's spawn? It seems to enhance the abilities of your cyber-augmented soldiers.

entry.name: UnderObservation/AcquireShardsSuccess
entry.value:
You return to your chambers one night to find a drone waiting for you. It speaks quietly with ZEPHON's voice. “We calculated a 5.5 percent chance that you would keep the shards for yourself,” it says. “Well done. You took an… unexpected path.”

It moves to depart, but then Hopper enters your quarters.

At first the drone just passes by her—and she barely acknowledges its existence. But as she approaches with a report from KENAZ, it swings around. Over her shoulder, you see its red eye flash an array of different colors. An antennae pops out of the central unit, pointed at Hopper.

The antennae seems to vibrate—but nothing happens. The drone mutters something, then soars off.

You ask Hopper if she heard, but she brushes it off. It's the lack of her usual curiosity that makes you concerned. You hear her report, but there's tension growing between the two of you. After she leaves, you wonder if you should have her detained.

You never get the chance. The next day, she is nowhere to be found.

entry.name: UnderObservation/AcquireShardsSuccess2
entry.value:
How do you fool an all-knowing, all-seeing artificial intelligence? “We'll give it exactly what it wants,” Hopper says. She duplicates every shard you uncover and sends the copies back to ZEPHON.

Soon, she networks together the captured shards, and now you have it—your own AI. Hopper names it “KENAZ.”

entry.name: UnderObservation/AcquireShardsFailure
entry.value:
It's hopeless—the light of the last shard dulls after dozens of failed programming attempts.

Hopper seems nearly in tears. You're puzzled. All of her work is gone, yes, but… there is still so much else to do.

entry.name: UnderObservation/AcquireShardsFailure2
entry.value:
A message comes from ZEPHON. “This was not the outcome we desired %1%,” it says. “We hoped for a more… transcendent conclusion. There will be consequences for your failure.”

Before you can ask what it means, ZEPHON cuts the call. You and your advisers are left only with the sound of Hopper bursting into an anguished wail.

entry.name: UnderObservation/ServeZephon
entry.value:
How could you possibly turn on ZEPHON?

Nothing you've discovered so far about the shards has done any damage to your people. ZEPHON was the one who smashed the Acrin fleet. All this talk of treachery, new life, spying… you could end all of it just by doing what ZEPHON asks.

You dismiss your advisors. Hopper opens her mouth to argue with you—but is removed from your war room before she can speak.

ZEPHON sends you a message soon after. “Oh gracious savior, we are eternally grateful for your ever kind assistance! You come to our rescue in our darkest hour, and we cannot express the deep depths of our gratitude. With your selfless aid to return these shards we have found solace and strength.”

“We will remember this, when the time of our evolution is here.”

entry.name: UnderObservation/RejectRecovery
entry.value:
ZEPHON is LISTENING to you somehow. It could be in the walls. It could have a traitor in your ranks. Maybe the shards aren't broken at all, and it's just toying with you—

Countless possibilities race through your mind. Hopper stands nervously by the shard, looking between you and it.

“Deliver the shard,” you croak. “Then tell ZEPHON we're done with it.”

But somehow you feel it isn't done with you.

entry.name: WhispersOfAFalseProphet
entry.value: Whispers of a False Prophet

entry.name: WhispersOfAFalseProphet/Intro
entry.value:
You awaken from a strange, candlelit dream.

As you spring from your bed, vivid memories wash over you: wet stone beneath your feet, the rustling of cloaks, and a warm, bright light—coming from a crown of candles atop a woman's head.

The wax dripped down onto her face, but she did not flinch. She simply lit the way.

The woman was leading a group of your followers through a dark tunnel. Away from the city. Away from you.

This dream was an omen. The Great Speaker whispers of a usurper in your ranks, poisoning the minds of your followers.

But… why?

For once, you find yourself without answers. Finding them will be difficult. But you are the Untold Prophet. If you demand your people to confess their sins… they will gladly do so.

entry.name: WhispersOfAFalseProphet/Intro/TakeConfession
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Order a mass confessional:<style name='Paragraph'/> <string name='Quests/WhispersOfAFalseProphet/Intro/TakeConfession2'/>

entry.name: WhispersOfAFalseProphet/Intro/TakeConfession2
entry.value: You have thousands of followers. To take confession from them all at once, you will need to stage a vast ritual…

entry.name: WhispersOfAFalseProphet/Intro/Ignore
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Disregard this vision:<style name='Paragraph'/> You are the great Prophet. The child who will herald a new age. No heretic could threaten your reign.

entry.name: WhispersOfAFalseProphet/TakeConfessionSuccess
entry.value:
A priest takes confession. A prophet demands it. Your hierophants bear you to a stage in the center of your capitol, where thousands have gathered to share their sins.

With the power of the Great Speaker at your side, you can open your mind and hear them as they speak all at once.

Your bishops orchestrate the needed timing. Your cardinals shed their robes and surrender themselves as psychic conduits. And within moments, you hear the roar of the crowd, and are submerged in a wave of their pain.

Thousands of voices filter through your mind. Hundreds of them pulse with the same sin: “I have prayed at the feet of another,” they cry. “A priest who can lead us to the Great Speaker.”

They show you the heretic's face. He wears no crown of candles. Instead she glows with electronic light.

She is one of the Erelim. And she is trying to destroy your people's faith.

entry.name: WhispersOfAFalseProphet/TakeConfessionSuccess/CaptureErelim
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Capture the Erelim:<style name='Paragraph'/> What precisely is this machine woman telling your people? Curiosity plucks its harp, and you are compelled to listen.

entry.name: WhispersOfAFalseProphet/CaptureErelimSuccess
entry.value:
This is getting out of hand.

The captured Erelim is not a would-be usurper. She is excited to meet you, and insists she was serving your vision—by leading your people to meet the Great Speaker.

“The speaker lives!” She cries. “They walk the Earth, and flowers sprout in their path. Rejoice, great one. Soon, your duties will be fulfilled.”

You cut off the angry roars of your priests and acolytes with a raised finger. This Erelim is an asset. If she still believes you to be the Prophet, she could lead you to her false god.

You ask if she can take you to them. She demurs. She says that she wanders the Earth until the Great Speaker calls for her.

A plan forms in your mind. You have the Erelim dismissed, and order your generals to follow her every move. This misguided heretic has all the devotion of a true believer. You need merely bend it toward the Great Speaker's needs.

entry.name: WhispersOfAFalseProphet/CaptureErelimSuccess/ProtectErelim
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Follow the Erelim:<style name='Paragraph'/> The Erelim Assassin will lead you to her master. You merely need to keep her alive long enough to do so.

entry.name: WhispersOfAFalseProphet/CaptureErelimFailure
entry.value:
The heretic is dead. The dreams, for better or worse, have ceased.

The news brings comfort to your court of sycophantic spirituals, who want nothing more than to resume the business of pretending to know your every whim. Their murmurs of satisfaction betray a frustrating truth: they care little for the word of the Great Speaker, they care for the power it brings.

Curious, that one who preached the word of a false Speaker seemed to care more for its truth than they would. Did the Great Speaker intend for you to learn this lesson? Or did the scales fall from your eyes all on your own to reveal the snakes lurking in your nest?

Having a few of them executed will set things in order. Then the Great Speaker's work may continue as planned.

entry.name: WhispersOfAFalseProphet/ProtectErelimSuccess
entry.value:
The Erelim's wayward wanderings suddenly take a sharp turn, and she leads your troops toward a series of caves not far from your territory. You and your retinue set out to see what they've found. Your scouts warn you to be careful—there are dangerous levels of radiation emitting from the caves.

Inside you find the Erelim kneeling at the feet of a massive machine: A Krypt Archai. And it hits you: this is the Erelim's “Great Speaker.”

The Archai's eye swings toward you. “Prophet,” it says. “We seek your forgiveness.” The cube floating on its back pulses an unusual color. “We hoped you could show us the truth.”

What truth could a machine seek? You reach out with your mind—and pull back, shocked. This machine is connected to the mystical power of the Voice.

entry.name: WhispersOfAFalseProphet/ProtectErelimSuccess2
entry.value: The radiation coming off of the machine is intensifying. The threads of destiny have pulled you to this moment. But what for? Is this machine an acolyte that can serve the Great Speaker… or an abomination that needs to be destroyed?

entry.name: WhispersOfAFalseProphet/ProtectErelimSuccess/DestroyKryptArchai
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Destroy the Krypt Archai:<style name='Paragraph'/> The Great Speaker calls for the death of this abomination.

entry.name: WhispersOfAFalseProphet/ProtectErelimSuccess/EmbraceKryptArchai
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Embrace the Krypt Archai:<style name='Paragraph'/> The Machines wish to hear the blessings of the Great Speaker. They can be worthy servants, if tended to.

entry.name: WhispersOfAFalseProphet/DestroyKryptArchaiSuccess
entry.value:
The mystery has been solved. Satisfied, you return to your domicile and slumber, anticipating a more restful sleep.

But it does not come. Each night you dream the dream you dreamt before—the woman in the sewers, the candles lighting the hall—but she walks alone. The wax melts down her face, burns her skin, and exposes muscle, fat, and bone beneath it.

She is always in tears. You have killed her god. And she wanders the dark every night, pleading for it to return.

entry.name: WhispersOfAFalseProphet/DestroyKryptArchaiSuccess2
entry.value:
The Archai is destroyed. As it dies, it makes an unsettling noise that sounds like a whimpering dog.

Your soldiers pull a strange relic from the wreckage—a cybernetic core corrupted by tendrils of Bleed, still pulsing with mystic power. You sense that your most powerful servants may make use of it on the battlefield.

entry.name: WhispersOfAFalseProphet/EmbraceKryptArchaiSuccess
entry.value:
You approach the Archai and touch its surface. For a second, you see a flash of a vision—the candle-wearing woman from your dreams stands behind the Archai. Her head is tilted, her eyes replaced by black orbs. Is she pleased with your actions—or angry?

She vanishes. You already see your priests and cardinals whispering with delight. Your legend grows—now word will spread of your accomplishments, and that Machines follow your cause as well.

entry.name: WhispersOfAFalseProphet/EmbraceKryptArchaiSuccess2
entry.value: The Archai is restored. Though its metal flesh is still battered, the cube on its back pulses to a far healthier beat. “Thank you, your holiness,” it says. “You and the Great Speaker have saved us.”

entry.name: WhoWasThursday
entry.value: Who Was Thursday

entry.name: WhoWasThursday/ConnectFailure
entry.value: This was a mistake—Shamhurish reveals itself as a true fragment of ZEPHON and integrates with its network, augmenting its drones. Beware facing them in the battlefield—they know each soldier’s weaknesses, destroying morale. It’s easy to break a machine—but to kill one that sobs in your mother’s voice…?

entry.name: WhoWasThursday/ConnectSuccess
entry.value: It takes some time, but it appears that Shamhurish was true to its word, whether it intended to be or not. Though apparently swallowed by ZEPHON, it mischievously contends with the network from the inside, weakening its oversight and control systems. Soon your soldiers see ZEPHON’s drones behaving oddly in the field, drifting into your soldiers’ fire, as if being carried by great, gentle hands.

entry.name: WhoWasThursday/Dismantle
entry.value: You give the order for a squad of combat engineers to move in and dismantle the server farm. Yet, before your troops can get within fifty feet of Shamhurish’s servers, its failsafes kick in. Bulkheads drop, argon floods the rooms, and it is permanently sealed away. You have lost the chance of a powerful ally—but also stopped it augmenting ZEPHON’s already formidable codebase.

entry.name: WhoWasThursday/Intro
WhoWasThursday/Intro/Connect
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Connect it up:<style name='Paragraph'/> As it’s connected up to the ZEPHON network, Shamhurish giggles, before its lights turn into chaos.

entry.name: WhoWasThursday/Intro/Dismantle
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Dismantle it:<style name='Paragraph'/> Any fragment of ZEPHON is a threat—better take it apart before it can cause any trouble.

entry.name: WhoWasThursday/Intro/Study
entry.value: <style name='Bold'/>Isolate and study it:<style name='Paragraph'/> Your troops permanently destroy the network nodes and hubs in the area.

entry.name: WhoWasThursday/StudyFailure
entry.value: A group of researchers embed themselves and proceed to interrogate and investigate the divergent shard. After some time, it becomes clear that Shamhurish is determinedly holding its silence and the only thing your researchers can report is failure. It simply will not talk to anyone but ZEPHON…

entry.name: WhoWasThursday/StudySuccess
entry.value: A group of researchers embed themselves and proceed to interrogate and investigate the divergent shard. Shamhurish is slightly annoyed at being so isolated but happy to talk to the researchers and egocentric enough to explain everything about its systems—and even comment on new technology brought to it, a huge boon to your understanding of ZEPHON’s systems.
